editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: IT is now ≈øomewhat vpward of two yeares,This mu≈øt be referred to the time wheÃÑ the Author writ it. ≈øince pa≈øsing through the City of Bri≈øtol towards the Vniuer≈øity of Cambridge, I was by the importunity of ≈øundry Cittizens, my very good friends, arre≈øted there certaine daies. For no ≈øooner was I there arrived, but pre≈øently they repaired vnto me, and like ≈øo many Iacobs began to wre≈øtle with me,Gen 32.24.26. Rom. 1.11. Mat. 11.12. prote≈øting they would not let me goe vnle≈ø≈øe I fir≈øt promi≈øed to ble≈øse them, and to be≈øtow ≈øome ≈øpirituall gift among them. It was no ≈ømall Ioy vnto mee to ≈øee the Kingdome of Heaven ≈øuffer ≈øuch violence, and the people of God (like ≈øo many thir≈øty Harts,P≈øal. 42.1. braying for the rivers of waters,) & paÃÑting after the liuing God. Wherefore I could not but with Iacobs Angel giue them leaue to prevaile,Gen. 32.28. Mat. 5.41. & yeeld ≈øo farre vnto their earne≈øt reque≈øt, that being angariated to goe but one mile, I was notwithstanding content to goe with them more then twaine, preaching (before my departure thence) divers ≈øermons vnto them.

One time among the re≈øt I cho≈øe for my Theme that of St Paul to the Ephe≈øians, Ephe≈ø. 6. 16. Aboue all take the ≈øhield of Faith whereby ye may quench all the fiery darts of that wicked One. Wherein becau≈øe Iu≈øtifying Faith ≈øeemed to be commended as the principallest peece of the Christians Panoplie, & of ≈øure≈øt proofe again≈øt all the a≈ø≈øaults & temptations
of Satan, I held it nece≈ø≈øary with all diligence to enquire what might be the true nature and definition thereof, and at length I re≈øolued that the Act thereof was not A≈ø≈øurance but Affiance, the Subiect not the vnder≈øtanding, but the will; and the Obiect not pre≈øent grace and future glory, but the per≈øon of the Mediator. So that I defined it, not as vulgarly it is conceiued, An a≈øsurance that we are already ju≈øtified and ≈øhall be ≈øaued; but thus, An affiance vpon Chri≈øt the Mediator for ju≈øtification and con≈øequently Saluation. The occa≈øioÃÑ mouing me to intreat of this argument was this; A certaine graue and godly Matrone of that City hauing beene a long time ≈øore afflicted with ≈øickne≈øse both in mind and body, I went vpon entreaty with other friends to vi≈øit her; and after mutuall ≈øalutation, Si≈øter quoth I vnto her, were I Phy≈øitian for the body, I would adui≈øe you the be≈øt I could for the health thereof: but it is not my element, and therefore I may not without great ra≈øhne≈øse put my ≈øelfe into it: neuerthele≈øse if you ≈øhall plea≈øe to di≈øcouer vnto me the wound of your ≈øpirit, happily I may apply ≈øuch a ≈øalue thereunto, as by the ble≈øsing of God may clo≈øe it vp, or at lea≈øt giue ≈øome refocilation and ea≈øe vnto the angui≈øh thereof. My wound then, quoth ≈øhe, in a word is this: I want faith; And what may be the ground, quoth I, of this per≈øwa≈øion? Becau≈øe, quoth ≈øhe, I am not a≈ø≈øured that I am iu≈øtified and ≈øhall be ≈øaued: A weake ground, quoth I, ≈øeeing a man may haue Faith that wanteth ≈øuch A≈øsurance; how may that be, quoth ≈øhe? for as hitherto I haue beene taught, Faith is no other then A≈øsurance: then haue you beene taught ami≈øse, quoth I: and if this be all the ≈øcruple that troubleth you, I hope ere we part to fini≈øh the cure. Thereupon I began freely to declare what I conceiued of the true nature of iu≈øtifying Faith, and proued vnto her by ≈øundrie remon≈øtrances that
it was not A≈ø≈øurance but Affiance, and with ≈øo good ≈øucce≈øse, that both ≈øhe and all that were pre≈øent re≈øted therewith much comforted and contented. Only they prayed me both for their owne confirmation, and the farther information of others, that I would be plea≈øed to ≈øpeak of it againe in a more publike audience: wherevnto (≈øeeing no rea≈øon to di≈ø≈øwade me) I readily conde≈øcended, and on the text afore≈øaid handled the matter ≈øomewhat largely.

This Sermon at lea≈øt ≈øo farre as concernes the Definition of Faith was by one Mr Baxter then preacher of that City greatly di≈øta≈øted and di≈øliked: in ≈øo much as by me≈øsage he threatned me with open confutation thereof in the Pulpit, vnle≈øse I gaue him the ≈øpeedier & better ≈øatisfaction; which threatning though I little feared, knowing I had built nor hay nor ≈øtubble vpon the foundation, 1 Cor. 3.12.13. but ≈øuch doctrines as were well able to endure the triall of the fire: yet becau≈øe the Apo≈øtle chargeth to be ready alwayes to giue an≈øwere to euery man that asketh a rea≈øon of the Hope that is in vs, 1 Pet. 3.15. I was eft≈øoones willing the be≈øt I could to ≈øatisfie him. Being therefore by the mediation of ≈øome friends brought to a parlie with him, I prayed him to remember that what≈øoeuer I ≈øayd in that Sermon was not barely affirmed but ≈øoundly proued, and therefore he might not in rea≈øon demaund ≈øatisfaction of me vntill him≈øelfe had ≈øatisfied my rea≈øons: which if he ≈øhould ≈øubstantially doe, I would ea≈øe him of his Pulpit-confutation, and the ≈øame tongue that broched the errour, ≈øhould in the ≈øame place againe reuoke it. Then began I to pre≈ø≈øe him with this argument, If faith be A≈ø≈øurance, then God commanding a Reprobate to beleeue, commands him al≈øo to be a≈ø≈øured, which is ab≈øurd: whereunto all his an≈øwere was, who art thou that di≈øpute≈øt with God? I replied,Rom. 9.20. that I neither di≈øputed with God nor controled
his actions: but only denyed that God commands a Reprobate to be a≈ø≈øured, for ≈øo he ≈øhould command that to be beleeued for true, which nor is nor euer ≈øhall be true. Againe I argued thus, If Faith be A≈ø≈øurance, then who≈øoeuer wanteth A≈ø≈øurance wanteth Faith, which to a di≈øtre≈ø≈øed ≈øoule is mo≈øt vncomfortable. To this he an≈øwered that de≈øire of A≈ø≈øurance is in the acceptation of God as A≈øsurance it ≈øelfe. I replyed, that Mr Perkins being vrged with the ≈øame Obiection an≈øwered in the ≈øame manner, but vn≈øufficiently: for if actuall Faith be nece≈øsary to iu≈øtification, then is actuall A≈ø≈øurance al≈øo nece≈ø≈øary if Faith be a≈ø≈øurance: Here Mr Baxter would needs take occa≈øion to expo≈øtulate, why I ≈øhould pre≈øume to define otherwi≈øe then Mr. Perkins, and ≈øo many worthy Divines had done before mee. Wherevnto I an≈øwered roundly and plainely, Socrates is deare, Ari≈øt. Eth. l. 1. c. 5.
and Plato is deare, but truth is farre dearer: and therefore prayed him that leauing to oppo≈øe authority vnto rea≈øon, and ≈øounding names vnto ≈øound proofes, hee would returne againe within the lists, and either ≈øatisfie what I had ≈øaid, or giue mee leaue to proceed to the rest of my arguments; But for this he craved, as then, to bee excu≈øed, pretending vrgent and in≈øtant bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, yet offering to haue our conference adiourned vnto ≈øome other day: I told him that the time of ab≈øence (limited me from the Colledge, whereof I was then Fellow) was almo≈øt at an end; ≈øo that vnle≈ø≈øe I would hazard my place I might make no longer stay there: neverthele≈ø≈øe if he plea≈øed I would before my departure giue him my minde in writing, and attend his an≈øwere al≈øo in writing at his better lei≈øure: To this hee pre≈øently conde≈øcended, holding it the fittest cour≈øe, and promi≈øing (if I held my word with him) within one Moneth to returne me his full an≈øwere. I a≈ø≈øured him that for my
part I would not faile him: and therevpon embracing one the other, and giuing hand that wee would proceed as wee had begun with all peace and loue, we brake off talke at that time and departed. The ≈øecond day after, according to promi≈øe, I ≈øent him the Treati≈øe following, Of the true nature & definition of iu≈øtifying Faith, comprizing therein with ≈øome addition what≈øoeuer touching the matter in que≈øtion I had more briefly deliuered in the Pulpit: and the next morning taking leaue of my friends, & commending them to the grace of God in Chri≈øt I ≈øet forward for Cambridge.

The moneth being expired I looked out for my an≈øwere: for I could not thinke he would proue a bad pay-ma≈øter, and breake day with me: But a moneth and a moneth and many other moneths followed after their predece≈ø≈øor, and all the while not a word from my Antagoni≈øt: which though in ≈øome Creditors it would haue bred ≈øu≈øpition, yet was I content to lay hold on the better handle, and to ≈øet the best con≈øtruction I could vpon his ouerlong ≈øilence,Epi≈øt. Fam. l. 9. ep. 8. interpreting it as Cicero did his frend Varros forbearance, rather Diligence then Slacknes. For as Zeuxis was the longer in drawing his Pictures, becau≈øe as he ≈øaid vnto Agatharchus, he painted vnto Eternity: ≈øo Mr Baxter perhaps might the more ≈ølowely come off with his an≈øwere, that in the meane ≈øea≈øon he might make it the more exact and accurate, it being ≈øeldome ≈øeene that the ≈øame thing is both ha≈øtily and exqui≈øitely done. But while I was thus ingenuou≈øly cen≈øuring his ≈øilence, and re≈øoluing yet further to forbeare him, remembring that of Cato, Soone enough if well enough: I receiued certaine aduerti≈øement that he had erewhile broken ≈øilence, and di≈øper≈øed among his friends a most bitter and contumelious Invectiue again≈øt me, contrary both to his promi≈øe that he would proceed with all peace and charity,
and the reputation of learning he ≈øo much affects, not daring to ≈øend me a Copy thereof. Loth I was ≈øeeing I haue not the rule of other mens pens, that others ≈øhould haue the command of my affections: yet being ≈øo vrgently & vn≈øchollerly dealt withall, the next time I pa≈øsed through the City I could not but with ≈øome indignation challenge him for it to his face: At which time how he faltered and staggered in his tale, now confidently affirming he had by a friend conueyed his an≈øwer vnto me, & by & by being conte≈øted by the party, ≈øhamefully retracting it. Pretending for excu≈øe the lo≈ø≈øe of my paper, I appeale to them who then both ≈øaw and heard it. But this I ≈øay, that as his incon≈øtancy and distraction bewrayed little friend≈øhip betwixt his heart & tongue, & argued a ≈øelfe-guiltines of a poore and ≈øorry Reply: ≈øo the preteÃÑced lo≈ø≈øe of my paper was but a ≈øilly ≈øhift to delay me for the pre≈øent, and as the euent ≈øhewes a mi≈øerable tergiuer≈øation. For hauing a fre≈øh offered within one moneth to ≈øend me an an≈øwere, and thereupon engaged both his credit and ≈øcholler≈øhip if he were ≈øupplied with another coppy: although the next day I left one for him vnder my hand, and now not one onely but twelue monthes are ≈øince fully fini≈øhed and expired, yet hath he hitherto beene to me ward as ≈øilent as midnight: to me ward I ≈øay, for otherwi≈øe the libell still pa≈øsed vnder hand, and at euery meeting made his di≈øciples good glee. Whereby it plainly appeareth, his meaning neuer was by an honest and christian entercour≈øe of writing to ≈øift out the truth: but onely by ≈øecret pamphletting to disparage me among his followers, that ≈øo him≈øelfe might ri≈øe the higher, in the ballance of their e≈øtimation. For had he ≈øincerely and vnfainedly purpo≈øed the maintenance of Gods truth, and the reformation of my erronious iudgment, would he thus vncharitably haue played his prizes in the dark, and to
michingly haue gone about to ≈øteale an opinion of victory? or would he not rather as became a right Champion of truth boldly haue confronted his aduer≈øary in the field, yea though hee had beene armed with no better weapon then a fillie ≈øling, as long as he came (for ≈øo he pretends) in the name of the Lord of Ho≈øts? But the truth is perceiuing him≈øelfe ≈øo farre aduanced into the battell that now without ≈øhame and confu≈øion hee might not retreat, hee held it the ≈øafe≈øt cour≈øe by writing ≈øomething to make the world beleeue hee had duly performed with mee, and yet by limiting it vnto the hands of a few of his tru≈øtie≈øt friends to depriue mee of all po≈øsibility of an≈øwering for my ≈øelfe, re≈øting a≈ø≈øured that my ≈øilence would be taken to proceed rather of weaknes and in≈øufficiencie in me, then any nece≈øsitie by his cunning enforced vpon mee. A new kinde of policie, or of malice rather as Hierome ≈øaith vnto Ruffin,Contra Ruffin. ad Pamm. & Marcell. l. 1. c. 1. to accu≈øe of what you feare to di≈øcouer, and to write what you would haue concealed. And ≈øo warie and heedfull hath he been herein, that with all the diligence and endeauour I could v≈øe, I could not for the ≈øpace of full two twelue moneths be ≈øeized of his An≈øwer.

But at length the night-raven fell into the ≈ønare, and by the watchfulne≈ø≈øe of my good friends in Bri≈øtow I obtained ≈øuch a Copie thereof as with all his ≈øhifts and excu≈øes hee cannot po≈øsibly di≈øclaime, being indeed ≈øub≈øcribed with his owne hand. Perhaps you may think it found me when I first receaued it, ≈øtrongly fore≈øtalled and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with preiudice: and indeed his ba≈øe and vnworthie dealing de≈øerued no other. For how could I entertaine any indifferent conceit of that whereof the authors ≈øelfe ≈øeemed to bee a≈øhamed? Neverthele≈ø≈øe before I began to perv≈øe it, ≈øo farre prevailed I over my affections, that I throughly cleered them of all partialitie
and pre≈øumption, yea and grew ≈øo rigorous & vnequall again≈øt my ≈øelfe, that I was content to ≈øuppo≈øe I might be in error, and he happily the Phy≈øitian to cure the di≈øea≈øe of my iudgement, re≈øolving if I might plainely be convinced to take vnto me Christian ≈øeverity and recant the ≈øame. For if I may not hope in this life to a≈øpire to the highe≈øt degree of wi≈ødome, yet would I willingly ri≈øe to ≈øome degree of mode≈øty: that if I may not in all things ≈øay that which is not to be repented of, yet I may at least repent me of what I haue ≈øaid ami≈ø≈øe.

In this temper and di≈øpo≈øition I tooke the booke, and ca≈øting mine eye vpon the front thereof, there I found it thus in≈øcribed. The an≈øwer of Nath. Baxter Bachelor in Divinitie and Warden of new Colledge in Yoghul to the arguments of Mr Io. Downe Bachelor in Divinitie in a controver≈øie of ju≈øtifying Faith, preached by the ≈øaid Mr Downe in Bri≈øtoll. Then vnderneath, the Que≈øtion thus ≈øtated M. Downe; Iu≈øtifying Faith is not a≈ø≈øurance, per≈øwa≈øion, or firme knowledge of a mans ≈øalvatioÃÑ in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus. M. Baxter; Iu≈øtifying Faith is an a≈ø≈øurance and knowledge of our ≈øalvation in Chri≈øt Ie≈øu. And la≈øtly vnder that againe this pa≈ø≈øage of Calvin vouched,In ad Colo≈ø≈ø. c. 1. to. 6. The Faith of the Go≈øpell is properly called a knowledge of the grace of God: becau≈øe no man ever ta≈øted of the Go≈øpell but he which knew him≈øelfe reconciled vnto God, and apprehended his ≈øalvation offered to him in Chri≈øt. In the in≈øcription, though it plea≈øe him in ≈øuch ≈øort to stile him≈øelfe, I thinke to make the reader beleeue that I had met with my peer at lea≈øt;Horat. lib. 1. Sat. 7. and if I were a Bithus, he were no le≈øse then a Bacchius: yet could he not without great arrogance challenge tho≈øe titles to him≈øelfe, hauing never taken ≈øuch degree in either of the Univer≈øities, and being no more
Warden of Yoghul then was Captaine Stukelie Marques of Ireland, Gentil. exam. Conc. Trid. Se≈ø≈ø. 1. or Robert Venantius in the Councel of Trent Archibi≈øhop of Armach. As touching the Que≈øtion that al≈øo is very defectiuely and imperfectly propounded: for neither doe J maintaine negatiuely alone that Faith is not A≈ø≈øurance, but affirmatiuely al≈øo that it is Affiance. neither doth he only affirme contradictorily vnto me that it is A≈ø≈øurance, but further granteth in his An≈øwer that it includeth al≈øo my Affiance. And as for the pa≈ø≈øage of Calvin, to what end it is here prefixed vnle≈øse it be to preiudicate mee with the greatne≈øse of his authoritie, I knowe not. But as hee would hold it vnrea≈øonable if another ≈øhould vrge him therewith in the que≈øtion of Eccle≈øia≈øticall Policie & conformitie, becau≈øe him≈øelfe is of another minde: ≈øo neither hath he any rea≈øon to pre≈ø≈øe the ≈øame vpon me in this controver≈øie wherein I profe≈ø≈øe my ≈øelfe (but with all mode≈øtie) to differ from him. The≈øe fla≈øhings, as it were, and inflammations thus appearing in the very face of his booke, made mee I confe≈ø≈øe, ≈øomewhat stagger in my former re≈øolution, and to doubt lest they might be ≈øymptomes of an vn≈øound and di≈øtempered bodie. Neverthele≈ø≈øe I was not ≈øo driven from my ≈øtation but that I ea≈øily recovered the ≈øame againe. For fearing le≈øt as the Phy≈øiognomer was foully deceiued, iudging of Socrates only by his outward Phy≈ønomie and countenance; ≈øo I al≈øo might be as much mi≈øtaken if by the front alone I ≈øhould make an e≈øtimate of the whole An≈øwer: I was ≈øoone per≈øwaded, yet further to ≈øu≈øpend my verdict vntill I had taken a full and thorow ≈øurvay thereof: Which when I had once done, then indeed began I to be greatly aba≈øhed, and vtterly to condemne my ≈øelfe of fooli≈øh lightne≈ø≈øe and credulity,Mat. 7.16. that could hope ≈øo ≈øuddenly to gather Grapes of Thornes; or reape other then tares in the field of the envious
man. For whereas touching the manner I looked hee ≈øhould haue followed the Apo≈øtles coun≈øell, who advi≈øeth to in≈øtruct with meekne≈ø≈øe tho≈øe that are contrary minded, if God at any time will giue them repentance to acknowledge the truth: 2 Tim. 2.25. he as if he had to deale, not with a brother erring of infirmity, but ≈øome ob≈øtinate Heretike condemned of his owne con≈øcience,Tit. 3.11. inflames his affections again≈øt me in as high a degree as was Nabucodono≈øors furnace, ≈øeven times hotter then Christian charity could haue made them: And whereas touching the matter I expected that hee who ≈øtood ≈øo much vpoÃÑ tearmes of ≈øcholler≈øhip, ≈øhould v≈øe nothing el≈øe but Syllogi≈ømes and nece≈ø≈øary Demon≈øtrations, that by pure vertue and fine force he might captiue my rea≈øon vnto the obedience of Faith: he rather like an idle declaimer, tru≈øting more to the noi≈øe and multitude of his words then the ≈øtrength and pregnancy of his rea≈øons, traver≈øeth a loofe in vnnece≈ø≈øary and impertinent di≈øcour≈øes, and puffs vp his empty An≈øwer with the breath of many frivolous & vainely affected phra≈øes, gaining perhaps thereby applau≈øe of the vulgar and ≈øimple, but from the graue and learned no better entertainment then the Shepheards whi≈øtle. In a word,Cic. l. 1. ep. 13. ad Attic. Hi≈øt. nat. lib. 12. c. 19. as the Troglodytes (of whom Pliny reports) venture vpon the maine Ocean, withou ‚Ä¢ either rudder or oare or ≈øayle, hauing in their boats nothing but man and boldne≈øse: even ≈øo my adver≈øary hazardeth him≈øelfe vpon this deepe que≈øtion, and taketh vpon him the Confutation of my Treati≈øe, v≈øing therein nor naturall rea≈øon, nor humanity, nor divinitie, but only impudent facing, and de≈øperate a≈øseveration.

The con≈øideration of all which halfe per≈øwaded me at the fir≈øt not to vouch≈øafe it any Replication at all, but without farther ceremonie to commit it to the mercy of the Moth
or the Grocer. For how could I reply vnto it, but either I mu≈øt grace it by making it ≈øeeme worthy to be confuted, or di≈øgrace my ≈øelfe by coÃÑfuting ≈øo vnworthy a ioy? And what ≈øhould I reioine vnto it? That which is ≈øerious and of importance‚ñ™ I could not, becau≈øe he giues me no occa≈øion: Reproch for reproch, and ≈ølander for ≈ølander? I might not, becau≈øe it is vnchri≈øtian: and to an≈øwer a foole according to his folly were to proue like vnto him, as Salomon ≈øaith.Prou. 26.4. Howbeit vpon riper adui≈øe and deliberation I held it for ≈øundrie cau≈øes if not nece≈ø≈øary yet very expedient and fitting to ≈øhape him an an≈øwer. And fir≈øt in re≈øpect of him, if it may be to expre≈øse his audaciou≈ønes, and to let him ≈øee that they oftentimes leap too ≈øhort, who thinke to make anothers impeachement ari≈øe for their owne reputation. For if a foole be not an≈øwered according to his folly, Prou. 26.5. he will ≈øaith Salomon, waxe wi≈øe in his owne conceit. Then ≈øecondly in regard of my owne ≈øelfe, and the credit of my Ministery, to wipe away the ≈ølanderous a≈øper≈øions and imputations of I know not what ≈øtrange opinions and dangerous intentions wrongfullie if not maliciou≈øly charged vpon me: lest if I di≈ø≈øemble them I bee thought to confe≈øse them, or to approue them if I refell them not. Thirdly and lastly in regard of others, and among the re≈øt tho≈øe my good friends e≈øpecially who occa≈øioned the preaching of this doctrine, partly to pre≈øerue from recidiuation ≈øuch as by the comfortablene≈øse thereof were recouered out of great di≈øtre≈øse, and partly to preuent others from falling into the like perplexitie. Although therefore I denie not but that good houres be≈øtowed vpon ≈øo bad a ≈øubiect might haue beene more profitably employed, e≈øpecially con≈øidering that by the violent ≈øtruggling thereof again≈øt the rooke of truth, it hath whollie turned it ≈øelfe into froth, and hath not ≈øo much as a drop
of cleere rea≈øon in it: yet notwith≈øtanding for the rea≈øons afore≈øaid, and that it may perfectly appeare how ≈øtedfa≈øt and vnmoued the rocke ≈øtands, and how little the ≈øtormes and tempe≈øts rai≈øed again≈øt it haue preuailed vpon it, I haue thought good to skim away the fome of Sophistrie wrought about it, and to di≈øcouer the very ground whereon it is ≈øetled. Which when I ≈øhall haue done, I doubt not, how≈øoeuer my aduer≈øary with his tong-valiantnes and ≈øwelling words may haue made vnexperienced folke belieue that with the breath of his mouth hee is able to driue whole armies of arguments before him: yet I ≈øhall approue euen to the iudgement of preiudice it ≈øelfe that what≈øoeuer in this windie & wordie Pamphlet he hath vented again≈øt me is vainer then vanitie it ≈øelfe.

And thus, Chri≈øtian Reader, haue I at length fully acquainted thee with the whole ≈øtory both of the originall and progre≈øse of this controuer≈øie. Now it remaineth ere thou pa≈øse thy cen≈øure and ≈øentence thereupon, that thou be plea≈øed to bestow a little paines in peru≈øing our aduer≈øary writings; and what thou findest in them (≈øaid or gain≈øaid) diligently to examine, not by the deceitfull ballance of priuate opinion, but by the publicke beame of the Sanctuarie euen the Scriptures of God. For mans ≈øiluer is mingled with dro≈ø≈øe, E≈øa. 1.22. and his wine is tempered with water, neither hath he receiued ≈øuch a mea≈øure of the Spirit as to know all things, or to be exempted from po≈øsibility of erring: but God is light and in him is no darkne≈ø≈øe, 1 Ioh. 1.5. and truth is vnto him ≈øo nece≈øsary and e≈øsentiall as it is impo≈øsible hee ≈øhould either deceiue or be deceiued, it implying contradiction with his nature. And therefore the priuilege of infallibility belonging vnto him alone, to him alone belongeth al≈øo the prerogatiue of ≈øupreme iudicature: ≈øo that what≈øoeuer
he ≈øaith, is ≈øimply and ab≈øolutely to bee belieued, whereas the ≈øayings of men are by his word to be tried and determined. This I ≈øay not to impeach the credit or e≈øtimation of any, only I would re≈øerue vnto God the Soueraigne authority due vnto him: Which if any pre≈øume to arrogate or claime vnto him≈øelfe (as indeed the Bi≈øhop of Rome doth vnto his chaire, as if it were made of Iri≈øh timber, and might not endure a ≈øpider to hang his web thereon) hee is vndoubtedly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with the Spirit of Antichri≈øtian pride, and like another Lucifer v≈øurpeth vpon the throne of God. But they that are led by the Spirit of Chri≈øt, and haue beene reputed the worthie≈øt in≈øtruments and ornaments in the Church, acknowledging holy Writ to be the Standard of truth, and the only vnmoued Principle into which all Que≈øtions of Faith are finally to bee re≈øolued, boldly exact the writings of other men thereunto, and meekely ≈øubmit their owne to be cen≈øured thereby. Let one S. Augu≈øtin ≈øpeake for all, The di≈øputations of men, ≈øaith he,Epi≈øt. 111. ad Fortunatian. how Catholicke or laudable ≈øoeuer, we ought not to e≈øteeme as Canonicall Scripture, as if it were not lawfull (≈øauing the honor due vnto them) to di≈øallow or reiect any thing in their writings, if happily wee find ought in them ≈øwaruing from truth. Such am I in the writings of other men, and ≈øo would I haue others to vnder≈øtand in mee. Now therefore, to draw to a conclu≈øion, ≈øeeing to thy vpright cen≈øure and arbitrement I referre my ≈øelfe, and the rule by which thou art to proceed if thou wilt pronounce righteou≈øly, is as we haue ≈øhewed, not the opinion of man, but the oracle of God; I must entreate thee that laying a≈øide all re≈øpect of per≈øons thou ≈øuffer not thy ≈øelfe to bee ≈øwayed either with the multitude or greatnes of tho≈øe that are contrary minded, but conferring cau≈øe with cau≈øe, and counterpoi≈øing
rea≈øon against rea≈øon, thou giue thy iudgement of them as the weight of Diuine euidence ≈øhall incline thee. For otherwi≈øe, if like a partiall Fe≈øtus, willing to doe the Iewes a plea≈øure, Act. 25.9. thou demand of me, Whither I will goe vp to Ieru≈øalem and there bee iudged of the≈øe things before thee: I must roundly and peremptorily an≈øwer thee with S. Paul,V. 10.11. I ≈øtand at Cae≈øars barre where I ought to be iudged, to the Iewes I haue done no wrong, neither may any man deliuer me vnto them, I appeale vnto Cae≈øar: But if with the ≈øame Fe≈øtus better adui≈øed by his Coun≈øell,V. 12. thou ≈øay vnto me as hee did vnto Paul, Ha≈øt thou appealed vnto Cae≈øar? Vnto Cae≈øar ≈øhalt thou goe: then looke what definitiue ≈øentence ≈øoeuer thou ≈øhalt giue according to Cae≈øars law, I meane the ≈øacred Scriptures, I ≈øhall as becommeth a ≈øubiect of the Kingdome humbly ≈øubmit my ≈øelfe vnto it, and without further prouocation or appeale quietly and peaceably rest in it. In the meane ≈øea≈øon I conclude with that holy and deuout prayer of Fulgentius, be≈øeeching the God of all truth, De Praede≈øt. to Mon. l. 1. that by his preuenting and pur≈øuing mercy what≈øoeuer truths we know which ≈øauingly are to bee knowne he would teach vs, in tho≈øe which already we know to be true hee would keepe vs, wherein as men we faile and are deceiued he would correct vs, in what truths we doubt of hee would confirme vs, and from fal≈øe and pernicious errors he would deliuer vs: Eph. 4.13. that ≈øo at length wee may all meet, as the Apo≈øtle ≈øpeaketh, in the vnity of Faith and knowledge of the Son of God vnto a perfect man, euen to the mea≈øure of the age of the fulne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt. Amen.

div.head: A TREATISE OF THE TRVE NATVRE AND DEFINITION of ju≈øtifying faith;
div.p:
IF it be true which Tertullian ≈øayth, that euen in the very ≈ømalle≈øt matters regard is to bee had of Truth: ≈øurely in tho≈øe weighty & profound my≈øteries of Religion wherein errour doth ≈øo much hazard ≈øoule and ≈øaluation, nothing ought more carefully to be re≈øpected then the ≈øearch and finding out of Truth. For as the ≈øame Father ≈øayth,Apol. aduer. Gen. c. 46. Although Philo≈øophers Player-like affect the truth as being ambitious of glory, yet Chri≈øtians ≈øtudiou≈øly follow it,
as being carefull of their Saluation. Now among the many excellent and heauenly graces, wherewith the ≈øpirit of God beautifieth and enricheth the hearts of his Elect, there is no one of more either nece≈ø≈øity vnto ≈øaluation, or importance for comfort and con≈øolation, then that of Iu≈øtifying Faith. For as by the fir≈øt Act of this faith, our Iu≈øtification before God, our peace with God, our incorporation into the my≈øticall body of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, our conuer≈øion vnto God are fir≈øt wrought and effected: ≈øo by the con≈øequent continued Acts of the ≈øame Fayth, are wee (being fallen) dayly renewed, and from both totall and finall falling away ≈øafely pre≈øerued and maintained. This (coÃÑ≈øidered me-thinkes) no time can be better employed, nor no paines more profitably taken, then in the que≈øt and enquiry of the true nature and definition of Iu≈øtifying Fayth. And although, I cannot deny but hee may haue fayth who cannot like a Logician define it, and may haue the benefit of Iu≈øtification, by it, who cannot di≈øtinguin≈øh the nature of it: yet this withall I boldly auerre, that the ignorance hereof, or a confu≈øed and indi≈øtinct apprehen≈øion of it, di≈øableth vs both from giuing and taking direct and euident comfort from it, whereas a cleare and di≈øtinct knowledge thereof is able to ≈øatisfie and repleni≈øh with comfort any di≈øtre≈ø≈øed or afflicted con≈øcience. For this cau≈øe haue I vndertaken (≈øo briefly and per≈øpicuou≈øly as I can) to ≈øet downe my opinion of the definition of Fayth, per≈øwading my ≈øelfe I doe not, endeauouring at lea≈øtwi≈øe not to ≈øwarue from the whole≈øome doctrine of Chri≈øt and Gods word. From the writings and doctrine of mo≈øt learned and worthy Diuines peraduenture it doth, and indeed it doth vary: to whom although as farre farre
inferior I owe all re≈øpect & reuerence, yet being Gods freeman I cannot endure to bee mans bond-man and ≈øweare to all they ≈øay. One Paphnutius ≈øometime in the matter of Prie≈øts marriage preuailed again≈øt a whole Coun≈øell of mo≈øt learned and godly Bi≈øhops:Socrat. l. 1. c. 8. and young Elihu may ≈øpeake more oportunely & pertinently then they that are much his Ancients. Therefore as Ni≈øus ≈øayth in Virgill, Ne
que hac no≈øtris ≈øpectentur ab annis, Aeneid. l. 9. looke not how greene or how gray his head be that ≈øpeaketh, but let the touch of truth try all, and what by it ≈øhall appeare to be ba≈øe and counterfait, refu≈øe and reiect; that which ≈øhall be found true and ≈øound, approue and embrace. And that preiudice too ≈øtrongly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe thee not, take my prote≈øtation; that I neuer haue entertained this opinion ra≈øhly and incon≈øiderately, but vpon mature adui≈øe and deliberation: nor broach it vpon a prepo≈øterous humour of nouelty or ambition, to build vp mine owne credit & exi≈øtimation by the ruine and di≈øparagement of ≈øo great Diuines (for this were Subul√¢ leonem excipere, to encounter a Lion with a bodkin, as it is in the Prouerbe) but vpon a ≈øincere affection and de≈øire, to mini≈øter ≈øolid and found con≈øolation to de≈øpayring and perplexed minds, which (as after ≈øhall appeare) vpon this foundation may mo≈øt firmely be rai≈øed. And now tru≈øting what I ≈øay ≈øhall be weighed in the ballance not of preiudice but vpright iudgement, I leaue to preface any farther and come directly to the purpro≈øe.

Becau≈øe I purpo≈øe not to rai≈øe my building very high I meane not to lay my foundation very deepe: & therefore neither will I play the Phylologer in ≈øhewing the diuers v≈øes and acceptations of the word
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ or Fides, id e≈øt Faith, or quote Ciceros Fiat quod dictum e≈øt, or St.
Augu≈øtines Fac quod dicis, Offic. l. 1. to doe as a man ≈øayes, for the notation of Faith: neither will I play the Phylo≈øopher in di≈øcour≈øing of Phy≈øicall or Morall or Ciuill Faith, wherein it were ea≈øie to wa≈øt much oile and paper: nor la≈øtly will I ≈øpeake of that Theologicall Faith called Miraculous either in Agent or Patient, which I take to bee none other then a diuine in≈øtinct for the working of a Miracle. For albeit they who at the la≈øt day ≈øhall ≈øay Lord in thy name haue we not ca≈øt out Diuels may ≈øeeme to haue tru≈øted in Miraculous Faith for Iu≈øtification,Mat. 7.22.23. and acknowledgement of Chri≈øt: yet notwith≈øtanding neuer any controuer≈øie about it hath exerci≈øed the Church of God. To deferre your expectations therefore no farther, three Faiths there ≈øeeme to be, which lay claime and title to the priuiledge of ju≈øtification: giue me leaue to di≈øtingui≈øh and denominate them according to their Obiects, neither be offended if I handle „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , and giue new termes to old matters.

The fir≈øt is Fides Hi≈øtoriae, Hi≈øtoricall Faith, which is an A≈ø≈øent of the mind vnto the truth of Gods word, and ≈øpecially the Go≈øpell. And this Faith whether it be according to the di≈øtinction of the Scoolemen, Acqui≈øite, gotten by much hearing and experience without illumination, or infu≈øed and reuealed by the ≈øpirit of illumination, it hath no intere≈øt in the matter of Iu≈øtification. For be≈øides that it is ab≈øurd that ≈øo generall a Knowledge ≈øhould iu≈øtify. Acqui≈øit Faith the Diuels haue; according to that of St Iames,Iam. 2. 19. The Diuels beleeue & tremble: Infu≈øed faith the Reprobates may haue, as Balaam, Iudas, Magus. Now the Scripture is plaine that ju≈øtifying faith is propper and peculiar vnto the Elect, and therefore Hi≈øtoricall faith cannot ju≈øtifie.

The ≈øecond is Fides Promi≈øsionum, Faith of promi≈øes, which is a Per≈øwa≈øion or A≈øsurance that the promi≈øes of God made in Chri≈øt, to wit Iustification, Remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øinnes, Adoption, Regeneration, and finally Election it ≈øelfe, and eternall Saluation doe particularly pertaine to me, and are mine. Now this although I deny not but in Scripture it is called faith, and that euery Saint of God both may and ought to haue this particular per≈øwa≈øion and A≈ø≈øurance, yet this I confidently deny that this per≈øwa≈øion is that which ju≈øtifies a man before God; and my rea≈øons are the≈øe.

1. If this were ju≈øtifying Faith, then who≈øoeuer liues and dyes without this particular A≈øsurance, he cannot be ≈øaued,Heb. 11.6. Without faith it is impo≈øsible to plea≈øe God. But a man may be ≈øaued without it; I in≈øtance in tho≈øe our Brethren of Germanie, who hold that faith may finally and totally fall away, and con≈øequently that there can be no certainty of Saluation, whom yet the Church of God calleth and counteth brethren, and it were vncharitable to cen≈øure of them otherwi≈øe. Therefore, or at lea≈øtwi≈øe probably Faith is not an A≈ø≈øurance.

2. That which is in time after Iu≈øtifying Faith cannot be that faith. This is vndeniable. But this particular knowledge is in time after faith. This I proue out of 1. Ioh. 5.13. The≈øe things haue I written vnto you that beleeue in the name of the Sonne of God, that ye may know that ye haue eternall life. Behold Beleeuing goes before, and Knowledge comes after: as for that which followeth in the ≈øame ver≈øe, and that yee may beleeue, I interpret it of Per≈øeuerance & growth in Faith. How≈øoeuer, beleeuing & Knowing are di≈øtingui≈øhed,
and therefore are not one.

3. That which in nature comes after Iu≈øtification cannot be Iu≈øtifying faith. This appeares becau≈øe Faith is the Efficient in≈øtrumentall cau≈øe of Iu≈øtification, and euery Efficient by the rule of Logick is in nature before the Effect. But this knowledge or A≈ø≈øurance is in nature after iu≈øtificatioÃÑ. This I proue thus, the truth of a propo≈øition is alwayes in nature before the knowledge of the truth: for Propo≈øitions are not therefore true becau≈øe knowne ≈øo, but they are fir≈øt true and then knowne ≈øo. Therefore this Propo≈øition, I know I am iu≈øtified ≈øpoken by on that is iu≈øtified, mu≈øt needs pre≈øuppo≈øe the partie before to be iu≈øtified. Therefore this knowledge of Iu≈øtification in nature following Iu≈øtification it cannot be Iu≈øtifying faith.

4. In conditionall promi≈øes there can be no A≈ø≈øurance of the thing promi≈øed before the performance of the condition. V. G. This is a conditionall promi≈øe in the couenant of workes, doe this and thou ≈øhalt liue, life is promi≈øed, but on condition of doing: and therefore vntill we haue performed the condition, we cannot, nor may not looke that God ≈øhould be reciprocall and giue vs life: So in the couenant of grace, iu≈øtification is promi≈øed, but vpon condition of faith: ≈øo ≈øayth the Scripture, beleeue, and thy ≈øinnes ≈øhall be forgiuen thee. And therefore the condition of beleeuing mu≈øt fir≈øt be performed before we can a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelues our ≈øins are forgiuen. If ≈øo, then faith going before and A≈ø≈øurance following after, A≈ø≈øurance cannot be ju≈øtifying faith.

5 That from whence followeth a bla≈øphemous ab≈øurdity cannot be a truth: for from truth nought but truth can be concluded. But from this that faith is an A≈ø≈øurance ≈øuch an ab≈øurdity doth follow. What is that? That God commands a man to know an vntruth, & to a≈ø≈øure him≈øelfe of that which neuer ≈øhall be. For God being truth cannot command fal≈øhood to be taken for truth. Nether tell me here, for who art thou that di≈øpute≈øt with God? for this is a ruled ca≈øe in diuinity, God caÃÑnot doe things which imply contradiction, and therefore not make vntruth to be truth, or knowledge error. Now that this ab≈øurdity followes from hence thus I demon≈øtrate it. God commands the Reprobate to beleeue: For,Ioh. 18.8.9. for vnbeleefe the world ≈øhall bee condemned: but no condemnation but for breach of a commandement:1 Ioh.3.4. for „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ Sinne is the transgre≈ø≈øion of the law, and therefore they are commanded to beleeue. I aske you then what it is to beleeue? you will ≈øay, to know, to a≈ø≈øure. Therefore God commands the Reprobates to know and bee a≈ø≈øured. But this is a bla≈øphemous ab≈øurdity: therefore is your opinion ab≈øurd which infers it.

6. That which the wicked may haue cannot be iu≈øtifying faith: for it is Fides Electorum, the faith of the Elect. But the wicked may haue this per≈øwa≈øion, yea and many haue beene mo≈øt confidently per≈øwaded that they are in the fauour of God. You will ≈øay it is no true per≈øwa≈øion: but I ≈øay if forme make truth they are as formally and therefore as truly per≈øwaded of it as the godly. And therefore if the godly are therefore and for this cau≈øe iu≈øtified becau≈øe
cau≈øe they are ≈øtrongly per≈øwaded that they are iu≈øtified: then why ≈øhould not the wicked likewi≈øe be iu≈øtified by his ≈øtrong per≈øwa≈øion? But in truth the≈øe kind of ≈øpeeches are vnrea≈øonable and ≈øen≈øele≈ø≈øe, and ≈øo the opinion cannot be rea≈øonable.

The≈øe ≈øixe rea≈øons ≈øhall ≈øuffice for the pre≈øent, although many more might be added: only from hence I gather this Corollary, that if iu≈øtifying Faith be not a Knowledge or A≈ø≈øurance, much le≈ø≈øe is it a full knowledge or full A≈ø≈øurance. Nay though we ≈øhould graunt it to be a knowledge, yet is it again≈øt Logick to define it by the perfection of knowledg. For as there is a ≈øtrong tree ≈øo there is a bru≈øed reed: as there is a burning lamp, ≈øo there is ≈ømoking flaxe: as there is

And that at length it appeareth, both that the matter is euery way old though the tearme bee new, and that new tearmes may bee giuen to old matters euen of this
kind, ≈øo as they bee proper determined and adequated thereunto. It remaineth onely to ≈øhew that ≈øuch is the tearme which here I v≈øe. For proofe whereof I ≈øay no more but this, that if our be≈øt Diuines haue conueniently di≈øtingui≈øhed other Faiths according to their obiects, calling one Faith of ≈øtory becau≈øe Scripture ≈øtory, another Faith of Promi≈øe becau≈øe the Euangelicall promi≈øe, a third Faith of Miracles becau≈øe miracles are the proper obiect of them: I ≈øee no rea≈øon why I may not as freely and as fitly call that Faith of Per≈øon which hath for its Obiect the Per≈øon of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. Neither can I conceiue if this bee an inkhorne tearme as it plea≈øeth your elegancy to tearme it, why Faith of Story, Faith of Promi≈øe, Faith of Miracles ≈øhould not bee inkhorne-tearmes al≈øo. But you are a very nice and dainty man, you can ta≈øt no wine how old or generous ≈øoeuer, vnle≈ø≈øe the cup out of which you drinke it bee grauen by Myron or Polycletus.

sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p:
But this hath beene the cour≈øe of all fanaticall ≈øpirits in all ages, moued with
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ,Phil: 1.14. ≈øelfe-loue, contention, hypocri≈øie, and couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, De Haere≈øibus ad Quodvult Deum. to condemne all others to ≈øet vp and ≈øtabli≈øh their owne fanta≈øies. Read Augu≈øtine, yea ≈øee the Eccle≈øia≈øticall hi≈øtories, Eu≈øebius, Sozomen, Euagrius, Dorotheus, Vincentius &c. there ≈øhall you ≈øee whereupon the≈øe Schi≈ømes in the Church began. Let mee therefore intreate you if you will needs deale in the≈øe graue cau≈øes
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , yet that you will deale al≈øo
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , well, as becommeth a wi≈øe man. For otherwi≈øe you ≈øhall bewray your mind de≈øirous of nouelties, hazard your
credit, offend the Church, yea as hee ≈øaith take vpon you to glew an egge, Diogenianus. loo≈øing your labour, and making your ≈øelfe ridiculous to the be≈øt.

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p: What hath beene the cour≈øe of fanaticall ≈øpirits in all ages, and whereupon they haue been moued to beginne their Schi≈ømes in the Church; I am not now to learne of you: neither needed you in this point ≈øo to flouri≈øh with your Greeke, or to make ≈øuch a rumble with the names of Eu≈øebius, Sozomen, Euagrius, Dorotheus, Vincentius and the re≈øt. But what my inward motiues haue beene, and with what affection I haue proceeded in this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, God and my owne con≈øcience are a ≈øufficient theater: for your tongue is not the fanne of this floore. And ≈øeeing my earne≈øt prote≈øtation in my preface cannot per≈øwade your vncharitable heart to entertaine a better opinion of my ≈øincere and vpright meaning in this cau≈øe, but that you will notwith≈øtanding reckon me in the number of fanaticall ≈øpirits, po≈ø≈øe≈øsed with ≈øelfe-loue, contention, hypocri≈øie, and couetou≈øne≈ø≈øe, condemning all other to ≈øet vp and ≈øtabli≈øh their owne fanta≈øies; I appeale vnto him who alone knoweth the heart and trieth the raines,Ep. 69. ad Florent. Pupian. and ≈øay vnto you in the words of S. Cyprian, The≈øe things haue I written out of a pure mind and con≈øcience, and with ≈øtedfa≈øt tru≈øt vpon my Lord and God. You haue my letters, I haue yours; in the day of iudgement both ≈øhall bee rehear≈øed before the tribunall of Chri≈øt.

Whereas you intreat mee to deale in this graue cau≈øe well, and as becommeth a wi≈øe man, ≈øurely hitherto I haue indeuoured ≈øo to doe: how well I haue performed
it I leaue vnto the cen≈øure of the Church, and ≈øpecially of tho≈øe vnto whom the Spirits of the Prophets are ≈øubiect. In the meane ≈øea≈øon pardon mee if I feare none of tho≈øe dangers you threaten vnto mee. How your ≈øelfe will auoid them I cannot tell, for neuer was there man wrote with le≈ø≈øe rea≈øon and more follie.

sp.speaker: Treati≈øe.
sp.p: Three Faiths there ≈øeeme to be which lay claime and title to the priuiledge of iu≈øtification; Faith of Hi≈øtory, Faith of promi≈øe, and Faith of Per≈øon. The fir≈øt is an a≈ø≈øent of the mind vnto the truth of Gods Word, and ≈øpecially the Go≈øpell. And this whether it bee Acqui≈øite or Infu≈øed hath no intere≈øt in the matter of iu≈øtification. For be≈øides that is ab≈øurd generall knowledge ≈øhould iu≈øtifie‚Äî

p.hi: That you dare bee ≈øo bold to make ≈øuch a di≈øtribution of Faith I impute it to your de≈øire of nouelties,
as you ≈øay in the words last betweene vs debated. I tell you there is but one Faith, and that a true and liuely working Faith,
p.note: Knowledge the beginning, Application or Apprehen≈øion the Progre≈ø≈øe, Re≈øt the end of Faith.
p.hi: and this onely is iu≈øtifying Faith, and comprehendeth your three nice di≈øtinctions, and is compounded of them all conioyned together, the fir≈øt the beginning, the ≈øecond the progre≈ø≈øe, the third being the end.

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
It is not de≈øire of noueltie in mee, but loue of confu≈øion in you, that dare not haue tho≈øe things di≈øtingui≈øhed
which in their natures are diuided. For di≈øtinction of that which is ambiguous,Top. 1. c. vlt. ≈øaith Ari≈øtotle, is the prime and mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary principle both of defining and di≈øputing well: the neglect whereof in≈øteed of profitable rea≈øoning about matters of ≈øub≈øtance, induceth fruitle≈ø≈øe contention and iangling about words. Now that Faith is equiuocall and needeth di≈øtinction appeares fir≈øt by rea≈øon, for that it comprehendeth vnder it ≈øometime more and ≈øometime fewer things, is both affirmed and denied of the ≈øame per≈øons, is a word of accident attributed to diuers Subiects not contained vnder one next Genus, as to the Elect, to Reprobates, to Diuels. Secondly by authority,Ser. de temp. 181. It is one thing to belieue a God, another to yeeld beliefe vnto God, another to belieue on God, ≈øaith Augu≈øtine. There is a kind of gift equiuocally called Faith, ≈øaith Oecumenius.In 1. Cor. 13. In 1. Cor. 12. Not Faith of doctrines, but Faith of miracles, ≈øaith Theophilact. There is one Faith of Precepts, another of Signes, another of Promi≈øes, ≈øaith Bernard. The ≈øame among the latter writers confe≈ø≈øeth Melancthon, Martyr, Kemnitius, Hiperius, Caluin, Vr≈øin, Foxe, Perkins, and who not? Nay behold Saul him≈øelfe al≈øo among the Prophets: for be≈øides that anon you acknowledge Faith ≈øometime to bee ≈øpoken abu≈øiuely and by an equiuocation, you doe expre≈øly both in your margent and text affirme that there are three kinds of Faith, and approue the ≈øame di≈øtribution which here you condemne in me.

For all this I tell you, ≈øay you, there is but one Faith, and that is iu≈øtifying Faith. Shall I now ≈øay vnto you as el≈øewhere you doe vnto mee, that you ≈øpeake pure Bellarmine? De Iu≈øtif. l. 2. cap. 4. For indeed you v≈øe the very language of that Ie≈øuit. Sectaries (≈øaith hee, vnder≈øtanding Prote≈øtants)
are wont to di≈øtingui≈øh three faiths, of hi≈øtory, of miracles, of promi≈øes: but Catholicks teach that they are one and the ≈øame Faith, and that iu≈øtifying Faith. But doth not the Apo≈øtle (in the place here quoted by you) auouch that there is but one Faith? yes verily: but thereby in the iudgement of the be≈øt Diuines hee meaneth, not that Faith whereby wee doe belieue, but that which we doe belieue: that is not the Habit but the Obiect of Faith, as if hee ≈øhould more plainely ≈øay, there is but one Chri≈øtian Religion. And although in regard of the variety and multitude of materiall obiects, there may ≈øeeme to bee not one but many Faiths: yet becau≈øe the formall rea≈øon wherefore we doe belieue them is but one, namely diuine te≈øtimony, and they are in ≈øuch ≈øort linked and woouen together that one Article cannot bee denied without the di≈ø≈øolution of the whole Creed, all being according to the old rule one copulatiue, it is therefore rightly and iu≈øtly called one Faith.

Finally where you ≈øay Faith comprehendeth my three nice di≈øtinctions, and is compounded of them all, I an≈øwer that ≈øuch compo≈øition is altogether impo≈ø≈øible: for Faith of Story, and Faith of Promi≈øe are in the Vnder≈øtanding, but Faith of Per≈øon is in the Will, and it cannot be that one and the ≈øame Habit ≈øhould bee ≈øubiectiuely in two ≈øeuerall faculties of ≈øo different natures. For the Habit that is for example in Peter is one in number and that which is one in number is indiui≈øible, and that which is indiui≈øible cannot bee at once in two Subiects, becau≈øe as Philo≈øophie teacheth Numeration is from the plurality of Subiects. This M. Perkins ≈øaw,On the Creed. and therefore ≈øaith, Some doe place Faith partly in the Mind, partly in the Will, becau≈øe it hath two parts, Knowledge & Affiance:
but it ≈øeemes not greatly to ≈øtand with rea≈øon that one particular and ≈øingle Grace ≈øhould bee ≈øeated in diuers parts or Faculties of the Soule. And this al≈øo you cannot bee ignorant was an≈øwered in my treati≈øe vnto the ≈øame obiection: which obiection I maruell how you can with mode≈øtie and credit mention, vnle≈ø≈øe withall you were prouided to ≈øatisfie my an≈øwer. But ≈øeeing (as Cicero ≈øaith of Horten≈øius) when you haue ought to ≈øay you haue not the power to hold your peace,Verrin. 3. it is an euident and ≈øtrong pre≈øumption now that you ≈øay nothing, that you haue nothing to ≈øay.

sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p:
Bleare not the eyes of Gods Saints with your niceties and fal≈øities any longer, for thus you rea≈øon. No hi≈øtoricall Faith hath any intere≈øt in the matter of Iu≈øtification: But firmely to belieue the truth of Gods Word, and ≈øpecially the Go≈øpell is hi≈øtoricall Faith, Therefore firmely to belieue the truth of Gods Word and ≈øpecially the Go≈øpell hath no intere≈øt in the matter of Iu≈øtification. Good Sir I deny your Maior, which you thus endeuour to proue ab ab≈øurdo & enumeratione partium, No generall knowledge ≈øhall haue any ≈øtroke in the matter of Iustification, All hi≈øtoricall Faith is a generall knowledge, Therefore no hi≈øtoricall Faith hath any intere≈øt in the matter of iu≈øtification. Proue your Minor, which I denie, telling you moreouer that firmely to con≈øent to the truth of Gods Word in genere, and the Go≈øpell in Specie is not a Generall knowledge, but a Speciall knowledge, and therefore I argue. Such a ≈øpeciall knowledge of the Go≈øpell is the beginning of Faith Iu≈øtifying. Mat. 13.11. Ioh. 17.3. Mat. 16.17. But firmely to con≈øent to the truth of Gods Word and
the Go≈øpell is ≈øuch a ≈øpeciall knowledge: ex confe≈ø≈øo. Therfore firmely to con≈øent to the truth of Gods Word and e≈øpecially the Go≈øpell is the beginning of Iu≈øtifying Faith.

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p: If you were as farre from hood-winking your owne eyes, as I am from blearing the eies of others, you might ea≈øily perceiue that now I deale again≈øt our common aduer≈øaries the Papi≈øts, and ouerthrow the iu≈øtification of their Hi≈øtoricall Faith, by the chiefe≈øt arguments which Prote≈øtants v≈øe. But you after the manner of tho≈øe Gladiators called Andabatae, nor ≈øee nor care whom or what you ≈øtrike: and ≈øo mildly affected are you towards mee that ≈øo you may make ≈øome probable ≈øhew of endammaging or di≈øaduantaging mee, you reck not though through my ≈øides you reach and wound the be≈øt Diuines of our Church, yea and the common truth which wee all maintaine.

Neither doe I v≈øe ≈øuch circumguagues, nor wiredraw my arguments into ≈øuch a length as you beare vs in hand: but hauing nakedly and plainely defined what Hi≈øtoricall Faith is, I proue by two rea≈øons that Faith ≈øo defined doth not iu≈øtifie, the fir≈øt whereof is this, becau≈øe it is ab≈øurd that ≈øo generall a Knowledge ≈øhould iu≈øtifie. So that your Ferio Syllogi≈øme de≈øerues a Ferula, and vtterly to bee ca≈øhed, as being no creature of mine, but an idle figment of your owne: and the next in Celarent (for ≈øo you forme it, although indeed it bee al≈øo in Ferio, the Minor propo≈øition and Conclu≈øion notwith≈øtanding your generall notes being but particular enuntiations) is the onely Syllogi≈øme intended by mee,
and including my fir≈øt argument. The Maior whereof it ≈øeemes you grant ≈øaying nothing vnto it: and the Minor only you deny, which I cannot but wonder at, ≈øeeing both the Minor and Conclu≈øion are vniuer≈øally vouched by all the Diuines of our ≈øide. The Conclu≈øion is that Hi≈øtoricall Faith iu≈øtifies not: So ≈øaith Hyperius,De fide Hom. iu≈øtificandi. There is a certaine Historicall Faith whereby tho≈øe things which are propounded in holy writ are ≈øimply beleeued: but yet is not applyed vnto Christ and the matter of our Saluation. Loco de Fide. The Minor is that Hi≈øtoricall Faith is a generall Knowledge: So ≈øayth Kemnitius, There is a certaine generall Faith which v≈øually is tearmed Hi≈øtoricall: and againe, Hi≈øtoricall Faith is a generall a≈ø≈øent holding in generall that the promi≈øe of the Go≈øpell is true. And M. Perkins,Ser. cau≈ø. c. 36. A generall Faith whereby they giue a≈ø≈øent vnto the Go≈øpell. Neither doe I know any one of our Diuines that either in the Conclu≈øion or the Minor doth gain≈øay them. So that by the iudgement of the≈øe men, both con≈øenting to Gods Word in generall, and to the Go≈øpell in ≈øpeciall, is not a Speciall but Generall Knowledge: and if the Speciality of the Go≈øpell being but a part of the whole Scripture did ≈øpecify Faith, it would follow thereupon that there are as many Speciall Faiths as there are ≈øeuerall Articles of the Creed, which were vnrea≈øonable to imagine. For that Faith which a≈ø≈øenteth vnto the Go≈øpell is no other then that which a≈ø≈øenteth vnto the re≈øt of holy Scripture: and although it may principally re≈øpect that part of diuine truth, yet doth it not only re≈øpect it, nor is limited thereunto as vnto the proper adequate obiect thereof, but vniuer≈øally extendeth it ≈øelfe vnto all ≈øupernaturall reuealed verities what≈øoeuer. As for that Faith which our Diuines call
Speciall, is to be vnder≈øtood of Faith of Promi≈øes wherby the Saints apply and appropriate them vnto them≈øelues, particularly and indiuidually a≈ø≈øuring them≈øelues of their pre≈øent iu≈øtification and future ≈øaluation. And the ignorance hereof as I ween is the cau≈øe why you turne generall into ≈øpeciall and write of this matter ≈øo wildly and confu≈øedly.

This notwith≈øtanding very peremptorily you pronounce that Hi≈øtoriall Faith is a ≈øpeciall Knowledge, and thereupon Syllogi≈øtically inferre that it is the Beginning of Iustifying Faith: to what end I wot not well, vnle≈ø≈øe it bee to proue that it doth iu≈øtify becau≈øe as you conclude it is the beginning of that Faith. But what≈øoeuer your intent bee, your argument I an≈øwer by di≈øtingui≈øhing of the word Beginning. For if you vnder≈øtand thereby a Pre-requi≈øite or Preparatiue vnto iu≈øtifying Faith, you doe but fight with a ≈øhadow, for in that ≈øence I grant the Conclu≈øion, neither doth ≈øuch a beginning of Iu≈øtifying Faith iu≈øtify. If you meane thereby that it is Iu≈øtifying Faith inchoat and in a remi≈ø≈øer degree, then I deny your Maior, and ≈øay that ≈øuch a knowledge (call it as you plea≈øe generall or ≈øpeciall) is not the beginning of iu≈øtifying Faith; If it were, then Diuels and Reprobates hauing it ≈øhould haue iu≈øtifying Faith which Gods Word attributes vnto the Elect onely.Tit. 1.1. And if it bee true that Faith of per≈øon is the con≈øummation of Iu≈øtifying Faith as in the former ≈øection you ≈øay, it cannot bee that ≈øuch a knowledge ≈øhould bee the Beginning thereof: vnle≈ø≈øe you will ≈øay that Accidents may pa≈ø≈øe from one Subiect to another, which is again≈øt all Philo≈øophy. For Hi≈øtoricall Faith is in the Vnder≈øtanding, and Faith of Per≈øon is in the Will: and therefore Faith
of Story beginning in the Mind can haue no ≈øub≈øi≈øtence el≈øewhere, and iu≈øtifying Faith being perfected in the Will cannot bee begunne in any other Subiect. The pa≈ø≈øages quoted in the margent though you ≈øhould rack them till they rent a≈øunder, yet will they not confe≈ø≈øe what you alledge them for. For how I pray you hang the≈øe things together? To you it is giuen to know the my≈øteries of the Kingdome of heauen; This is life euerla≈øting to know thee; Fle≈øh and Bloud hath not reuealed this vnto thee but my Father, Ergo Such a knowledge is iu≈øtifying Faith begun. This is too violent a≈øtraining of Scripture, and as Volu≈øian ≈øpeaketh, is not a ≈øucking of milke, but drawing of bloud from the dugs of the Church. Ep. 1. ad Nic. 1. As for the Minor I haue already ≈øufficiently demon≈øtrated the fal≈øhood thereof: only it ≈øeemeth ≈øtrange why you ≈øhould take it as confe≈ø≈øed. For ≈øure I am in expre≈ø≈øe tearmes I haue affirmed the contrary: neither can I gue≈ø≈øe of what words you gather it, vnle≈ø≈øe perhaps of that I ≈øay and ≈øpecially the Go≈øpell, which were too ridiculous. For that indeed confe≈ø≈øeth the Go≈øpell to bee a ≈øpeciall part of Gods truth, but (not determining Faith onely thereunto) it doth in no ≈øort ≈øpecifie it, as is aboue fully proued.

sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p: Hi≈øtoricall Faith not diuided from the other two kinds, but ioyned with theÃÑ, is cau≈øe of Iu≈øtification. Againe I would pray you to ≈øpeake more learnedly, and argue ≈øoundly: For if you had ≈øaid formerly, No Hi≈øtoricall Faith only iu≈øtifieth &c. We had been agreed. For Hi≈øtorica Fides e≈øt cau≈øa iu≈øtificationis non ≈øolitaria ≈øed ≈øocia; non diui≈øa ≈øed coniuncta. But ≈øpeaking thus ab≈øolutely you ≈øpeake vnlearnedly. Well, thus you proceed leauing your Minor naked and expo≈øed to the mercie of the World.

sp.speaker: I. D
sp.p: Agreed, quoth you? Nay hee can hardly agree with mee that is at warre with him≈øelfe: and had I ≈øpoken neuer ≈øo learnedly, and argued neuer ≈øo ≈øoundly, yet I verily belieue you would haue quarrelled at it, becau≈øe I ≈øee you make contradiction of mee the onely rule of your ≈øpeeches. That there is but one Faith you ≈øay it is nouelty not to grant, and that, Faith only iu≈øtifies I think you dare not deny: how is it then that in the margent forgetting your ≈øelfe you talke of three kinds of Faith, which except my Arithmetike faile mee are more then one? and ioyne fellowes with that in iu≈øtification in the body of your text, which yet you confe≈ø≈øe doth onely iu≈øtify? But what is it that comes not within the ≈øphere of your omnipotent Philo≈øophie? The power of your Logicke hath already contracted Vniuer≈øall into Speciall: and why then may not the ≈øubtlety of your Metaphy≈øicke find a plurality al≈øo in an Vnity?

But to be plaine with you, I ≈øay that Hi≈øtoricall Faith is ≈øo far from being a ioint cau≈øe that at all properly vnder≈øtood of Iu≈øtification, but onely as I haue ≈øaid a Pre-requi≈øite or Preparatiue thereunto. True it is that Faith of Per≈øon is neuer Solitary, but is euer conioyned with ≈øundry other graces, and among the re≈øt with Hi≈øtoricall Faith: yet are not their operations to bee confounded, becau≈øe in the ≈øame per≈øon they are conioyned. Many ≈øeeds lye in my hand together, yet euery one hath his ≈øeuerall and di≈øtinct vertue: Faith of Per≈øon is neuer without Faith of Story, yet it is Faith of Per≈øon which onely iu≈øtifies. And as in the generation of man, the
Sen≈øitiue ≈øoule goes before, and prepares a fit organ for the infu≈øion of the Rea≈øonable, and yet not the Sen≈øitiue but the Rea≈øonable only doth informe: ≈øo in the reparation of man, Faith of Story proceeds, and makes way for the inducement of Faith of Per≈øon, and yet not Faith of Story but Faith of Per≈øon only doth iu≈øtifie.

Now whether in ≈øpeaking thus ab≈øolutely I haue ≈øpoken vnlearnedly as you ≈øay or no, it skilleth not much, ≈øeeing I am ≈øure I haue ≈øpoken truly.1 Cor. 15.9. What euer I am, by the grace of God I am, and de≈øire ≈øo to bee vnto his glory. My want and inability I thanke God I know: yet know I no cau≈øe why in this mediocrity of knowledge and ≈øpeech I ≈øhould in compari≈øon with you any whit di≈øable my ≈øelfe. But ≈øith as the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith, knowledge puffeth vp, 1 Cor. 8.1. God grant vs both the ≈øpirit of humility, that denying our ≈øelues and all our learning, wee may be content to bee wholly captiuated vnto the obedience of the Faith of Chri≈øt.

The Minor which you ≈øay I left naked and expo≈øed to the mercy of the world was this, that Hi≈øtoricall Faith is a generall knowledge, which indeed in my Treati≈øe I did forbeare to confirme, not for want of ≈øufficient proofes, but pre≈øuming that ≈øo euident a truth would neuer haue beene denied. But now I hope it appeares by what I haue aboue ≈øaid to bee ≈øo well guarded with ≈øtrength of rea≈øon and approbation of the learned, that henceforward it need not feare the rigor of your oppo≈øition.

sp.speaker: Treati≈øe.
sp.p:
Acqui≈øite Faith the Diuels haue according to that of Saint Iames, The Diuels belieue and tremble: Infu≈øed
Faith the Reprobates may haue, as Balaam, Iudas, Magus. Now iu≈øtifying Faith is proper to the Elect, and therefore hi≈øtoricall Faith cannot iu≈øtifie.

sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p:
O yee noble Schollers marke this Syllogi≈øme: I haue made your arguments hitherto for you Ma≈øter Downe, and in this creeping and incroching argument tell you that you beg the matter in question. For I deny that your definition of Historicall Faith is a generall knowledge, but ≈øpeciall and peculiar vnto the Elect in the beginning of their iu≈øtifying Faith, conioyned with the Application, and Resting vpon Christ and his merits. And to bee plaine with you I tell you it is ridiculous yea bla≈øphemous to ≈øay that Diuels haue Faith, or that euer Balaam, Iudas, or Magus had Faith. And ≈øo telleth you M. Caluin, In Iac. 2.19. Ridiculum erit ≈øi quis Diabolos habere fidem dicat, it is ridiculous for any man to ≈øay that Diuels haue Faith: For there is but one Faith, Eph. 4. and the other is ≈øpoken

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p: Surely I am very deeply beholding vnto your Ma≈øter≈øhip, hauing ≈øo ≈ømall skill in Logicke, that you will bee plea≈øed to forme my arguments, and to ≈øhape them in ≈øo excellent fa≈øhion for mee. sp.speaker: I. D.

The≈øe things being ≈øo, to what end take you ≈øo much

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p: Iud. 14.18.Seeing here you plow with my heifer (as Sam≈øon ≈øometime ≈øaid vnto the Phili≈øtines) how is it that you read not my riddle al≈øo? I meane hauing borrowed this Obiection from my Treati≈øe, why take you not from thence the an≈øwer al≈øo? Surely that you vrge the one ≈øo eagerly, and ≈øo diligently ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe the other, I know no cau≈øe but this you knew not how to reply vnto it: and therefore I will by your fauor repeate the ≈øame againe, vntil you find out ≈øome forcible rea≈øon to driue me from it. The verbs of vnder ≈øtanding and ≈øence in the Hebrew tongue ≈øignifie not onely the acts of them, but of the will and affections al≈øo. So P≈øal. 1.6. the Lord knoweth the way of the righteous: And, Depart, I know you not: And I will not heare, ≈øee, &c. that is, God will not ≈øo know, heare, ≈øee, as to loue, and approue. And ≈øo may I interpret that of the Prophet, Chri≈øt being ≈øo knowne as to bee embraced and re≈øted on by the will ≈øhall iu≈øtifie many. Adde now, that it is neither nece≈ø≈øary nor likely your Particular knowledge ≈øhould bee here ment: for the Obiect of the Prophets knowledge is no other then Chri≈øt, but the Obiect of your knowledge is your owne ≈øelfe, or, your pre≈øent ≈øtate in grace and future Saluation. And what a ≈øen≈øele≈ø≈øe ≈øpeech doe you put into the mouth of the Prophet? for by your glo≈ø≈øe it is as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay My righteous ≈øeruant by making many to know that they are already iu≈øtified ≈øhall bring many vnto that which already they haue namely iu≈øtification. But E≈øay had in him both the Spirit of Wi≈ødome and the Tongue of Eloquence, and therefore pardon me if I cannot thinke he v≈øed to ≈øpeake non≈øen≈øe like you.

Where you ≈øay my ≈øpeech helpeth Bellarmine who ≈øaith Faith may bee rather in ignoranti√¢ implicit√¢, in an ignorance couched, then in explicit√¢ cognitione, a di≈øcouered knowledge; Fir≈øt, Bellarmine hath no ≈øuch words, neither I thinke did hee euer dreame of an implicit or couched ignorance. Of an implicit Faith we haue often heard, and of a rude and confu≈øed apprehen≈øion the Ie≈øuit in the place by you quoted ≈øpeaketh: but an implicit ignorance was neuer yet heard of, and what meaning it may haue for my part I cannot ≈øee.De iu≈øtif. lib. 1. ca. 7. Bellarmines right words are the≈øe, Faith is better defined by ignorance then knowledge: which ≈øaying of his how my ≈øpeech helpeth I would you had taken a little more paines to make it manife≈øt. For, whence and how you ≈øhould collect it I cannot tell, except perhaps it bee thus, I ≈øay that Faith is not a knowledge; Ergo, I ≈øay al≈øo it is an ignorance. I an≈øwer therefore ≈øecondly, that Bellarmine and I, ≈øpeake not of the ≈øame Faith, for hee ≈øpeaketh of Faith of Story, and I of Faith of Per≈øon: ≈øo that when I ≈øay Faith of Per≈øon is not a knowledge I cannot help him who ≈øaith Faith of Story is not a knowledge. For, as for Faith of Story you cannot bee ignorant that contrary vnto Bellarmine in my Treati≈øe, I haue called it a Generall knowledge, ≈øo farre am I from defining it by ignorance with him. And yet I would haue you to know al≈øo, that when I ≈øay Faith of Story is a knowledge, I meane not thereby Science of Conclu≈øions acquired and gotten by demon≈øtratiue proofe out of ≈øuch principles as are of them≈øelues knowne and euident. For how can a man by the light of naturall rea≈øon a≈øpire to the knowledge of that which is ≈øupernaturall and aboue rea≈øon? But I vnder≈øtand an explicit and di≈øtinct apprehen≈øion
of the nece≈ø≈øary Articles of Faith, oppo≈øite vnto that bruti≈øh ignorance which Papi≈øts call implicite Faith and Blind obedience: which di≈øtinct apprehen≈øion Bellarmine in the place before alledged denieth nece≈ø≈øarily to bee required vnto Faith. Farthermore I would faine know how this followes, Faith is not knowledge, Ergo, it is Ignorance: for by the ≈øame rea≈øon you may conclude, Faith is not Hope, Ergo, it is De≈øpaire; or thus, Earth is not fire, Ergo, it is water, and ≈øo by your creation all things in the world ≈øhall bee one of two, fire or water.Metaph. 12. But you ≈øhould remember that ≈øimple negation is po≈øitiue of nothing, and that Priuations are reduced vnto that ≈øubiect whereunto their Habits doe belong: whence it followeth that denying Faith to be in the Vnder≈øtanding and ≈øo to be knowledge, I deny it al≈øo to bee Ignorance.

sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p:
Againe, what≈øoeuer bringeth life eternall bringeth iu≈øtification and is Faith: But true knowledge of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt bringeth life eternall, Therefore true knowledge of Ie≈øus Christ bringeth iustification and is Faith. The Minor I proue out of the Words of Chri≈øt in S. Iohn,Ioh. 17.3. Mel. & Pez. Arg. Theol. p. 3. notitia Es. 53. ≈øignificat. non ≈øolum agnitionem per≈øonae & beneficiorum Chri≈øti≈øed etiam fiduciam quie≈øcentem in Chri≈øto ≈øicuti & Ioh. 17. This is life eternall to know thee to bee the onely true Lord, and him to bee Ie≈øus Chri≈øt whom thou ha≈øt ≈øent into the world. The Maior is plaine, what≈øoeuer apprehendeth that la≈øt which is life Eternall, apprehendeth the former, as election and iustification &c. But the knowledge of Chri≈øt apprehendeth eternall life, Therefore it apprehendeth iu≈øtification. But hence it followeth, what≈øoeuer apprehendeth iu≈øtification is Faith, True knowledge of Je≈øus Christ apprehendeth iustification, Therefore true knowledge of Chri≈øt
is Faith, and ≈øo con≈øequently and conuer≈øiuely Faith is knowledge, and this knowledge is Faith. Ioh. 19.25. Eph. 3.14.15.16.17.18. 1 Cor. 13. And by this meanes Particular knowledge commeth not in time after faith, but is Faith, and is knowledge in the beginning, & in proceeding is knowledge, and in the end is knowledge.

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
The Maior of your fir≈øt Syllogi≈øme that what≈øoeuer bringeth life eternall bringeth iu≈øtification I deny. You ≈øay it is plaine becau≈øe what≈øoeuer apprehendeth the la≈øt ≈øuch as is eternall life, apprehendeth the former al≈øo which is iu≈øtification. But fir≈øt, what rule of Logicke allowes you thus to ≈øhift tearmes, and to turne bringing of life and iu≈øtification into apprehending life and iu≈øtification? For, how≈øoeuer you ≈øeeme to v≈øe them indifferently, yet are they words of different ≈øignifications: and therefore confounding them thus you make not ≈øo much the truth of the Maior plaine, as ob≈øcure the meaning thereof. Againe, chu≈øe whether of the≈øe tearmes you plea≈øe, yet is it palpably fal≈øe that What≈øoeuer bringeth or apprehendeth the la≈øt, bringeth and apprehendeth al≈øo the former. Rhetoricke brings a man to ≈øpeake eloquently which is the latter: yet it is Grammar not Rhetoricke that brings a man to ≈øpeake congru√® which is the former. Phy≈øicke brings a man to the faculty of curing di≈øea≈øes which is the latter: yet brings not to the knowledge of the nature of things; for that belongs vnto the naturall Philo≈øopher, and according to the old ≈øaying, where the Phy≈øiologer ends, there the Phy≈øician begins. So al≈øo in diuine matters, Hope apprehends eternall life which is the latter, for it is the proper obiect about which it is occupied:
it apprehendeth not iu≈øtification which is the former, for then by your rule it ≈øhould bee Faith it ≈øelfe, that being faith as you ≈øay which apprehends iu≈øtification. As therfore when diuer≈øe needles are by the Load≈øtone trained one after another, the vertue of the ≈øtone moueth the fir≈øt, the fir≈øt the ≈øecond, and ≈øo of the re≈øt, but the third or ≈øecond is no way the cau≈øe of the dependency of the fir≈øt: ≈øo in the concatenation of the cau≈øes of our ≈øaluation reckoned vp by the Apo≈øtle, to wit Election,Rom. 8.30. Vocation, Iu≈øtification, Glorification, the former are mouers as it were vnto the latter, but not the latter vnto the former. The rea≈øon of all in a word is this, becau≈øe as I haue already ≈øhewed, more is required vnto the maine end, then vnto the ≈øubordinate meanes: and therefore ≈øeeing ≈øaluation is the end, Iu≈øtification the meanes, not what≈øoeuer is requi≈øite vnto that is pre≈øently nece≈ø≈øary vnto this.

The Minor that true knowledge of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt bringeth eternall life, I al≈øo deny. For Particular a≈ø≈øurance (which is the knowledge you mu≈øt here vnder≈øtand, or el≈øe you conclude not to the purpo≈øe) bringeth not eternall life, in as much as a man may be ≈øaued without it, as we haue already ≈øufficiently proued. Neither doe the words of Chri≈øt in S. Iohn verify your Minor:Ioh. 17.3. for by knowledge there he meaneth not your particular a≈ø≈øurance and per≈øwa≈øion by which a man knowes he is iu≈øtified & ≈øhall be ≈øaued: but ≈øuch a knowledge of Chri≈øt and his Go≈øpell as is mingled with faith, and worketh our wils to accept of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt for our onely mediator. And this knowledge is ≈øaid to bee eternall life, not becau≈øe euery one that barely and nakedly knowes liues eternally (for as wee haue ≈øhewed Reprobates and Diuels haue Hi≈øtoricall
Faith) but partly, becau≈øe no man can liue without it, partly becau≈øe by it the Spirit of God worketh in the Elect that Faith by which they are iu≈øtified and ≈øo come to eternall life.

But what ≈øay I vnto the Minor deliuered in other tearmes, thus, Knowledge of Chri≈øt apprehendeth eternall life? I ≈øay fir≈øt, it is not the ≈øame Propo≈øition, becau≈øe the tearmes are changed, neither are they equipollent. Secondly, I grant it to bee true, whether you meane by knowledge Dogmaticall Faith or Particular a≈ø≈øurance: for by the one doe we apprehend that there is an eternall life, by the other that wee haue ≈øpeciall intere≈øt in it. Well then, if it apprehendeth eternall life doth it not follow that therefore al≈øo it apprehendeth iu≈øtification? No, by no meanes: for as wee haue aboue demon≈øtrated, it is not nece≈ø≈øary that that which apprehendeth the latter ≈øhould apprehend the former al≈øo. And yet though I di≈øallow the con≈øequence, the con≈øequent I readily yeeld you, that Particular knowledge apprehendeth iu≈øtification: for ≈øo haue wee defined Faith of promi≈øe to be a per≈øwa≈øion or a≈øsurance that the promi≈øe of God made in Chri≈øt, to wit iustification, remi≈øsion of ≈øinnes, adoption, regeneration, finally, election it ≈øelfe and eternall ≈øaluation doe particularly pertaine vnto mee and are mine. What gather you now of this? Ergo, ≈øay you, it is iu≈øtifying Faith. How ≈øo? Becau≈øe what≈øoeuer apprehendeth iu≈øtification is iu≈øtifying Faith. Nay contrarily what≈øoeuer apprehendeth iu≈øtification it not iu≈øtifying Faith: for apprehen≈øion followeth iu≈øtification, no man apprehending him≈øelfe to bee iu≈øtified vntill hee be iu≈øtified, but Iu≈øtifying Faith is in nature before iu≈øtification, that being the cau≈øe and this the effect. And therefore vnle≈ø≈øe
you will ≈øay that that which followeth is that which goeth before, you cannot ≈øay that that which apprehendeth iu≈øtification is that which iu≈øtifieth.

To conclude therefore neither is Faith knowledge nor knowledge Faith, but particular knowledge for ought you haue yet ≈øaid or can ≈øay commeth in time after Faith. But whereas finally you inferre that Faith is knowledge in the beginning, knowledge in proceeding, knowledge in the end, be≈øides that the foundation vpon which it is grounded is vntrue it is cleane contrary al≈øo to that which erewhile you affirmed, that Faith is but one, compounded of my three nice di≈øtinctions, the fir≈øt being the beginning, the ≈øecond the progre≈øse, the third the end. For the third is Faith of Per≈øon, and in the Will, and is by your confe≈ø≈øion there the end of Faith, yet here you ≈øay faith is knowledge in the end: which things how they can ≈øtand together I ≈øee not, vnle≈ø≈øe you will ≈øay that knowledge is in the Will and ≈øo confound the faculties and operations of the ≈øoule.

sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p: In Ioh. 1. Ep. c. 5. to. 13. The place of Saint Iohn by you cited to proue your Minor in your argument maketh nothing for you: becau≈øe the Apostle ≈øpeaketh of their increa≈øe of knowledge, and not of the originall begetting of knowledge, and ≈øo ≈øaith M. Caluin.

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
The text in the cleare≈øt tearmes that may bee di≈øtingui≈øheth betweene Belieuing and knowing, and vnto that giueth the priority before this: but your glo≈ø≈øe confoundeth
their natures, and ≈øaith that the Apo≈øtle here ≈øpeaketh onely of increa≈øe of knowledge. Wo to the glo≈ø≈øe that corrupteth the text: for if this bee S. Iohns meaning, it is as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay, I write vnto you that know that yee are iu≈øtified & haue eternall life, that yee may increa≈øe in knowing that yee haue eternall life, and that yee may know yee are iu≈øtified and haue eternall life, which how vnworthy it is the pen of an Apo≈øtle euery one ea≈øily ≈øeeth. But Caluin you ≈øay interpreteth the place as you doe. Bee it ≈øo: yet is it not the name of Caluin how venerable ≈øoeuer that may ≈øway this matter. For ≈øeeing I profe≈ø≈øe to differ from him in the definition of Iu≈øtifying Faith, hee defining it by knowledge, I by Affiance: you may not thinke it vnrea≈øonable, if in this point, and the explication of ≈øuch ≈øcriptures as may ≈øeeme to concerne it, I de≈øire rather to bee pre≈ø≈øed with his rea≈øons, then borne downe with his authority. But what ≈øaith Caluin? Becau≈øe there ought to bee dayly proceedings in Faith, therefore he writes to them that belieue already, that they may more firmely, and certainly belieue. Whereunto I willingly a≈ø≈øent, if you apply it as Beza in his annotations doth vnto the la≈øt clau≈øe of the ver≈øe, and that yee may belieue: for then the meaning without forcing or con≈øtraining the words will bee as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay, I write vnto you that belieue that belieuing yee may know yee haue eternall life, & knowing the ≈øame may con≈øtantly per≈øeuere and proceed on in Belieuing. For as the clouds poure downe raine to moi≈øten the earth, and the earth moi≈øtned ≈øendeth vp vapours againe to make clouds: ≈øo likewi≈øe Faith begets A≈ø≈øurance, and A≈ø≈øurance being gotten doth againe confirme and ≈øtrengthen faith. And thus doe the Century-writers expound this place,Cent. 1. l. 2. c. 4. p. 276. gathering
from it that Cetainty of Saluation is an Effect of Faith and ≈øo euidently di≈øtingui≈øhing knowledge from Faith.

sp.speaker: Treati≈øe.
sp.p: 3. Arg. That which in nature comes after iu≈øtification cannot bee iu≈øtifying Faith. This appeares becau≈øe Faith is the Efficient In≈øtrumentall cau≈øe of Iu≈øtification: and euery Efficient by the rule of Logicke is in nature before the Effect. But this knowledge or a≈ø≈øurance is in nature after Iu≈øtification, Ergo, it is not Faith.

sp.speaker: N. B.

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
The Maior of my Syllogi≈øme is vndeniable, becau≈øe as I haue ≈øaid Faith is the cau≈øe of iu≈øtification. For as D. Fulke ≈øaith vnto Bri≈øtow excluding it from Efficient cau≈øes,Reioinder to Bri≈øtow. p. 172. Seeing Scripture often affirmeth that God worketh in vs by Faith, faith mu≈øt needs be an in≈øtrumentall efficient when you haue ≈øaid all that you can, except you will
teach vs new Grammar and Logicke. The Minor therefore you ≈øay is very fal≈øe, and ≈øo proued by your former arguments. But tho≈øe arguments are already an≈øwered, and thus I proue the Minor. For as for the re≈øt of your idle and wilde talke touching the infu≈øion, begetting, degrees, habit, act of Faith, I willingly pa≈ø≈øe ouer, le≈øt pur≈øuing you in this cour≈øe I ≈øeeme to run riot and play the wanton with you.

What mum Master Baxtar? Hath Sigalion now in≈øtantly ≈øealed vp your lips that you cannot, or are you ≈øuddenly become a profe≈ø≈øed Pythagorean that you may not ≈øpeake?
