Which cour≈øe if you had al≈øo v≈øed in the re≈øt of this di≈øputation, you ≈øhould haue ≈øaued this ≈øcribling labor, and I had receiued virgin paper from you. And ≈øo, as Galba in the iudgement of all might haue beene thought worthy of the empire if hee had not beene Emperor:Tacit. 1. Hi≈øt. you al≈øo in the opinion of ≈øome might haue beene counted able to write if you had not written. sp.speaker: Treati≈øe.
sp.p:
4. Arg. In conditionall Promi≈øes there can bee no A≈ø≈øurance of the thing promi≈øed before the performance of the condition. v. g. This is a conditionall Promi≈øe in the couenant of works, Doe this and thou ≈øhalt liue, Life is promi≈øed but on condition of Doing: and therefore vntill wee haue performed the condition, wee may not looke that God ≈øhould bee reciprocall and giue vs Life. Now in the Couenant of Grace, Iu≈øtification is promi≈øed, but vpon condition of Faith: ≈øo ≈øaith the Scripture, Belieue and thy ≈øins ≈øhall be forgiuen thee. Therefore the condition of Belieuing mu≈øt fir≈øt bee performed before wee can a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelues our ≈øins are forgiuen. If ≈øo, then Faith going before, and A≈ø≈øurance

I deny your Minor and ≈øay, there may bee an A≈øsurance of Saluation in ≈øome mea≈øure, before there can bee the performance of Faith actuall in the highe≈øt mea≈øure: Therefore your Minor is vtterly fal≈øe. sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
To make all plaine, my argument reduced into the right forme ≈øtandeth thus, That which goeth before iu≈øtification is not that which followes after iu≈øtification: But Faith goeth before iu≈øtification and A≈øsurance followes after, Ergo, Faith is not A≈ø≈øurance. The Minor of this Syllogi≈øme is that which you deny affirming it to be vtterly fal≈øe, and you confirme it to bee ≈øo by this rea≈øon, There may bee A≈ø≈øurance of Saluation in ≈øome mea≈øure before there can be Performance of Faith Actuall in the highe≈øt mea≈øure, Ergo, Faith goeth not before A≈ø≈øurance, nor doth A≈øsurance follow after Faith. The Antecedent of
which Enthymeme I grant, for as much as there may bee A≈ø≈øurance in this life, but not the performance of Faith actuall in the highe≈øt mea≈øure, wee here Belieuing only in part, as the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith. But if hereupon it follow, Therefore Faith goeth not before A≈øsurance, it will al≈øo follow, Faith goeth not before Charity or good works, becau≈øe Charity and good works may be in ≈øome mea≈øure, before Faith actuall bee in the highe≈øt mea≈øure: or thus, The elder Sonne is not borne before the yonger, becau≈øe the yonger may waxe as tall as a Pygmee before the elder bee growne to the ≈øtature of a Giant. Which Con≈øequences if they be ab≈øurd and ridiculous, as ab≈øurd and ridiculous is it to inferre that Faith cannot bee before A≈ø≈øurance, becau≈øe A≈ø≈øurance may bee in ≈øome mea≈øure before Faith bee in the highe≈øt mea≈øure. Nay farre better doth it follow from hence again≈øt your ≈øelfe that Faith is not A≈ø≈øurance, nor A≈ø≈øurance Faith. For if as you expre≈øly ≈øay A≈ø≈øurance may bee in a lower mea≈øure when Faith is in a higher, how can they po≈ø≈øibly differing ≈øo in degrees but bee differing things? For although it be true that more and le≈ø≈øe doe not diuer≈øify the kind, yet is it as true that the ≈øame indiuiduall quality cannot at the ≈øame time bee both intended and remitted, no more then the ≈øame ≈øtring in a Lute can at once bee ≈øtrained vp, and let downe, and yeeld at the ≈øame time both a ba≈øe and treble ≈øound.

You ≈øhould therefore
euidently demon≈øtrate out of the Scriptures that God commands a Reprobate ≈øo to bee a≈ø≈øured and per≈øwaded: and then if I re≈øted not ≈øatisfied with Gods reuealed will, you might iu≈øtly bid mee goe and di≈øpute with Christ, and forbid to ≈øearch into the coun≈øels of God le≈øt I be ouerwhelmed with his Maiesty. sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p: Againe it is an vntruth that God commandeth, when he biddeth a Reprobate to belieue and hee ≈øhall bee ≈øaued. For, if hee could belieue, he ≈øhould then be ≈øaued without doubt, Ioh. 11. That hee cannot belieue, the rea≈øon is, Chri≈øt hath not wa≈øhed him Io. 13.8. neither hath opened his heart to belieue. So that if hee could haue belieued, hee ≈øhould haue this doctrine effectuall vnto him to ≈øaluation. That he therefore could not belieue is not to bee imputed to the fal≈øity of the doctrine, but to the hardne≈ø≈øe of his owne heart.

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
The commandement of God is ab≈øolute, Belieue: the promi≈øe of Saluation is conditionall, if we Belieue, That the Promi≈øe is conditionall you denyed in your an≈øwer to the former argument: now al≈øo you deny that Belieuing is commanded. Whereby you bewray, how inexpert you are in the Word of righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, as the Apo≈øtle ≈øpeaketh: and that whereas by office you are,Heb. 5.12 13. and
concerning the time ought to be a teacher, yet haue you need your ≈øelfe to be taught the very elements of the Chri≈øtian Religion. That therefore the Promi≈øe is conditionall I haue in the due place demon≈øtrated: now that Belieuing is commanded remaineth to bee poued, or rather it is already proued, thus, No condemnation but for breach of a Commandement, Condemnation for vnbeliefe: for, for vnbeliefe the world ≈øhall bee condemned, Ergo, Beliefe commanded. But this rea≈øon according to your wont you cunningly ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe, and hauing found out a new Art of di≈øputation, thinke it enough to ≈øcorne the premi≈ø≈øes, and with a bold face to deny the Conclu≈øion. Yet for your further confu≈øion vnto nece≈ø≈øary con≈øequence, I adde the expre≈ø≈øe words of Scripture, This, ≈øaith Iohn, is his commandement that wee belieue in the Name of his Sonne Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. 1 Ioh. 3.23. And vnto diuine authority I adde the humble con≈øent of holy men of God. Beza expoundeth that place of Saint Iohns Go≈øpell,Ioh. 6.29. This is the worke of God that yee belieue in me, De gra. vniuer. De Praede≈øt. & gratia. on this wi≈øe, This is that which God requireth of you that yee belieue in me. The Lord commandeth, ≈øaith Hemingius, that we belieue. Together with the Promi≈øe, ≈øaith Ma≈øter Perkins, is conioined the Exhortation or Commandement to Belieue, which is more generall then the Promi≈øe, becau≈øe the promi≈øe belongs only to Belieuers, but the CoÃÑmandement both to Belieuers & vnbelieuers. Harm. Conf. Sax. of remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øins & iu≈øtif. Finally, the whole Church of Saxony thus confe≈ø≈øeth, It is the eternall & immutable commandment of God, that we ≈øhould belieue in the Son of God, according to this ≈øaying (which is my very ground) the Spirit ≈øhall conuince the world of ≈øinne, becau≈øe they Belieue not in mee. Nay, ≈øee the lucke of it, that which here you affirme to be an vntruth, not many lines before you haue
auowed to bee a truth ≈øaying, God commandeth all to Belieue, and therefore the Reprobates. Yea doe you not in this place vn≈øay that which you ≈øay, ≈øaying, it is vntrue that God commandeth when hee biddeth a Reprobate to Belieue? For hee that Biddeth in my vnder≈øtanding commandeth: vnle≈ø≈øe you that complaine of nice and ≈øubtle Di≈øtinctions in others, haue learned of late by ≈øome new-found nicetie to di≈øtingui≈øh there where the letters and ≈øyllables onely differing, there is otherwi≈øe an identie of nature and definition. A man would wonder how you could ≈øo ≈øoone forget your ≈øelfe, but that it is commonly ≈øeene a liar hath ≈øeldome or neuer a good memory.

But to proue that God commands not a Reprobate to belieue you come vpon mee with a mo≈øt mighty and in≈øoluble Enthymem. What is that I be≈øeech you? Marie this. A Reprobate if he could belieue, he ≈øhould then without doubt bee ≈øaued: Ergo, God doth not command him to Belieue. A de≈øperate Demon≈øtration I promi≈øe you: for by the ≈øame rea≈øon you may conclude, that God commands him not to obey the Precepts of the Morall law neither, Becau≈øe if hee could keepe them he ≈øhould bee ≈øaued. What you conceiue may bee the knot and ≈øowlder as it were of this Con≈øequence I cannot well imagine, vnle≈ø≈øe it be one of two, either this, God promi≈øeth the Reprobate hee ≈øhall bee ≈øaued if hee Belieue, Ergo, hee commandeth him not to Belieue: or this, The Reprobate cannot belieue, Ergo, God commandeth him not to Belieue, for your words ≈øeeme to bee indifferent either way. If you intend the former, fir≈øt, you contradict your owne ≈øelfe, for in your an≈øwer to the former argument you deny Iu≈øtification and Saluation
to bee promi≈øed vpon condition of Faith. Secondly, euery Catechumenus and Nouice in Diuinity knowes that God vnto Commandement v≈øually annexeth Promi≈øe to draw on Obedience: as in the Couenant of works, fir≈øt hee Commandeth, Doe this and then Promi≈øeth, if thou doe it thou ≈øhalt liue; and in the Couenant of Grace al≈øo, fir≈øt hee Commandeth, Belieue, and then addeth the Promi≈øe, if thou belieue thou ≈øhalt bee ≈øaued. So that Promi≈øe and Commandement exclude not one the other, neither doth it follow, Faith is the condition of a Promi≈øe, Ergo, it is not commanded. If you vnder≈øtand the latter, then know that as Augu≈øtin, and Barnard, and all Diuines not infected with Pelagiani≈øme ≈øay, God commandeth ≈øome things which man cannot doe, to the end that knowing his owne in≈øufficiency, hee may craue of him the helpe of grace that hee may doe them. And if God doe command any ≈øupernaturall action vnto the Reprobate as without doubt hee doth, then doth hee al≈øo command ≈øome thing aboue his power: for being meerely naturall he cannot produce any ≈øupernaturall operation. Whereupon it followeth euidently that although a Reprobate cannot belieue, yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe hee may bee commanded to Belieue.

Well, yet you will proue that a Reprobate cannot Belieue. To what end? for it is not denied, and you ≈øhould rather ≈øtrengthen your Con≈øequence, and proue that therefore Faith is not commanded. Notwith≈øtanding let vs heare your rea≈øon, for it ≈øeemeth to bee very remarkable. That hee cannot Belieue, ≈øay you, the rea≈øon is, Chri≈øt hath not wa≈øhed him. If you had ≈øaid as followeth, Chri≈øt hath not opened his heart to Belieue, or, it is to
bee imputed to the hardnes of his owne heart, and had ≈øtopt there, I ≈øhould ea≈øily haue yeelded vnto you: but now that you ≈øay the rea≈øon is becau≈øe Chri≈øt hath not wa≈øhed him, I mu≈øt needs tell you it is vnrea≈øonable rea≈øon, for it implies that wee are fir≈øt wa≈øhed and then Belieue, whereas both Scripture and the analogie of Faith teach vs that we fir≈øt belieue and then afterward are wa≈øhed. Search the booke of God,Rom. 3.28. Act. 15.9. Rom. 3.25. and there ≈øhall you read, that wee are iu≈øtified by Faith, that the heart is purified by Faith, that God hath ≈øet forth Ie≈øus Chri≈øt to bee a reconciliation through Faith in his Blood. Which Blood although it haue in it ≈øufficient vertue and force to clean≈øe vs from the lepro≈øie of all our ≈øinnes, yet doth it not actually wa≈øh or purge any vnle≈ø≈øe it bee particularly applied and accepted by Faith. Otherwi≈øe, as Ambro≈øe excellently ≈øpeaketh, if thou belieue not, Chri≈øt de≈øcended not for thee, Chri≈øt ≈øuffered not for thee. De fide ad Gratian. Wherby it manife≈øtly appeareth that Remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øinnes is an effect or con≈øequence of Faith, and that therefore the rea≈øon of the Reprobates vnbeliefe, is not becau≈øe Chri≈øt hath not wa≈øht him, but rather the rea≈øon why Chri≈øt hath not wa≈øhed him is, becau≈øe hee doth not belieue, nor hath by Faith applyed the blood of Chri≈øt to him≈øelfe for the remi≈ø≈øion of his ≈øinnes. Where you adde negatiuely, that the Reprobates vnbeliefe, is not to bee imputed to the fal≈øity of the Doctrine, whether you meane thereby either this Doctrine that God commands him to belieue, or this that it is ab≈øurd hee ≈øhould command him to bee a≈øsured, I confe≈ø≈øe indeed, that neither is the cau≈øe why the Reprobate cannot belieue: but that either of them is fal≈øe, you ≈øhall neuer bee able to ≈øhew, and I haue ≈øufficiently proued the contrary.

sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p: Ex. 14.4. Rom. 9. If you aske, who hath hardned him? sp.p:
This is right that Sophy≈øticall place which Ari≈øtotle in his Topicks calleth Apagogen, Lib. 2. c. 5. See Muret. var. lect, l. 7. c. 10. that is Abduction. For whereas I goe about to proue, that God commandeth not a Reprobate to bee a≈ø≈øured, becau≈øe ≈øo doing hee ≈øhould command him to belieue a manife≈øt fal≈øhood, which implieth contradiction, and affirmeth errour to bee truth: you not knowing what an≈øwer to make vnto

Why di≈øpute you ≈øo earne≈øtly of the „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ why it is, when I flatly deny the
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ that it is? And why doe you thus alwayes grate vpon the Conclu≈øions, and make ≈øo little reckoning to an≈øwer the proofes I bring for it?

Well, not to wre≈øtle with words any longer, nor ≈øo fruitle≈øly to beate the aire, becau≈øe you thinke like the Cuttle-Fi≈øh to e≈øcape the net, by ca≈øting about you a filthy inke of foule ≈øpeeches, telling me I ≈øpeak impurely &
impiou≈øly, and charging me with Pre≈øumption and Curio≈øity, for inquiring into the Coun≈øels of God: giue mee leaue by di≈øtingui≈øhing matters to cleare the water which you wittingly and purpo≈øely haue pudled, and withall to let the Reader ≈øee how ba≈øely and cowardly you ≈øeeke out ≈øtarting holes to ≈øhift your ≈øelfe a≈øide from my arguments, rather then Schollerly to an≈øwer them by ≈øome conuenient ≈øolutions. Con≈øider therefore I pray you the≈øe few Po≈øitions.

1. The ≈øecret Coun≈øels of God are tho≈øe matters which hee hath trea≈øured vp in the clo≈øet of his owne knowledge, and doth not di≈øclo≈øe vnto mankind: but what truth ≈øoeuer it hath plea≈øed him in wi≈ødome to reueale vnto vs, and hath regi≈øtred in his Word, is not to bee e≈øteemed nor taken for a ≈øecret.

So di≈øtingui≈øheth Saint Augu≈øtin, Although both, De v ‚Ä¢ il. credendi ca. 9. ≈øaith hee, bee carried with a great de≈øire of knowing, yet the curious man inquireth tho≈øe things which nothing concerne him, and the Studious man contrarily

4. This is a reuealed truth that, There is no contradiction in God, and that Hee cannot doe tho≈øe things which imply contradiction,2 Cor. 1.17.18.19.20. Heb. 6.18. or are repugnant vnto the nature and definition of a thing. For in God, as ≈øaith S. Paul, there is not yea and nay, but yea and Amen; neither is it po≈ø≈øible that hee ≈øhould lie, or deny him≈øelfe, and it is rather impotency then Power ≈øo to bee able to doe, whereas contrarily,De Trin. l. 15. c. 14. as elegantly Saint Augu≈øtin ≈øaith Powerfully hath hee not power to doe this, neither is it infirmity but firmity, becau≈øe that truth cannot bee fal≈øe.

5. The≈øe two Propo≈øitions are contradictory, The Reprobate is iu≈øtified, The Reprobate is not iu≈øtified: and, The Reprobate ≈øhall bee ≈øaued, The Reprobate ≈øhall not bee ≈øaued. The Reprobate ≈øhall bee ≈øaued: for they onely who are Prede≈øtinated vnto life, are as Saint Paul ≈øaith, effectually called, and they onely who are effectually called are iu≈øtified and ≈øhall bee glorified. Impious rather and bla≈øphemous is it to ≈øay the contrary: for it imputes impotency and weaknes vnto God, making him to ≈øay, Yea and Nay, and to auouch that for truth which is euidently fal≈øe.

9. But this opinion, that Faith is an A≈ø≈øurance, infers this bla≈øphemous ab≈øurdity. Finally, wee accept him to bee our King, when wee put our ≈øelues wholly and onely vnder his gouernment, and ≈øubiect our wils vnto his will, de≈øiring that in all things it alone may bee done by vs. And this accepting of Chri≈øt by the Will, is that very Receiuing of him which Saint Iohn here meaneth.Ioh. 1.12. For fir≈øt, who≈øoeuer thus accepteth of him hath without que≈øtion withall be≈øtowed on him the ≈øame power and prerogatiue, which hee affirmeth to bee giuen to as many as receiue him, namely to bee made the Sonnes of God. To grow therefore at length vnto an i≈ø≈øue, you ≈øee that according to promi≈øe I haue demon≈øtrated vnto you, fir≈øt, that tho≈øe tearmes both of the old and new Te≈øtament mentioned in my Treati≈øe import that Act of Faith whereby wee ≈øtand iu≈øtified before God: ≈øecondly, what is the true, proper, and naturall meaning and ≈øignification of the≈øe tearmes: and that therefore thirdly by the word Re≈øt, in my Definition I vnder≈øtand no other thing then that which the≈øe words import and ≈øignify. p.hi: I an≈øwer, a man may rest his will vpon Christ and his merits, and yet bee damned for want of Sanctification, and ≈øo con≈øequently may bee damned hauing Iu≈øtifying Faith, which is ab≈øurd, therefore is your Definition ab≈øurd.

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
Here, Master Baxter, and in the re≈øt of your an≈øwers
in≈øuing, you waue & flote vp and downe like a boat in a ≈øtorme without a Pilote, an≈øwering tumultuarily what euer comes next to head, and ≈øcorning like another Ca≈ø≈øius Seuerus to keep either in method your matter,Tacit. vel poti√πs Quintil. de cau≈ø≈ø. corrupt. eloq. or mode≈øtie in your words. But as you lead the dance, ≈øo mu≈øt I needs follow. Thus therefore you argue. No man can be damned hauing iu≈øtifying Faith, A man may be damned re≈øting his will vpon Chri≈øt & his merits, Ergo, Re≈øting of the will vpon Chri≈øt and his merits is not iu≈øtifying Faith: The Maior I grant, the Minor thus you confirme, Hee that wanteth ≈øanctification may bee damned, A man re≈øting his will vpon Chri≈øt and his merits may want ≈øanctification, Ergo, a man re≈øting his will vpon Chri≈øt and his merits may be damned. The Maior againe I grant, if you vnder≈øtand it either thus, Hee that finally wanteth ≈øanctification ≈øhall bee damned, or thus, Hee that wanteth pre≈øent ≈øanctification is for the pre≈øent in the ≈øtate of damnation: for otherwi≈øe the Elect vntill their effectuall vocation want ≈øanctification, and yet ≈øhall neuer actually be damned. The Minor you barely affirme but confirme not: thinking it as it ≈øeemes proofe inough if you ≈øay it and ≈øub≈øcribe thereunto Witne≈ø≈øe our ≈øelfe: vnto this argument therefore I an≈øwer two things.

Fir≈øt, that you are a very vnkind and vngratefull man that hauing now the third or fourth time borowed arguments of me to ≈øerue your need, haue not the good manners to ≈øay mee God a mercy for it, or to acknowledge to whom you haue beene beholding. For in my Treati≈øe thus I obiected again≈øt my ≈øelfe, If Faith be Affiance then the wicked may haue it: for Balaam de≈øired to die the death of the Righteous, and ≈øome receiue the Word with ioy belieuing for a time. Treati≈øe I gaue a ≈øufficient and full ≈øolution, di≈øtingui≈øhing betweene that Affiance which is ≈øleight and ≈øuperficiall, and that which is ≈øetled and grounded, as there you may read more at large, for thither I referre you. But becau≈øe,Hecub. act. 2. as Euripides ≈øaith, the ≈øame ≈øpeech ≈øpoken by diuer≈øe per≈øons is not alike entertained: peraduenture this an≈øwer would be better accepted if you might haue it from the mouth of greater authority. Perkins expo≈øition of the Creed, whereupon the fir≈øt word I Belieue hee intreats of the nature of Faith, and you ≈øhall find in effect the ≈øame obiection in like manner an≈øwered, and di≈øtinction made betweene the fleeting motions & de≈øires of them who liue ≈øtill in their ≈øins & after the cour≈øe of the world & the De≈øire of reconciliation that comes from a bruzed heart, & brings with it alwayes reformation & amendment of life. Secondly, I an≈øwer vnto your Minor negatiuely, denying that ≈øuch Re≈øting of the will vpon Chri≈øt and his merits, as wee haue de≈øcribed, and in the definition vnder≈øtand, can at any time bee ≈øeparated from Sanctification. For be≈øides that it is contrary vnto your owne Po≈øitions, as anon in the due place ≈øhall bee ob≈øerued: it is al≈øo flatly repugnant vnto the rules of holy Scripture. For doth not the Scripture pronounce them all, Ble≈ø≈øed, that retire them≈øelues vnto the Lord? P≈øal. 2.12. P≈øal. 25.2. like vnto mount Sion which can neuer bee remoued, but ≈øtandeth fast for euermore? 2 Chron. 16‚ñ™ 8.9. that to re≈øt vpon the Lord is to bee of a perfect heart? Finally, doth it not affirme that who≈øoeuer receiueth Chri≈øt and belieueth in him, Ioh. 1.12. Rom. 4.5. Ioh. 3.36. 1 Ioh. 5.1. Rom. 8.1.14. is the Son of God, is iu≈øtified before God, hath euerla≈øting life, is borne of God, is led by the Spirit of God, and walketh not after the fle≈øh, but after the Spirit? vnle≈ø≈øe therefore vtterly ≈øtripping your ≈øelfe of all mode≈øty you will put on the forehead of an harlot, and ≈øay that all the≈øe things may bee affirmed of the Vn≈øanctified man: how can you po≈ø≈øibly auouch that a man resting his will vpon Christ, retiring vnto him, tru≈øting on him, belieuing in him, and accepting of him to bee his Mediator, can be without ≈øanctification, and for want thereof bee damned eternally? Nay, who≈øoeuer accepteth Ie≈øus Chri≈øt for his Mediator, ≈øubmitteth him≈øelfe as wee haue ≈øhewed not onely vnto his Prophecy and Prie≈øthood, but al≈øo vnto his Kingdome: and if hee ≈øubmit him≈øelfe vnto his Kingdome, that is vnto his rule and gouernment, how can hee bee Vn≈øanctified? for the Vn≈øanctified man ≈øubiecteth him≈øelfe vnto the Fle≈øh, and not vnto the Spirit of Chri≈øt:Act. 15.9. where by the way you may ob≈øerue, defining Faith in this ≈øort, how and after what manner it purifieth the heart, and begetteth in vs ≈øanctity and newne≈ø≈øe of life: whereas defining it by A≈ø≈øurance as you doe, it doth not readily appeare how ≈øuch A≈ø≈øurance can bee the principle and rea≈øon of our Sanctification. And although in ≈øundry copies and tran≈ølations By good works is omitted: yet the addition thereof mi≈øliketh not Beza, In loc. praed. On the other ≈øide if you define Faith with mee to bee that Act whereby wee accept and make choice of Chri≈øt to bee our Mediator, that is to ≈øay, our Prophet, Prie≈øt, and King: who ≈øeeth not that this Faith working in vs a free and voluntary ≈øubiection vnto the Kingdom of Chri≈øt, is the very purifier of our hearts, and the cau≈øe of all our holy ≈øtudies and indeuours? whence al≈øo it appeareth what the rea≈øon is why our Sauiour vnto belieuing in the Sonne oppo≈øeth Di≈øobedience vnto him when hee ≈øaith,Ioh. 3.36. p.hi: Your Genus is, that Faith iu≈øtifying is a Re≈øt, which is fal≈øe; when you ≈øpeake more learnedly I will deigne you farther an≈øwer.

Yet ≈øeeing the Sunne ≈øo ≈øurpa≈ø≈øing in glory is no way enuious of his light, but imparteth bountifully of his beames to the enlightning of the re≈øt of the ≈øtarres: it may plea≈øe you al≈øo (with whom wi≈ødome mu≈øt liue and dye)Ioh. 12.2. out of your benignity to ≈øend forth ≈øome influence of your learning

sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p: Shew mee for your warrant one place of Scripture that ≈øo tearmeth it, any one Father of the Church, old or new, for the≈øe 1600. yeeres, Greeks or Latins, that will auouch it, and I will yeeld to your Genus. The Hebrew word for Faith, and the Greek word (whereof you haue heard before) doe vtterly condemne you, they both ≈øignifying a per≈øwa≈øion and an A≈øsurance, and neuer a Re≈øt. sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
If by denying vnto mee the warrant of Scriptures, of Fathers old and new, Greeke and Latin, for 1600. yeeres and of the Greeke and Hebrew words for Faith, you intend to proue that Affiance or Re≈øt is not the Genus of Faith, it ≈øhall without more a-doo bee yeelded vnto you: for as appeares in the former ≈øection I make it to bee not the Genus but the Act or Forme thereof. But if you would thereby per≈øwade that Re≈øt or Affiance is not the Act of Faith, I mu≈øt tell you that the≈øe rea≈øons are cleane out of date, and that you doe too much abu≈øe your Readers patience ≈øetting againe before him the≈øe Coleworts now more then twice ≈øodden. For both in the beginning of this di≈øputation, and in the la≈øt ≈øection ≈øaue two before this I haue throughly ≈øcanned & cleered
this bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; ≈øhewing that I am ≈øo farre from teaching the Holy Gho≈øt to ≈øpeake, and the Church to vnder≈øtand what Faith is, as you vnchri≈øtianly lay vnto my charge, that I v≈øe no other tearme, but that which the Spirit of God hath in Scripture ≈øanctified to this purpo≈øe, and the Holy Church hath euer ≈øpoken and v≈øed. But becau≈øe I am loth to pe≈øter my paper with ≈øo many Tautologies and needles repetitions as you v≈øe to doe, thither mu≈øt I entreate the courteous Reader to repaire for ≈øatisfaction.

In the meane ≈øea≈øon, ≈øeeing both by expre≈ø≈øe te≈øtimony of Scripture, and cleere euidence of rea≈øon I haue warranted euery part of my definition, and yet you without di≈øprouing the weake≈øt of my proofes tauntingly call it a woodden Definition: you mu≈øt pardon mee if I tell you plainely that this wood-kinde of an≈øwering de≈øerues to bee reformed with a little woodden correction. But where you ≈øay my Definition may rather moue to choler then con≈øent, a man would thinke reading this your an≈øwer, that either your principles were ≈øo incurably hurt, or your braine dam'd and ram'd vp with ≈øuch a deale of dull and tough flegme, that it were as ea≈øy almo≈øt to remoue a mountaine as to moue you either to the one or the other. And yet indeed I find you of a cleene contrary complexion, euen the mo≈øt petti≈øh and wa≈øpi≈øh gentleman that euer I met withall, euery ≈ømall & petty occa≈øion ≈øtirs your choler, and works you pre≈øently out of temper. But becau≈øe I ≈øee it is your impotency & di≈øea≈øe I beare with you the more, praying you notwith≈øtanding to haue as much patience as you may, if at times for the purging of this humor I play the Phy≈øician and mini≈øter ≈øome ≈ømall quantity of rheubarb vnto you.

sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p: For alas, Ma≈øter Downe, what Rest can a man haue vpon Chri≈øt without A≈ø≈øurance to bee ≈øaued by his death and Pa≈ø≈øion and knowledge of his Lord and Sauiour. A full a≈ø≈øurance therefore as a cau≈øe, worketh Re≈øt vpon Chri≈øt as an effect, and is therefore the Generall word in the Definition of Iu≈øtifying Faith.

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
Your argument if I mi≈øtake not ≈øtandeth thus, That which is an Effect of A≈ø≈øurance cannot be the Act of Faith, But Resting vpon Chri≈øt is an Effect of A≈øsurance, Ergo, it cannot bee the Act of Faith. I di≈øtingui≈øh of A≈ø≈øurance, for it is either of the generall propo≈øition, or of the Speciall and indiuiduall; of the Generall when wee are a≈ø≈øured that, Who≈øoeuer Belieueth on Chri≈øt ≈øhall bee iustified and ≈øaued, of the Speciall when wee are certainly per≈øwaded that We are iu≈øtified and ≈øhall bee ≈øaued. If you meane the former, then I deny the Maior: for ≈øuch Hi≈øtoricall A≈ø≈øurance is a nece≈ø≈øary pre-requi≈øite vnto Iu≈øtifying Faith, and is the cau≈øe without which wee cannot belieue on Chri≈øt, and therefore that which is ≈øuch an effect of A≈øsurance may bee the Act of Faith. If you vnder≈øtand the latter, then doe I grant the Maior: for if ≈øuch A≈ø≈øurance be (as I haue demon≈øtratiuely proued) it ≈øelfe the Effect of Faith, it is more then manife≈øt that, That which is an effect of ≈øuch A≈ø≈øurance cannot bee the Act of Faith. But then I deny the Minor, that Re≈øting vpon Christ, is an effect of ≈øuch a≈ø≈øurance: affirming that contrarily
Re≈øting vpon Chri≈øt is the cau≈øe of ≈øuch A≈ø≈øurance, and A≈ø≈øurance is the Effect of that Re≈øting.

But, what re≈øt, ≈øay you, can a man haue vpon Chri≈øt, without A≈ø≈øurance to be ≈øaued by his Death & Pa≈ø≈øion? Surely vnle≈ø≈øe wee know his Death and Pa≈ø≈øion to bee the onely meanes of ≈øaluation, wee cannot re≈øt vpon him for it: but to ≈øay, that a man cannot re≈øt vpon him for ≈øaluation, vnle≈ø≈øe hee know that hee is already tran≈ølated from death to life, is a mo≈øt vnrea≈øonable and ≈øen≈øele≈ø≈øe ≈øpeech, as if a man might not tru≈øt vnto his friend to doe ≈øomething for him, vntill he were ≈øure, it is already done. If you be ≈øo ≈øandblind in this pre≈øent ca≈øe that you cannot ≈øee how Re≈øt may goe before A≈ø≈øurance, yet I hope your ≈øight is not ≈øo much decayed but you may perceiue it through a paire of ≈øpectacles. Put ca≈øe then that a skilfull and welknowne Phy≈øician ≈øhould offer freely to cure the di≈øea≈øes of ≈øuch as are ≈øicke vpon condition they receiue Phy≈øicke of no other, but put them≈øelues wholly & ab≈øolutely into his hands: doe you thinke it ab≈øurd to become his patient, or that you cannot repo≈øe your ≈øelfe vpon his skill to bee cured by him, vnle≈ø≈øe you be fir≈øt a≈ø≈øured that the cure is already done? Nay rather if you know well, that your health is perfectly recouered, you cannot rely vpon him, for that whereof you are fully po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. Ie≈øus Chri≈øt the Arch-phy≈øician of our ≈øoules, as hee is knowne to bee all-≈øufficient, and euery way able to heale our maladies, ≈øo doth hee louingly inuite all tho≈øe that are heauy loden to come vnto him, promi≈øing to refre≈øh them all vpon condition, that renouncing them≈øelues and all others they ≈øet their whole Affiance on him for the remi≈ø≈øion of their ≈øinnes. And dare you now make que≈øtion how a man
may betake him≈øelfe into the hands of Chri≈øt, vntill he know that his ≈øinnes bee already pardoned? Nay rather when wee know the debt is paid, and that according to the old rule ≈øinnes once remitted neuer returne againe, we remaine thankefull for that which is pa≈øt, and continue our Affiance on him for di≈øcharge of that which is to come. For (to ob≈øerue this by the way) wee may not thinke that in the fir≈øt act of our conuer≈øion and iu≈øtification we receiue actuall pardon of all our ≈øinnes pa≈øt, pre≈øent, and to come, as ≈øome, and tho≈øe of no meane marke haue ra≈øhly and vnadui≈øedly taught: for ≈øinnes pa≈øt only are then actually forgiuen, and ≈øinnes to come onely in the de≈øtination and purpo≈øe of God. But neither doth God actually pardon the iu≈øtified man, nor the iu≈øtified man actually receiue pardon for his ≈øinnes, vntill hee haue actually committed them, and renewed his Faith and Repentance for them. Neither let any man thinke that I ≈øpeake this out of mine owne head, and without ground: for I am ≈øtrongly backed herein by the warrant of Scripture, the euidence of rea≈øon, and the te≈øtimony of worthy men. By the warrant of Scripture: for that teacheth onely remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øinnes pa≈øt; ≈øo ≈øaith Saint Paul in expre≈ø≈øe tearmes,Rom. 3.25. God hath ≈øet forth Ie≈øus Chri≈øt to bee a reconciliation through faith in his bloud, to declare his righteou≈øne≈øse by the forgiuene≈øse of the ≈øinnes that are pa≈øsed: By the euidence of rea≈øon, for if future ≈øinnes as well as ≈øinnes pa≈øt bee actually remitted in our conuer≈øion and fir≈øt acceptation into grace, what need of Repentance, what need of Prayer that God would forgiue vs our tre≈øpa≈ø≈øes? To repent and craue p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ on of that whereof wee are not guilty, and which wee neuer committed, is palpable folly: and as great folly is it by
Repentance and prayer to demand that of God which wee ≈øay wee are ≈øure hee hath long agoe be≈øtowed vpon vs: Finally, by the te≈øtimony of worthy men; for Pardon, ≈øaith Origen, is of ≈øinnes pa≈øt not future: Repentance, In ad Rom. 3. De acerb√® Iudicantib. Mi≈øcell. lib. 3. pa. 97. ≈øaith Gregory Ny≈ø≈øen, is the di≈øsolution and de≈øtruction of ≈øinnes pa≈øt. It is confe≈øsed by all truly godly and learned, ≈øaith Hierome, Zanchie, that the Saints to obtaine new remi≈ø≈øion for a new ≈øinne haue need of a new act of Faith and Repentance, according to that ≈øaying ≈øo ri≈øe in Scripture, that by Faith men are iu≈øtified and haue their ≈øinnes remitted: which when it is ≈øpoken of them that are come to yeeres of di≈øcretion, is alwayes to be vnder≈øtood of Actuall Faith, that is of the Act of Faith.De praede≈øt. & grat. La≈øtly Master Perkins, when a Faithfull man grieuou≈øly ≈øinneth, the ≈øinne is indeed remitted in the de≈øtination of God: yet no remi≈ø≈øion is actually either giuen by God, or receiued by man vntill hee repent. Nay if hee ≈øhould neuer repent (which yet is impo≈ø≈øible) hee ≈øhould (as guilty of eternall death euen for this one ≈øin) be damned: for there is no new remi≈ø≈øion of any new ≈øinne without a new act of Faith and Repentance. But inough of this point in this place though it bee of great importance, becau≈øe it is but by the way: only hence I gather that ≈øeeing Faith goeth before and A≈ø≈øurance nece≈ø≈øarily commeth after remi≈ø≈øion, that Faith is not A≈ø≈øurance.

p.hi: I had rather ≈øay Faith were a labour then a Re≈øt: for it ≈øeeketh continually by ≈øanctification and holy loue to bring both body and ≈øoule vnto eternall re≈øt, and then Faith cea≈øeth when eternall pacification and re≈øt is wrought in man.

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
Thus you rea≈øon, Faith is a labour, Re≈øt is not a labour, Ergo, Faith is not a Re≈øt. The Maior you proue thus, That which worketh re≈øt is a labour, But Faith worketh re≈øt and cea≈øeth when re≈øt is wrought, Ergo, Faith is a labour. The Minor you leaue naked and without proofe, ≈øuppo≈øing I thinke that no man vnle≈ø≈øe bereft of his fiue wits would deny it, and hold that Re≈øt is a labour. Let vs therefore briefly examine them both. The Maior of your ≈øecond Syllogi≈øme preci≈øely and literally vnder≈øtood is not true: for that which worketh is the Agent or Labourer, and the Labourer cannot bee the Action or Labour. Whereupon it followeth, If that which worketh bee not a labour, And Faith as you a≈ø≈øume worke, that therefore Faith is not a labor which is contradictory vnto the Maior of your fir≈øt Syllogy≈øme. And yet as I grant not vnto you that Faith is a labour, ≈øo neither dare I peremptorily deny it: only I blame you for ≈øpeaking ≈øo confu≈øedly where it was nece≈ø≈øary to v≈øe di≈øtinction. Know therefore that Faith as all other qualities whether acquired or infu≈øed may bee con≈øidered two wayes, either in the fir≈øt act, (as Schooles v≈øe to ≈øpeake) or in the ≈øecond. The fir≈øt act is the very habit of Faith inhering and ≈øticking in the ≈øoule: the ≈øecond is the immediate and proper operation and action thereof. If then you vnder≈øtand Faith in the fir≈øt Act, and as it is an Habit, it is not a labour, but is imprinted in vs by the Holy Gho≈øt, to the end that when oportunity is offered, and duty requireth, wee may by vertue thereof more ≈øweetly, readily, and ea≈øily worke, and labour. And ≈øo
far is it from being a labor it ≈øelfe, that oftentimes it lieth as it were idle & a≈øleep doing nothing at all vntill it plea≈øe the Spirit of God to ≈øtirre vp our wils, and to quicken the ≈øparke hee hath put in vs, inabling vs thereby to cooperate with him. But if you vnder≈øtand Faith in the ≈øecond Act, and as it is in operation and action, then may you iu≈øtly call it a labour: for as our Sauiour ≈øaith,Ioh. 6.29. to belieue in him whom the Father hath ≈øent is a Worke which God requireth vs to doe, in regard whereof the Apo≈øtle Paul calleth it the Worke of Faith.1 The≈ø≈ø. 1.3. And becau≈øe Faith iu≈øtifieth, not as it is in the fir≈øt, but in the ≈øecond act, that is not as it is an Habit, but as it is in action, accepting and applying vnto vs Chri≈øt and his merits, hence is it, ≈øaith Bucer, that Prote≈øtants v≈øually define it by a motion.De iu≈øtific. Let the Maior therefore in this ≈øen≈øe bee granted vnto you.

The Minor which you thinke to bee ≈øo cock≈øure I flatly deny, confidently affirming that Re≈øt is a labour: prouided, you vnder≈øtand no other Re≈øt then that which in my Treati≈øe I haue expre≈ø≈øed and declared. For if by Re≈øt you meane Quiet, ≈øuch Re≈øt without all que≈øtion is not Labour: for it is the end of labour, and a ce≈ø≈øation from it, and therefore well did you ≈øay that, when eternall re≈øt is wrought, then the labour of Faith cea≈øeth. But you cannot bee ignorant, that by Re≈øt I vnder≈øtand not Quiet, but Affiance, in as much as I render the Latin word Fiducia by it, and make the Act thereof to bee Inniti, which (as I haue ≈øhewed in ≈øome of our Engli≈øh tran≈ølations) is oftentimes turned by Re≈øting and Staying vpon. And this Re≈øt, that is, this Relying, this Repo≈øing, this Tru≈øting or Belieuing on Chri≈øt, is not a Quiet, but a motion or operation, and therefore a labour. True it is that who≈øoeuer commeth vnto Chri≈øt, and ≈øetteth
his whole Affiance vpon him, ≈øhall thereby finde refre≈øhment and Quiet vnto his ≈øoule: yet neuerthele≈ø≈øe it is apparant that Affiance it ≈øelfe, is an act or motion of the Will, and not a Quiet, euen as the inclination of a mans ≈øelfe vpon his ≈øtaffe, or the laying of him downe vpon his bed is an action of the body. In a word remember what a little before I haue deliuered to cleare this tearme from all ambiguity, and take it in the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe which there I giue vnto it, and vnle≈ø≈øe you will ≈øay‚ñ™ that light is darkne≈ø≈øe you cannot but confe≈ø≈øe that ≈øuch re≈øt is a labour, and ≈øo that notwith≈øtanding this argument, Faith may be a Re≈øt.

But now giue mee leaue to take vp the weapon which you are forced to lay downe, and to trie whether a blow therewith from my arme will pearce any deeper: for thus I retort your owne rea≈øon again≈øt you. Faith is rather a labour then a re≈øt, A≈ø≈øurance is not ≈øo, but rather a re≈øt then a labour, Ergo, Faith is not A≈øsurance. The Maior is your owne, and you may not deny it. The Minor I proue thus, Intellection or knowledge, ≈øaith Ari≈øtotle, is more like vnto re≈øt and quiet then vnto motion: for although the mind while it is inquiring & ≈øeeking for knowledge is euer in motion and ≈øo laboureth, yet when the Habit of knowledge is once acquired and gotten, then is there no farther motion of the vnder≈øtanding thereunto, but a ≈øweet re≈øt and Quiet therein. Whereupon ≈øaith the ≈øame Philo≈øopher, By the quieting & ≈øetling of the ≈øoule, doth a man become intelligent and wi≈øe, meaning by Quiet, as Iulius Scaliger expoundeth him,Exerc. in Card. 307. 13. nothing el≈øe but the a≈ø≈øent of the minde. I a≈ø≈øume, But A≈ø≈øurance is ≈øuch intellection or knowledge, for it is an habituall a≈ø≈øent vnto this truth, that wee are in the pre≈øent ≈øtate of grace and
≈øhall infallibly bee ≈øaued. Wherefore I conclude that A≈øsurance is rather a re≈øt or quiet then a labour: whence al≈øo it farther followeth that Faith, being as you confe≈ø≈øe rather a labour, then a re≈øt, cannot be A≈øsurance.

Againe, Faith, you ≈øay, cea≈øeth when eternall pacification and re≈øt is wrought. I grant: for the Obiect of Faith, as the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith, are things which are not ≈øeene, whereupon Saint Augu≈øtin elegantly,Heb. 11.1. Si vides non e≈øt Fides, Beholding is not Belieuing. As therefore while we liue here in the≈øe earthly tabernacles, and are ab≈øent from the Lord, wee walke not by Sight, but by Faith: ≈øo when wee ≈øhall be clothed vpon,2. Cor. 5.4.7. Ver≈ø. 4. and mortality ≈øhall bee ≈øwallowed vp of life, then ≈øhall wee walke not by Faith, but by Sight. Neither is the cea≈øing of Faith any lo≈ø≈øe or di≈øaduantage, but an exchange for the better, namely vi≈øion: for Seeing vnto Belieuing is, as the full brightne≈ø≈øe of the Sunne is to the glimmering light of a candle. I a≈ø≈øume then, But A≈øsurance cea≈øeth not when eternall pacification and rest is wrought: for then the certainty of our Election, of our adoption, of our acceptation into grace, and finally of our Saluation is ≈øo farre from cea≈øing, that it is by ≈øo much the more confirmed vnto vs, as intuitiue apprehen≈øion and the ≈øight of the eye is more infallible then heare-≈øay or ≈øeeing by reflexion. I conclude therefore out of your owne principles, that Faith cea≈øing, and A≈øsurance not cea≈øing, Faith is not A≈øsurance. But as touching Affiance or Re≈øting vpon the mediation of Chri≈øt for iu≈øtification and Saluation, it is euident that that cea≈øeth when wee ≈øhall haue obtained eternall re≈øt and pacification. For being perfectly quitted of our ≈øinnes, and in full po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Saluation, how can wee farther ≈øet out Affiance vpon
him for it? E≈øpecially ≈øeeing hee ≈øhall then cea≈øe to bee vnto vs a Mediator of Redemption and Reconciliation, in regard whereof only hee is the Obiect of Affiance or Iu≈øtifying Faith, and ≈øhall bee vnto vs no otherwi≈øe then he is vnto the Elect Angels, a Mediatour of Con≈øeruation to confirme & pre≈øerue vs eternally in the mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed ≈øtate of glory. For neither ≈øhall hee Prophecy any more vnto vs by the mini≈øtry of the Go≈øpell, nor propitiate for vs by the ≈øacrifice of his death and Pa≈ø≈øion, nor gouerne vs by the ≈øcepter of his word as here hee doth:1 Cor. 15.24. but in this re≈øpect ≈øhall hee deliuer vp the Kingdome vnto his Father, and the Godhead in the holy Trinity ≈øhall without all meanes bee immediately vnto vs all in all.

p.hi: Re≈øt therefore in Christ is the Effect of Faith, and Faith is the cau≈øe of Rest: and ≈øo con≈øequently Faith is not Re≈øt, nor Rest is not Faith.

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
If, ≈øay you, Faith bee the cau≈øe of Re≈øt, and Re≈øt bee the Effect of Faith, then is not Faith Re≈øt nor Re≈øt Faith. This I yeeld you. But Faith is the cau≈øe of Re≈øt and Re≈øt is the effect of Faith. How proue you this? It ≈øeemeth by the illatiue particle: Therefore that you referre vs for this vnto ≈øome former premi≈ø≈øes. What then haue you formerly ≈øaid? That a full a≈øsurance as a cau≈øe worketh re≈øt vpon Chri≈øt as an effect. But neither is A≈ø≈øurance Faith, and I haue ≈øufficiently proued that A≈ø≈øurance is not the cau≈øe of Re≈øt, nor Re≈øt an effect of A≈ø≈øurance. Againe,
you ≈øay that Faith worketh eternall re≈øt and peace. But how doth this follow, Faith is the cau≈øe of eternall quiet and re≈øting from our labours in the Kingdome of Heauen, Ergo, it is the cau≈øe of Affiance and Re≈øting vpon Chri≈øt here in this life? for it is not nece≈ø≈øary that that which cau≈øeth the one, ≈øhould al≈øo cau≈øe the other. But if in your Conclu≈øion when you ≈øay Faith is not a Re≈øt, you meane it is not that eternall re≈øt, what is that to mee who define not Faith by ≈øuch a Re≈øt? So then your therefore either concluding be≈øide the Que≈øtion, or being inferred vpon no Premi≈ø≈øes, de≈øerueth of mee no an≈øwer at all. Yet to take away all ≈øcruple, let vs ≈øee what may be ≈øaid for it.

Bellarmine to proue that Affiance is an Effect of Faith,De iu≈øtif. lib. 1. cap. 6. and con≈øequently not Faith, alledgeth and vrgeth three pa≈ø≈øages of Scripture: but withall I mu≈øt tell you, that if hee di≈øpute to the purpo≈øe, hee mu≈øt meane by Affiance, no other then confident Per≈øwa≈øion or A≈ø≈øurance. For his aduer≈øaries, as him≈øelfe there ≈øaith, defining Faith by Affiance, vnder≈øtand thereby that Speciall Faith, whereby euery one applying to him≈øelfe the diuine Promi≈øe, belieueth or rather confidently tru≈øteth that all his ≈øins are forgiuen him by Chri≈øt. So that if (as he ought) hee argue vnto the meaning of his aduer≈øaries, hee concludeth not again≈øt my Affiance, but onely again≈øt your Per≈øwa≈øion or A≈ø≈øurance. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe let vs examine tho≈øe places ≈øeuerally and particularly. The fir≈øt is that of the Apo≈øtle to the Ephe≈øians,Eph. 3.12. In whom wee haue boldne≈ø≈øe and entrance with confidence by the Faith of him: whence it followeth, ≈øaith hee, if confidence or Affiance be by Faith, that Faith is not Affiance but the cau≈øe thereof: for otherwi≈øe the ≈øen≈øe would bee, we haue entrance
with confidence by confidence, which is ab≈øurd. To this I an≈øwer, fir≈øt that „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ or Confidence oftentimes ≈øignifieth Per≈øwa≈øion or A≈ø≈øurance, being deriued of a verbe that ≈øignifieth firmely to be Per≈øwaded, as where the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith,Rom. 2.19.
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , thou ≈øtrongly per≈øwade≈øt thy ≈øelfe that thou art a guide of the blind; Phil. 1.25. and againe, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , this am I well a≈øsured of: and therefore it is not nece≈ø≈øary here to vnder≈øtand it of my Affiance. Secondly, grant that by „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ this Affiance is meant, yet doth it not follow that it is an effect of Iu≈øtifying Faith, ≈øeeing by faith not Iu≈øtifying but Hi≈øtoricall Faith may bee vnder≈øtood, which is the meanes by which wee grow vnto Affiance. La≈øtly, let it be farther yeelded, that both, by „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ Affiance, and by
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ iu≈øtifying Faith are meant; yet may Affiance this notwith≈øtanding bee that Faith, neither will any ≈øuch ab≈øurdity en≈øue thereon. For as when you ≈øay, wee are a≈ø≈øured by Faith you would thinke your ≈øelfe wronged if I ≈øhould inferre thereupon that Faith is not A≈ø≈øurance but the cau≈øe thereof, or that otherwi≈øe the ≈øen≈øe would bee wee are a≈ø≈øured by a≈ø≈øurance: ≈øo when the Apo≈øtle ≈øaith in Affiance by Faith, why ≈øhould he not al≈øo count him≈øelfe as much abu≈øed if you gather from hence that Faith is not Affiance but the cau≈øe thereof, or that el≈øe the ≈øpeech would be ab≈øurd, as if hee ≈øhould ≈øay in Affiance by Affiance. The rea≈øon of all in a word is, becau≈øe this forme of words may import that Affiance is the next and immediate Act of Iu≈øtifying Faith. The ≈øecond place is that ≈øaying of our Sauiour vnto the woman di≈øea≈øed with an i≈ø≈øue of blood,Mat. 9.22. Bee confident daughter, thy Faith hath ≈øaued thee: where ≈øaith hee, Faith is againe in like ≈øort di≈øtingui≈øhed from Affiance; for the woman
is moued to conceiue and entertaine Affiance who was already healed by Faith. To this I an≈øwer, that the word which our Sauiour v≈øeth to the woman is „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ which ≈øignifieth to be bold or couragious, whence commeth „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ Boldnes, courage,Exerc. 317.4. which as Iulius Scaliger ≈øaith, is the motion of Fortitude vnto ≈øome worke, and is oppo≈øed vnto Timerou≈øne≈ø≈øe or Fearefulne≈ø≈øe. Neither was it without ≈øpeciall rea≈øon that our Sauiour cho≈øe that word rather then any other: for finding that vertue proceeded from him, and demanding who had touched him,Luc. 8.47. the woman ≈øeeing that ≈øhee could conceale it came vnto him trembling, and fell at his feet, and declared what ≈øhee had done, whereupon hee ≈øaid vnto her, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Tremble not Daughter, nor be di≈ømay'd, but cheere vp and bee of good courage, for I a≈øsure thee thy Faith hath ≈øaued thee, goe thy way in Peace. Now this Boldne≈ø≈øe or courage I confe≈ø≈øe is an effect of Faith, nay oftentimes an effect of the effect of Faith, namely Hope: for as De≈øpaire of victory cau≈øeth Fearefulne≈ø≈øe and deiection of Spirit, ≈øo contrariwi≈øe Hope of victory maketh a man to bee bold and confident. And hence it is that the Syriacke oftentimes rendreth this word by Retection or Reuelation of the face, becau≈øe a good con≈øcience lifteth vp the head, and boldly ≈øheweth the face: whereas a guiltie minde hangeth downe the head, and (as one confounded and a≈øhamed) dares not looke either God or man in the face. And therefore to end this di≈øcour≈øe, whereunto not the force of your Conclu≈øion (which being barely affirmed might as ea≈øily haue beene reiected) but onely the ≈øincere de≈øire I haue to leaue nothing vn≈øatisfied, drew me: I ≈øtill pronounce that for any thing hitherto hath beene ≈øaid, Iu≈øtifying Faith is an Affiance.

Yet before I proceed any farther, I mu≈øt bee ≈øo bold as to plucke you by the eare, and to call to your remembrance what erewhile you ≈øaid, namely that a man may re≈øt his will vpon Christ and his merits and yet bee damned. p.hi: Be≈øides this word Rest is ambiguous, and may bee taken in ill part, and may bee in many negligent and carele≈øse Chri≈øtians which euery day and for euery ≈øinne bring Chri≈øt to the Cro≈ø≈øe, and ≈øay wee will rest vpon Christ, and in the meane time worke nothing worthy of the Name of a Chri≈øtian, but rather wallow in all kind of filthine≈øse. sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
That the word Re≈øt is ambiguous I ≈øaw well inough, and therefore in my Treati≈øe carefully di≈øtingui≈øhed the equiuocation thereof, where if you marked it not, you mu≈øt blame your owne ouer≈øight and not my Vnwarine≈ø≈øe. For two kinds of Re≈øting vpon Christ, I ≈øaid there were, the one Sleight and Superficiall, the other Setled and well grounded, and this Setled and grounded Affiance I made to bee the Act of Iustifying Faith, as there you may read more at large. Now you, to preuent captious cauils, tell me, that when you ≈øay, a man may bee damned notwith≈øtanding his Re≈øting vpon Chri≈øt, you vnder≈øtand it of that which may bee in many negligent and carele≈ø≈øe Chri≈øtians, that is to ≈øay of Sleight and ≈øuperficiall Affiance onely. Wherein you ≈øhew your ≈øelfe too too both ridiculous and idle: ridiculous in ≈øaying, you ≈øpeake
this to preuent my captious cauils, whereas indeed this very captious cauill of yours was in my Treati≈øe as appeareth ≈øo manife≈øtly preuented by mee: Idle, in arguing from ≈øleight and ≈øuperficiall Affiance vnto that which is Setled and Grounded on this manner (for ≈øo in effect you confe≈ø≈øe,) Sleight Affiance may bee in the Damned, Ergo, ≈øetled Affiance is not Iu≈øtifying Faith, as if you ≈øhould ≈øay, An a≈ø≈øe may haue a ≈øhadow, Ergo, the Body of a man is not a ≈øolid ≈øub≈øtance. And thus, to requite you with your owne Prouerbe, you peri≈øh like the rat by bewraying your ≈øelfe: for hauing vrged this argument now twice again≈øt mee and that with ≈øuch confidence as if it alone were ≈øufficient to batter downe the bulwarke of my Definition, at length you tell ys very grauely and ≈øadly that it is but paper ≈øhot which hitherto you haue di≈øcharged, and that all the breaches you haue made may ea≈øily bee repaired by di≈øtingui≈øhing an equiuocation.

Where you ≈øay I take vpon mee to ≈øee more then euer any learned man ≈øaw before my time, it hath beene already ≈øufficiently an≈øwered both in my Treati≈øe & in this Defence thereof. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe becau≈øe you harpe ≈øo often vpon this ≈øtring, this I adde, that (vnle≈ø≈øe you can demon≈øtrate that it is impo≈ø≈øible for a man of meane parts, and gifts to ≈øee and ob≈øerue that which men of greater learning and deeper vnder≈øtanding haue not ob≈øerued) I know no rea≈øon why a man may not without taxation of mode≈øty take vpon him in ≈øome things to ≈øee that which others haue not ≈øeene before him. It is true that a Giant by rea≈øon of his tallne≈ø≈øe mu≈øt needs ≈øee farther then a dwarfe or one that is but of a meane ≈øtature: yet if you place a dwarfe aloft vpon the ≈øhoulders of a giant,

And yet by your fauour, Sir, I take no ≈øuch matter vpon mee, or if I ≈øeeme to doe ≈øo, I hope I doe it with all mode≈øtie, and it can bee no more then this that out of ≈øuch Premi≈øes as they haue taught mee, I gather a Conclu≈øion which they attended not.

sp.speaker: N. B.

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
Neither is it your vaine ≈øurmi≈øing what Ma≈øter Perkins would ≈øay; Neither his expre≈ø≈øe and direct ≈øaying,

Perkins place it only in the vnder≈øtanding,On the Creed. affirming that it ≈øcarce ≈øtandeth with rea≈øon that one ≈øingle grace ≈øhould inhere in two di≈øtinct faculties: why may not I take the ≈øame liberty vnto my ≈øelfe, and define Iu≈øtifying Faith by Affiance, although M. Perkins would take it for no other then the Effect of Iu≈øtifying Faith? for ≈øo indeed hee doth, and I deny not, but freely confe≈ø≈øe, that vpon the rea≈øons aboue rendred, I doe in this point altogether differ from him. sp.speaker: N. B.

Baxter, that booke is not of ≈øuch bulke but that peru≈øing the titles of each Chapter you might ≈øoone haue found out the places by me intended: and you know that the ≈øchedule I ≈øent you, being endited at Bristoll, where I was farre from my bookes, I could not po≈ø≈øibly referre

But now becau≈øe I haue the booke at hand, I will ≈øet you downe his direct words, and quote you the page where you may read them, and then leaue you to bee iudge your ≈øelfe, whether as you charge mee I abu≈øe the writings of that reuerend man, or hee agree with mee in this, that Faith is not A≈ø≈øurance.Foxe. Master Foxe therefore in his booke de Christo gratis iu≈øtificante, pag. 246.≈øaith thus, My iudgement and opinion is that this confidence of mercy, and certainty of Saluation promi≈øed is a thing which ought to bee very neerely conioined with Faith, and which euery one ought nece≈ø≈øarily to apply vnto him≈øelfe: yet being most applied is not that which onely by it ≈øelfe properly and ab≈øolutely di≈øchargeth vs of our ≈øinnes, and iu≈øtifies before God, but that there is ≈øome other thing propounded in the Go≈øpell, which in nature goeth before this certainty, and iu≈øtifieth before God. For Faith vpon the Per≈øon of the Sonne of God, whereby wee are fir≈øt reconciled vnto God nece≈øsarily goes before. Againe pag. 253. Although, ≈øaith hee, certainty and a≈øsurance of diuine grace (which it ≈øelfe is ≈øometime commended vnder the name of Faith) bee very neerely ioined with Faith, yet this a≈ø≈øurance doth not properly import the cau≈øe of iu≈øtifying, but receiueth it being brought, neither worketh iustification, but is rather wrought by it, and maketh them certaine, who by the Faith of Chri≈øt are iu≈øtified, but it ≈øelfe iu≈øtifieth not. Yet to preuent captious cauils, you may bee plea≈øed to vnder≈øtand that the Latin word v≈øed by Ma≈øter Foxe, to wit Fiducia, I haue in my tran≈ølation engli≈øhed Confidence and A≈ø≈øurance; not that I was afraid le≈øt rendring it Affiance, hee might ≈øeeme to exclude my affiance al≈øo from the Definition of Faith, for had hee done ≈øo, it were nothing to mee, hauing ≈øhewed that hee denies Faith to be A≈ø≈øurance, which was all I there affirmed of him: but becau≈øe, if you marke his words attentiuely, you ≈øhall find that by Fiducia, hee vnder≈øtands not Affiance, but confident Per≈øwa≈øion or A≈ø≈øurance, for hee doth euer confound it with Certainty, and expre≈øly defines it to bee that whereby wee are a≈ø≈øured of our iu≈øtification by Chri≈øt. sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p: Now thinke not that I hold, that a man ordinarily ≈øaued may be ≈øaued without relying vpon Chri≈øt Ie≈øus: for I hold the cleane contrary, viz. that true Iu≈øtifying Faith a≈øsuring a man in ≈øpirituall knowledge of his owne ≈øaluation in Ie≈øus Christ, worketh and cau≈øeth a ≈øweet rest and repo≈øing of the whole ≈øoule vpon Chri≈øt and his Merits. sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p: And to be plaine with you, when you ≈øay Iu≈øtifying Faith is not a Knowledge or an A≈øsurance, Tom. 3. de Iu≈øtif. ca. 7. you ≈øpeake pure Bellarmine, as appeareth in his Booke de iu≈øtificatione. I pray you therefore though you mi≈ølike M. Perkins, turne not pure Papi≈øt.

sp.speaker: I. D.

sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p: Now, Ma≈øter Downe, to make an end, and returne to my other affaires from whence you haue vnkindly drawne mee, I pray you read a few Po≈øitions to the which oppo≈øe what you can.

sp.speaker: I. D.

sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p: True Iu≈øtifying Faith defined.1. Iustifying Faith, is an a≈ø≈øured knowledge, or knowing a≈øsurance, by the which euery one of the elected relieth vpon the Promi≈øes of the mercy of God in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, firmely holding that Chri≈øt and eternall life together with all the merits of Chri≈øt, are giuen to him to righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe and eternall ≈øaluation.
Fides vnica & indiuidua ≈øpecie. Haec Fides differt numero & gradu.2. There is but one onely ≈øpeciall iu≈øtifying Faith.

Mat. 26.74.75. & 17.17. Mat. 9.24.6. This Faith differeth in degrees, ≈ømall in one man, and mighty in another, Mat. 13.23. & 14.31. Act. 2.8. ca. 4. Mat. 15.28.
Fides imperfecta; Ad re≈øi≈øtendum tamen diabolo ≈øufficiens & quare.7. The greate≈øt Faith in this life is imperfect. 1 Cor. 13.9. & 12.

2 Cor. 5.1. E≈øa. 53.11. Cau≈øa efficiens material.9. This Knowledge or Faith (for they bee conuertible Ioh. 17.3.) pa≈ø≈øeth all vnder≈øtanding Eph. 3.14. &c.

Word of God, in ≈øpeciality the promi≈øes of God in Chri≈øt and his Merits.

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
The fir≈øt, the thirteenth, and the foureteenth, I wholly and ab≈øolutely deny, hauing fully proued, again≈øt the fir≈øt, that Faith is not a Knowledge or A≈ø≈øurance; again≈øt the thirteenth, that the onely proper Obiect of Faith is the Per≈øon of the Mediator, and again≈øt the foureteenth, that the Forme thereof is Affiance and not any ≈øuch Relation or Certainty. The ninth, ≈øixteenth, and ≈øeuenteenth in part I deny: the ninth, where you make Faith and Knowledge to bee conuertible which I haue proued to haue different natures and Definitions; the ≈øixteenth where you affirme Re≈øting vpon Chri≈øt to bee an effect of Faith, which I haue demon≈øtrated to bee the Forme and proper Act of Faith; the ≈øeuenteenth, where you ≈øay that the ≈øubiect of Faith is both the Vnder≈øtanding and the Will, again≈øt which I haue ≈øhewed, that it is impo≈ø≈øible
for one and the ≈øame Habit to be ≈øubiectiuely in two ≈øeuerall faculties of the Soule. The re≈øt of your Po≈øitions (≈øauing the inconuenience of ≈øome tearmes, and ≈øetting a fauourable con≈øtruction vpon them) I acknowledge to bee true; and becau≈øe, as the Apo≈øtle ≈øpeaketh, I can doe nothing again≈øt the truth, but for the truth, therefore I oppo≈øe them not, but readily and willingly yeeld and ≈øub≈øcribe vnto them.

But, Ma≈øter Baxter, in all this long di≈øcour≈øe of Faith, hauing ≈øpoken ≈øo carefully of the Definition of Faith, of the vnity of it in kind, and difference of it in number and degree, of the imperfection, ≈øufficiencie, efficient, principall and in≈øtrumentall, of the obiect both in generall and ≈øpeciall, of the forme, and end both Subordinate and Highe≈øt, finally of the Effects, Subiects, and adiuncts thereof: in all this long di≈øcour≈øe, I ≈øay, how is it that wee heare not ≈øo much as a word of Iu≈øtification, which notwith≈øtanding is the immediate and proper Effect of Faith? Immediate, becau≈øe it is the fir≈øt fruite and benefit that ≈øpringeth of it, and commeth before Adoption and Sanctification: proper, becau≈øe it is the Act of Faith onely, and not of any other Grace which iu≈øtifies a man before God. Whether it were of negligence, or of policy, that you haue omitted ≈øo materiall and nece≈ø≈øary a point, I cannot ≈øay. If of negligence, it de≈øerues a ≈øeuere cha≈øti≈øement: if of policy, it was I think you fore≈øaw what a dangerous con≈øequence would follow thereupon. For if you had placed Iu≈øtification (as needs you mu≈øt haue done if you had mentioned it) among the Effects of Faith, the Reader po≈ø≈øibly might haue rea≈øoned thus, If iu≈øtification be an Effect of Faith and ≈øo follow after Faith, then cannot A≈ø≈øurance of Iu≈øtification
bee Faith, becau≈øe it is an effect of Iu≈øtification and followes after: for it is nece≈ø≈øary that a man bee iu≈øtified, before hee can bee a≈ø≈øured that hee is iu≈øtified. And thus you had ca≈øt away your whole pot of broth,2 King. 4.39. if you had not warily kept this Coloquintida out of it. But vpon what ground ≈øoeuer you haue forborne to ≈øpeake of this point, I will by your leaue ≈øupply this defect, and in a word or two ≈øhew you in what ≈øen≈øe I affirme that Affiance iu≈øtifies, and deny it of A≈ø≈øurance: for in ≈øome ≈øort A≈ø≈øurance al≈øo may bee ≈øaid to iu≈øtifie.

Iu≈øtification is a law-tearme, and is oppo≈øed vnto Condemnation. As therefore Condemnation is the ≈øentence of a iudge pronouncing a man to be guilty, and deliuering him ouer to bee puni≈øhed: ≈øo is Iu≈øtification al≈øo the ≈øentence of a iudge, but ab≈øoluing and acquitting a man both from crime and puni≈øhment. Now there are three barres at which all men are arraigned, and three Iudges, who at their ≈øeuerall barres either iu≈øtify vs, or condemne vs, that is to ≈øay, the barre of God, the barre of Con≈øcience, and the barre of Men. If wee bee condemned at all the≈øe barres, and by all the≈øe Iudges, wee are of all creatures the mo≈øt mi≈øerable: if wee bee ab≈øolued at them all, and by them all, of all men wee be the mo≈øt ble≈ø≈øed. Againe, if Men acquit vs, what booteth it, if our owne Con≈øcience condemne vs? and if our Con≈øcience acquit vs, what auaileth it, if God condemne vs? for who can deliuer the prey out of the pawes of that Lion? On the contrary ≈øide, if men condemne vs, it mattereth not, ≈øo as our Con≈øcience doe ab≈øolue vs: and if our Con≈øcience al≈øo doe condemne vs, yet happy are we, if God ab≈øolue vs, for God is greater then our Con≈øcience. What that is,1 Ioh. 3.20. for which ≈øentence of
Condemnation pa≈ø≈øeth vpon vs at any of the≈øe bars there is no que≈øtion, for it is well knowne to bee ≈øinne: ≈øinne I ≈øay which is ≈øo indeed, or at lea≈øt is ≈øo in appearance. For although nothing appeare vnto God otherwi≈øe then it is, ≈øo that there can bee no error in his iudgement: yet our owne con≈øciences and other men may ea≈øily bee deceiued and mi≈øtaken, and ≈øo without cau≈øe oftentimes pronounce ≈øentence of Condemnation. What then is that by which wee are iu≈øtifyed and ab≈øolued from our ≈øins, and the puni≈øhment of death due vnto them? Surely, that which is contrary vnto ≈øinne, euen Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe. What Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe?Phil. 3.9. for, as the Apo≈øtle di≈øtingui≈øheth, there is a Righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe which is of the law, and there is a righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe which is of Faith: by the former, ≈øhall no fle≈øh liuing bee iu≈øtified, by the latter euery one that Belieueth is iu≈øtified. God iu≈øtifieth vs at his barre when hee ≈øeeth our Faith, that by firme Affiance wee re≈øt and rely our ≈øelues vpon Chri≈øt to bee our Mediator, accepting him to bee our Prophet, Prie≈øt, and King: for then according vnto promi≈øe doth hee accept the Pa≈ø≈øiue obedience of Chri≈øt to ≈øatisfy for our ≈øinnes pa≈øt, and imputeth vnto vs his Actiue obedience to ≈øupply the want of that perfect legall righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe which ≈øhould be in vs. Our Con≈øcience iu≈øtifies vs at his barre, when it is per≈øwaded that God hath already iu≈øtified vs: for as long as it is per≈øwaded that God condemneth, it cannot acquit vs. If the per≈øwa≈øion of the Con≈øcience be built vpon a ≈øandy and deceitfull foundation, it is rather vaine pre≈øumption then true a≈ø≈øurance, and the iudgement that it giueth is erronious: but if it bee grounded vpon infallible euidence, euen the te≈øtimony of the Spirit of God,Rom. 8.16. witne≈ø≈øing with our ≈øpirits that wee are the
≈øons of God, then is the A≈ø≈øurance ≈øound and certaine, and the ≈øentence pronounced thereupon iu≈øt and rightfull,Phil. 4.7. whence pre≈øently ari≈øeth in our ≈øoules ≈øuch vnconceiuable peace as pa≈ø≈øeth all vnder≈øtanding, and ≈øuch durable ioy as nothing can take from vs. Finally, Men iu≈øtify vs at their barre al≈øo,Ioh. 16.22. Mat. 5.16. when our light ≈øo ≈øhineth before them, that they ≈øee our good works, which are the fruits of Faith and a good Con≈øcience, and thereby are moued to glorify our Heauenly Father: as being per≈øwaded in the iudgement of Charity that they are indeed as they ≈øeeme to bee, euen iu≈øtified before God, and borne againe of water and the Holy Gho≈øt. This iudgement becau≈øe it is built vpon probability onely, and not vpon certainty (for who knowes whether the outward appearance come from the inward holyne≈ø≈øe or hollowne≈ø≈øe of the heart, but onely the heart it ≈øelfe, and God which made it?) May therefore bee erronious, and though proceeding from Charity, yet in the meane ≈øea≈øon ≈øwaruing from verity. If then when Men iu≈øtify vs, our owne Con≈øciences tell vs, that they pronounce a wrong ≈øentence, and ab≈øolue the guilty: the comfort that growes vnto vs thereby is no better then a cup of cold water is vnto a man ≈øicke of a burning feuer, or then the Sardonian laughter which makes the face ≈øeeme to grin, while the deadly poi≈øon is ≈øearching through euery veine, and ≈øeazing vpon the very heart. But if wee bee well a≈ø≈øured that the ≈øentence is iu≈øt and true, and that they are not deceiued therein, although it bee not the end wee aymed at, nor the Crowne wee looked for, yet is it a ≈øweet and amiable companion of holy life, publickely te≈øtifying vnto our great comfort that God hath been glorified by vs, our profe≈ø≈øion honoured, and
others inuited if not gained vnto Chri≈øt. And thus much haue I thought good in regard of your ≈øilence to ≈øpeake I hope not impertinently, at lea≈øt wi≈øe not vnprofitably of Iu≈øtification: the ≈øumme whereof is that Affiance iu≈øtifies before God, A≈ø≈øurance before Con≈øience, works before Men. So that I doe not ≈øimply deny either that A≈ø≈øurance is Faith (for in my Treati≈øe I acknowledge that the Scripture ≈øometime calleth it Faith) or that it iu≈øtifieth (for I confe≈ø≈øe it iu≈øtifieth at the barre of Con≈øcience) onely I deny it to bee that Faith which iu≈øtifies before God, affirming that Faith to bee no other then Affiance.

sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p: Thus, Ma≈øter Downe, you haue, what you haue ≈øo much, ≈øo earne≈øtly, ≈øo bitterly, and contumeliou≈øly wre≈øted from mee in writing, ≈øith that you haue refu≈øed to defend your Doctrine preached here by Di≈øputation.

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
Indeed, Ma≈øter Baxter, when I vnder≈øtood by the aduerti≈øements of ≈øundry my good friends in Bri≈øtoll, that you had not onely drawne vp an An≈øwer again≈øt me full of reprochfull and di≈øgracefull ≈øpeeches, but had al≈øo di≈øper≈øed it abroad into the hands of diuers Burge≈ø≈øes of that City, thereby to di≈øcredit both mee, and the Doctrine which I preached among them, without vouch≈øafing after a whole twelue months ≈øpace to ≈øend mee a copie thereof according vnto promi≈øe: true it is that as ≈øoone as the next oportunity was affoarded mee, I could not forbeare to chalenge you for this vnchri≈øtian and
vn≈øchollerly dealing, and to let you know the iu≈øt indignation and di≈ødaine I conceiued thereat. Be≈øides that once, did I neuer either by word or writing ≈øollicit you in this matter: and then earne≈øt perhaps and vehement I might bee in expo≈øtulating with you, but Bitter and Contumelious I am ≈øure I was not, and for proofe thereof I referre mee vnto the te≈øtimonie of tho≈øe who were then pre≈øent with vs. But whether earne≈øt and vehement, or Bitter and Contumelious, An≈øwer from you by no meanes could I wre≈øt any. And that now I haue obtained a Copie thereof, thanks vnto tho≈øe my good friends who neuer left following vpon the ≈øent of the Foxe vntill they ≈øurprized him for me, and not vnto you who de≈øired and laboured nothing more then to keep it from mee. Of all men you liked not it ≈øhould light into my hands, and yet of all men me it mo≈øt concerned, and vnto mee was onely promi≈øed. And ≈øo after the Parthian manner you fight flying, and as Cae≈øar ≈øaid of the Scythians make it more difficult to finde you then to foile you.

Well yet I refu≈øed, you ≈øay, to defend the Doctrine I preached by di≈øputation. Fir≈øt, the cour≈øe which formerly we had agreed and re≈øolued vpon was Writing: and therefore I ≈øaw no rea≈øon why I ≈øhould yeeld to haue the cau≈øe remoued from a higher vnto an inferiour Court, from Writing vnto Di≈øputation. For as a late learned writer ≈øaith, Writings are more ≈øolid, peaceable, Dan. Chamier Ep. ad Egnat. Armand. and certaine, then is pre≈øent ≈øpeech: for more ≈øolid must tho≈øe things needs bee which are meditated then which are ≈øuddenly; ≈øpoken, more peaceable then tho≈øe things which are done in the tumult, and while the minds of the Di≈øputants are with pre≈øent vehemence inflamed; more certaine,
for writings remaine, and words are winged and fly away, and writings ea≈øily conuince the impudence of them that would corrupt them, which ≈øpeaking cannot ≈øo well doe. And although in quicke writing there bee without que≈øtion more adui≈øedne≈ø≈øe then in pre≈øent ≈øpeaking, yet doth Saint Hierome excu≈øe his ha≈øty commentary vpon Saint Mathews Go≈øpell,Proaem. comment. in Math. promi≈øing a more ab≈øolute worke, that you may know, ≈øaith hee, What ods there is betweene the boldne≈ø≈øe of ≈øudden enditing, and the diligence of well-≈øtudied writing. Secondly, as the Apo≈øtle Saint Paul an≈øwered the Serieants that were ≈øent vnto him from the gouernours of Philippi,Act. 16.37. After that they haue beaten vs openly vncondemned which are Romans, they haue cast vs into Pri≈øon, and now would they put vs out priuily? Nay verily, but let them come and bring vs out: ≈øo ≈øay I vnto you, after you haue in a more publicke manner traduced and wronged mee, ≈øcattering through the whole City a mo≈øt ≈ølanderous inuectiue and libell again≈øt mee, doe you thinke now by a priuate and chamber-di≈øputation to content mee? Nay verily, this plai≈øter is too narrow for the wound, and open wrong requires open ≈øatisfaction. La≈øtly, how≈øoeuer you pretend that you ≈øet not pen to paper vntill I had refu≈øed your chalenge of di≈øputation, the Reader may bee plea≈øed to vnder≈øtand that it is cleane contrary. And therefore as I cannot but impute your deniall to impart vnto mee what in writing you had oppo≈øed again≈øt mee, to the di≈øtru≈øt you had either in your cau≈øe, or in your owne ≈øufficiency: ≈øo now, hauing ≈øcribled away ≈øo much precious time, and ≈øacrificed ≈øo much paper to Cloacina, that ≈øuddenly you apprehend a di≈øputation, I a≈ø≈øure my ≈øelfe it was but a ≈øleight deui≈øed vpon the pre≈øent to ≈øhift
mee off, and to rid your ≈øelfe from me, who≈øe re≈øidence you knew to bee el≈øewhere, and who at that time was to take vp a nights lodging with you. Or if you meant ≈øincerely and vnfainedly, double≈ø≈øe it was confidence you had either in the boldne≈ø≈øe of your forehead vncapable of the purple tincture of mode≈øty, or in the vnskilfulnes of tho≈øe who were like to be our Auditors & Moderators, who as I take it haue more skill in Marchandize and trafficking, then in Demon≈øtration or Dialecticall Syllogi≈ømes. For otherwi≈øe wee had beene vpon equall ground in either of the Vniuer≈øities, I ≈øuppo≈øe you would haue beene better adui≈øed ere you had made that challenge vnto mee.

sp.speaker: N. B.
sp.p: I pray God it may worke in you a willing mind to embrace Peace and Brotherly loue, without the which wee can neuer ≈øee God. Bri≈øtol. Iuly 27. 1602.

sp.speaker: I. D.
sp.p:
It is impo≈ø≈øible that vnto a man of vnder≈øtanding any benefit or profit ≈øhould accrew by reprehen≈øion, vnle≈ø≈øe it may appeare vnto him by ≈øome euident remon≈øtrance that that which is reproued in him bee faulty and erronious, and that al≈øo hee bee guilty thereof. For they that thinke them≈øelues to bee in health, will hardly be drawne to take Phy≈øicke:In Pa≈øtore. and then ≈øhall we better correct them that are wayward, ≈øaith Gregory, when tho≈øe things which they belieue to bee well done, wee demon≈øtrate to bee euill. Whereas therefore it plea≈øeth you here in the conclu≈øion
and clo≈øing vp of your An≈øwer, to charge mee with a mo≈øt Vnpeaceable and Vncharitable di≈øpo≈øition, praying God it may worke in me a willing mind to embrace peace and brotherly loue: you may not thinke that this can any way affect or moue mee, vnle≈ø≈øe fir≈øt you ≈øhew that I am guilty of this crime, and beare a mind ≈øo auer≈øe and abhorring from Peace and Charity, as you pretend, which I am ≈øure hitherto you neither haue done nor can doe. For though you haue carefully ≈øearched euery corner of my Treati≈øe, and ran≈øackt euery letter and ≈øyllable thereof with as much greedine≈ø≈øe as euer Laban did Iacobs ≈øtuffe to find his Idols therein;Gen. 31.33. yet haue you not found any thing ≈øauouring other then of Peace and Loue, or if you haue, why doe you not, as Iacob ≈øaid vnto his Vncle, put it here before your brethren & my brethren, Ver≈ø. 37. that they may iudge betweene vs both? You will ≈øay perhaps that in broaching this erronious doctrine touching the Definition of Faith, I plainely bewrayed a ≈øeditious ≈øpirit, and that I intended the interruption of Peace and di≈ø≈øolution of loue. But neither is it nece≈ø≈øary that who≈øoeuer deliuereth an error ≈øhould pre≈øently haue ≈øuch a ≈øeditious intention, for then what writer almo≈øt either ancient or late but is guilty of that impiety? Neither is the doctrine errronious, but ≈øound and good, and now plentifully proued ≈øo to bee by this Defence thereof again≈øt your An≈øwer. So that this accu≈øation of yours, is altogether vniu≈øt, and grounded vpon no truth at all. Suppo≈øe neuerthele≈ø≈øe it were iu≈øt, and that you had found your Idols, I meane both Fal≈øhood and Faction in my writing: is it po≈ø≈øible thinke you that ≈øuch an An≈øwer as this is, either of it ≈øelfe, or ≈øanctified by your Prayer, may be effectuall to reclaime
mee from mine errour, or to worke mee vnto a more peaceable mind? Certainly it is impo≈ø≈øible. For what is it of it ≈øelfe other then a fardle of vanities? And what promi≈øe haue you in Gods word that vpon your prayer you ≈øhall bee able to open the eyes of the blind by dawbing them ouer with clay, or to ≈øtill the raging of the ≈øea by ≈øending forth more ≈øtormes and tempe≈øts vpon it? And that ≈øuch is your An≈øwer, and ≈øuch the cour≈øe you haue taken therein, although this Defence haue already made it as cleere as the noone-day: yet mu≈øt I intreat your patience before I di≈ømi≈ø≈øe you in a word or two, to trauer≈øe it ouer againe, and in a briefe Synop≈øis as it were to ≈øet before you the very ≈øpirit and quinte≈ø≈øence thereof, that if it be po≈ø≈øible you may ≈øee your nakedne≈ø≈øe,Gen. 3.10. and be a≈øhamed.

Fir≈øt, it is your manner like the Schollers of Theodorus to receiue with the left hand that which I offer with the right, that is to wre≈øt and peruert my plaine≈øt words,Plutarch. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . and to make them ≈øpeake not that which I intend, but what you conceiue is fitte≈øt for you to de≈øcant vpon. For example where I ≈øay, I will not ≈øpeake of the notation, or diuer≈øe acceptions of the word Faith: you turne it another way ≈øaying I refu≈øe, and accu≈øe, and find fault with them. Againe where I argue thus, It is very probable, that many are ≈øaued without A≈øsurance, becau≈øe our brethren of Germany hold a man cannot bee a≈øsured of Saluation: you make me rea≈øon thus, What≈øoeuer our brethren of Germany hold is true. And againe where I affirme that the Saint of God both may bee a≈ø≈øured and ought to bee a≈ø≈øured: you report mee to ≈øay that hee ought to have it as of nece≈øsity to ≈øaluation. And yet againe where I ≈øay God ≈øhould command a reprobate to believe an vntruth if hee
command him to belieue that hee ≈øhall bee ≈øaued: you relate it as if I had ≈øayd, God ≈øhould command a reprobate to belieue an vntruth if hee command him to belieue, and hee ≈øhall bee ≈øaued. The≈øe and ≈øundry other ≈øentences in like ≈øort doe you mi≈øcon≈øter and wilfully depraue: vnle≈ø≈øe perhaps your ignorance bee ≈øo gro≈ø≈øe and palpable that you could not picke the right ≈øen≈øe out of the plaine≈øt tearmes that po≈ø≈øibly could bee v≈øed. But nothing is well ≈øpoken, Terent. Pigh. Onely as Diogenes being informed that ≈øome derided him,Plutarch.

Thirdly, it is another tricke of yours, in matters vnnece≈ø≈øary and of no moment to bee as loud as Stentor, but in things that very much pre≈ø≈øe you and call for ≈øati≈øfaction, to bee as mute as one po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with a dumbe ≈øpirit. And as cunning Cockma≈øters (di≈øtru≈øting the weakne≈ø≈øe of their Cocks) feed them with garlicke that yet they may annoy their aduer≈øaries with the ranckne≈ø≈øe of their breath: ≈øo you ≈øeeing by pure ≈øtrength of rea≈øon you were very vnlikely to preuaile again≈øt mee, you thought yet with the ≈øtincking breath of ≈ølanderous and opprobrious ≈øpeeches to mole≈øt and trouble mee. Fiftly and la≈øtly, it is your fa≈øhion not ≈øo much to care what you ≈øay, as how loudly you cry: hoping I thinke that as C. Marius ≈øometime ≈øaid,Valer. Max. l. 5. c. 2. that Lawes could not bee heard in time of warre becau≈øe of the clattering of armour, ≈øo neither ≈øhould the voice of truth bee heard in this di≈øpute by rea≈øon of your vociferation and clamorou≈øne≈ø≈øe. For thus you come vpon mee, How dare you deale thus, That you dare bee ≈øo bold, with what face can you accu≈øe, I tell you there is but one faith, I tell you it is ridiculous and bla≈øphemous, I tell you Faith is a knowledge, I tell you the promi≈øe is not conditionall, O hominis acumen & argumentum lepidum, O yee noble Schollers, Wo vnto you, You cannot e≈øcape Gods hand, Quite contrary is this to your knowledge and con≈øcience, Goe di≈øpute with Ie≈øus Chri≈øt and tell him his Father deliuereth a bla≈øphemous ab≈øurdity, All Fathers, all Writers, old and new, Greeke and Latin for 1600. yeeres, be≈øides many other ≈øuch peremptory and confident ≈øpeeches.In≈øtit. Orator. l 6. c. 5. Quintilian thought it ≈øcarce worthy to bee remembred in his In≈øtitutions, that his Orator bee not turbulent and tumultuous as are they who are vnlettered and therefore I maruell how you who would bee counted as wi≈øe as Thales, could forget your ≈øelfe ≈øo much as to imitate ba≈øe barri≈øters and pettifoggers. Saue only,Declam. 18. as the ≈øame Quintilian ≈øaith, it was nece≈ø≈øary to auouch with as much contention of voice as might bee, that which otherwi≈øe you could not proue: that what affirmation it could not haue from truth, it might receiue from your manner of ≈øpeaking. But Vanity, ≈øaith Saint Augu≈øtin, De ciuit. Dei l. 5. c. 27. is wonderfull talkatiue, yet is not therefore ≈øo powerfull as verity,
for if ≈øhee li≈øt ≈øhee can al≈øo bee lowder then verity. For the ≈øhallower the brooke the more the murmure, and the emptier the caske the greater the ≈øound. And therefore I would wi≈øh the Reader not to bee terrified with Torrents, Enar. in P≈ø. 57. as Saint Augu≈øtin ≈øpeaketh, who≈øe waters make a noi≈øe for a time, but pre≈øently will cea≈øe and cannot long continue. For doubtle≈ø≈øe if they of the hot and dry countreyes of Tema and Sabaea repaire hither in hope to ≈øatisfy and quench their thir≈øt,Iob. 6.19.20. they ≈øhall, as Iob ≈øaith, returne confounded and a≈øhamed, becau≈øe their brother hath deceiued them as a brooke, and as the ri≈øing of riuers which ≈øuddenly are dryed vp and faile out of their places.

Iudg. 16.17.The≈øe, Ma≈øter Baxter, are the Topicall places whence all your arguments are deduced, and if I may ≈øo ≈øay, the fiue locks wherein your chiefe≈øt ≈øtrength lyeth.
