Perhaps they that cannot di≈øcerne betweene Conicall and true gold, will bee content to receiue Lupins in≈øteed of currant money, and ≈øounding words for ≈øound proofes. And indeed it is the manner of the vnskilfull vulgar, though reiected and refu≈øed as mo≈øt incompetent, yet to beare them≈øelues as iudges in euery cau≈øe how weighty ≈øoeuer, and without taking any knowledge at all of the right i≈ø≈øue, to pronounce him ouercome that holds his peace, and him to haue an≈øwered that hath not held his peace, the controuer≈øie to bee doubtfull or undecidable if both parties haue ≈øayd alike much; whither ≈øide ≈øpeakes with more rea≈øon neither doe they attend, and if they doe yet can they not vnder≈øtand. And becau≈øe Vanity, De ciuit. Dei l. 5. c. 27. as wee haue ob≈øerued out of Saint Augu≈øtin, is euermore talkatiue then verity, and
hee ≈øeemeth vnto them to haue ≈øpoken be≈øt who hath ≈øaid mo≈øt; therefore doe they for the mo≈øt part giue ≈øentence again≈øt the truth for vaine talking. But how≈øoeuer ≈øimple and ignorant people may iudge, ≈øure I am they that are wi≈øe and learned, will e≈øteeme the cour≈øe you haue taken rather preiudiciall then any way auaileable vnto your cau≈øe. For ≈øhould a man, as Iob ≈øaith,Iob. 13.7. talke deceitfully for Gods cau≈øe? or is the ≈øtrength of truth ≈øo empaired that ≈øhee can no longer ≈øtand but by ≈øuch wrie and ≈øini≈øter meanes? Nay verily but ≈øhee is ≈øtill of ≈øo noble and hautie a nature that ≈øhee ≈øcorneth to haue her conque≈øts empeached by ≈øo ba≈øe and di≈øhonorable ≈øuccors. Deprauing of the aduer≈øaries words and meaning, impertinent digre≈ø≈øions, di≈ø≈øembling of his rea≈øons, and an≈øwers, vnchri≈øtian reuelling and reproaching, and tumultuous hoobubs and outcries, are the v≈øuall weapons of tho≈øe who re≈øolue to fight in vnrighteous quarels. But truth being pure and ≈øimple will not, and ≈øtanding firme vpon her owne ba≈øe needs not, and becau≈øe fal≈øhood hath no ≈øub≈øi≈øtence but only by her, cannot bee a≈ø≈øi≈øted and ≈øupported by ≈øuch vniu≈øt and fraudulent policies. Although therefore as I haue ≈øaid the≈øe meanes may bee forcible inough to ≈øeduce and beguile ≈øimple people, yet they that are wi≈øe and iudicious know that naked truth neuer comes di≈øgui≈øed, either in a Wolues or Foxes ca≈øe: but prudently di≈øcerning and ≈øeparating betwixt pa≈ø≈øionate ≈øpeeches and found rea≈øons, Rhetoricall flouri≈øhes and Logicall demon≈øtrations, vnnece≈ø≈øary circum≈øtances and ≈øub≈øtantiall matter, iudge alwayes of controuer≈øies not by what is confidently ≈øaid and affirmed, but by what is rea≈øonable alledged and proued. And who≈øoeuer thou bee Chri≈øtian Reader, that art in
this ≈øort affected and qualified,Deut. 33.8. Exod. 28.30. 2 Tim. 2.7.And thus, Ma≈øter Baxter, haue you at length my whole and entire Apologie, not importunately and violently wre≈øted from mee, as you ≈øay your An≈øwer was from you, but voluntarily of mine owne accord endited for the information and ≈øatisfaction of tho≈øe who earne≈øtly expect the i≈ø≈øue of this combat. Whereby the prudent and di≈øcreet Reader, and I hope your ≈øelfe al≈øo may perceiue how ≈ømall cau≈øe you had ≈øo vn≈øea≈øonably to ≈øing your Paean in your Prologue, and to trumpet out victory before you were entred in the li≈øts. rude. And yet I would haue you know that it is not ≈øo much your ignorance as your in≈øolency which I inueigh again≈øt. For,Yuo Viliomar. in Rob. Tit. as a late learned Humani≈øt writeth, There is no mortall man but is in ≈øome degree, tainted with ignorance, and this contagion haue wee drawne from mortality it ≈øelfe: for man when hee erreth, erreth becau≈øe hee is a man, and to vpbraid error in man is to reproch euen mortality in ≈øelfe. div.head: OF THE FAITH OF INFANTS, AND HOW THEY ARE Iu≈øtified and Saued.
div.p:
THat Chri≈øtian Infants haue a particular Faith of their owne, is generally affirmed both by Papists and Lutherans: yet with ≈øome difference,De Bapt. l. 1. c. 10. as Bellarmine writeth. For Papists hold that they haue onely Habituall Faith, and that it (together with Hope and Charity) is infu≈øed into them in the Sacrament of Bapti≈øme: but the Lutherans, ≈øaith he, attribute vnto them Actuall Faith, or ≈øomething like thereunto.
Wherein it may be the Cardinall doth them ≈øome wrong.Field Append. part. 2. ¬ß. 1. For it is ob≈øerued by ≈øome Diuines, that they con≈øtantly deny Children to haue any actuall apprehen≈øion of Gods mercies, or that they feele in them≈øelues any ≈øuch motions of Faith. Whereupon it mu≈øt needs follow; that their meaning is not to attribute vnto them Actuall Faith, but a kind of Habituall Faith onely, or that ≈øeed, root and Habit, whence Actuall motions in due time doe flow. But bee their opinion herein what≈øoeuer it will bee, ≈øure I am that both Lutheran and Papist agree in this, that Infants haue a particular Faith of their owne.

The principall rea≈øons that they alledge for proofe hereof are the≈øe.Heb. 11.6. Infants plea≈øe God: but without Faith, it is impo≈øsible to plea≈øe him. Mat. 19.14. The Kingdome of God belongs vnto them: Which yet the Scriptures ≈øay cannot be attained without Faith. Mar. 9.36. Luc. 1.41. Nay Chri≈øt him≈øelfe expre≈øly ≈øaith that they doe belieue. And Iohn the Bapti≈øt in the very wombe of his Mother was filled with the Holy Gho≈øt, and ≈øprang at the ≈øalutation of the Ble≈ø≈øed Virgin. Other arguments they v≈øe, but they are all of the like nature, and notwith≈øtanding them all, I cannot bee per≈øwaded that Infants while they are ≈øuch, haue any Faith of their owne either Actuall or Habituall. And the≈øe among ≈øundry others are my chiefe≈øt rea≈øons.

Deut. 1.39.Fir≈øt, the Scripture in plaine tearmes affirmeth, that they haue no knowledge at all, either of good or euill:

que ≈øermonis ≈øuperet euidentia veritatis: that is, If wee ≈øhould goe about to demon≈øtrate with words that Children know the things of God, who as yet know not the things of men, I feare wee ≈øhould offer wrong euen to our very ≈øen≈øes endeuouring to per≈øwade by ≈øpeech that, the euidence of the truth whereof far exceeds all power and office of ≈øpeech.

Secondly, when Infants are pre≈øented at the holy Font, and either ≈øprinkled with the water of Bapti≈øme, or dipped therein: how chanceth it that they ≈øo much di≈ølike thereof, te≈øtifying their di≈ølike by their crying and other motion of the body? Certainly, had they actuall Faith, they would endure all with much patience and cheerefulne≈ø≈øe, and neuer bewray ≈øo much aduer≈øene≈ø≈øe and di≈øcontent. But if in doing ≈øo they goe again≈øt their knowledge, the Sacrament mu≈øt needs bee ≈øo f ‚Ä¢ rre from auailing them to the wa≈øhing away of Originall guilt, that by their reluctation they rather contract a further guilt of Actuall ≈øinne, which I ≈øuppo≈øe none except he be too too vncharitable will imagine of them.

For if a iu≈øt and hone≈øt man would, much more will God performe his Word and Couenant, although the ≈øeale be not ≈øet thereunto. But if it may bee had, there is Nece≈øsitas praecepti, a nece≈ø≈øity laid by Gods commandement vpon all tho≈øe that are Filij praecepti the Sonnes of the commandement. Tho≈øe Sonnes all men are when they are grown to be Adulti; and therefore if then they neglect
to be baptized, they de≈øerue for their contempt to bee cut off and to bee eternally condemned. But Infants while ≈øuch are none of the≈øe Sonnes, as being both vncapable of the precept, and vnable to offer them≈øelues vnto the Sacrament: whence followeth that the commandement taketh hold onely of the Parents, and tho≈øe that haue the care of them. So that although the Child dying vnbaptized may bee free from danger: yet tho≈øe that neglect to pre≈øent him vnto Bapti≈øme ≈øhall bee damned for breach of Gods commandement. Le ‚Ä¢
Parents therefore by all meanes bee carefull to performe this duty: and if by rea≈øon of weakene≈ø≈øe or ≈øome other impediment it cannot bee done publickely, rather then left vndone, let it bee done priuatly. Wi≈øe men, and among≈øt the re≈øt M. Caluin would haue it ≈øo: yea the Church of England requireth it, pre≈øcribing a forme of Priuate Bapti≈øme, in ca≈øe of nece≈ø≈øity, and commanding that what is priuatly done be by the Mini≈øter publickely made knowne in the Congregation. An order heretofore too much neglected, God grant henceforward it may be better ob≈øerued.

Finally and la≈øtly, ≈øeeing euery one that is Adultus mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity haue a Faith of his owne, fir≈øt it is the duty of Parents by all meanes to worke Faith in their Children when they are capable thereof: that as they haue beene in≈øtruments to traduce Originall ≈øinne vnto them to their perdition, ≈øo they may againe repaire in them the image of God to their eternall ≈øaluation. Secondly, let euery one looke to him≈øelfe, and ≈øee that hee haue Faith, for it is in vaine to tru≈øt to the Faith of another. The righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øt indeed is a cloke large enough to couer the ≈øinnes of all men: but the Faith of
another man is little enough for him≈øelfe, I cannot couer my nakedne≈ø≈øe with it. They were but fooli≈øh virgins that ≈øaid, Giue vs of your oile, for our lamps are out: and fitly were they an≈øwered by the wi≈øe virgins, Wee feare there will not bee enough for vs and you, but goe yee rather to them that ≈øell and buy for your ≈øelues. Let Papi≈øts bla≈øpheme and ≈øay, they can ≈øupererogate and more then ≈øatisfy for their ≈øinnes, and that one man may for a price buy out of the Popes trea≈øury the Surplus of another mans merits: yet am I ≈øure the oile of another mans lampe will not ≈øerue my turne, nor procure mee fauour to enter with the bridegroome. div.p: Written by the occa≈øion of a conference had with Mr. Bayly, by the late Reuerend and Learned Diuine, Ma≈øter Iohn Downe, Bachelour of Diuinity, and ≈øometimes Fellow of Emanuell Colledge in Cambridge.

div.head: NOT CONSENT OF FATHERS BVT SCRIPTVRE THE GROVND OF FAITH.
div.p:
LOVING and Reuerend M. Bayly, I acknowledge my ≈øelfe much endebted vnto you, both for my kind entertainment, and the peaceable Conference I had with you. Would you but vouch≈øafe to vi≈øit my poore Cottage, I ≈øhould readily endeauour to ≈øatisfy ≈øome part of the debt, if not with like entertainment, yet with equall
welcome. The re≈øidue I know not how better to di≈øcharge, then by pur≈øuing my fir≈øt intention; that is, by labouring to reduce you backe into the bo≈øome of that Church, out of which with ≈øuch danger to your ≈øoule, ≈øcandall to the brethren, and vnkindne≈ø≈øe to her you haue withdrawne your ≈øelfe. And to this end might I haue obtained from you in writing, as at our parting I entreated, what tho≈øe ≈øpeciall Motiues were which had wrought in you this ≈øudden change: I would haue ≈øtrained my ≈øelfe by writing al≈øo to haue giuen them the be≈øt ≈øatisfaction. But ≈øeeing for rea≈øons be≈øt knowne to your ≈øelfe, and into which I li≈øt not further to inquire, you held it not fit as then to yeeld ≈øo farre vnto mee: I haue thought good for the pre≈øent to reflect vpon ≈øome pa≈ø≈øages of our Conference, ≈øpecially that ground whereon you then ≈øtood ≈øo much, and vpon which you plainely profe≈ø≈øed that you would aduenture your Faith.

It may plea≈øe you therefore to remember that being demaunded a rea≈øon of your departure, you pretended that in reading the ancient Fathers you had met with ≈øundry Bugbeares, which ≈øo ≈øcared and affrighted you, that vnle≈ø≈øe you would re≈øi≈øt the light of Con≈øcience, and hazard your eternall ≈øaluation, you could not chu≈øe but bee ≈øwayed by them. Whereunto it being replied, that happily tho≈øe Bugbeares were but Scarcrowes, and that you ≈øhould haue taken a ≈øafer and ≈øurer cour≈øe, if you had re≈øolued your Faith into Scriptures, nothing being ≈øufficient to beare vp ≈øo weighty a peece but onely diuine te≈øtimony: your an≈øwer was that vpon Scripture you relyed, howbeit, becau≈øe it is ob≈øcure and ≈øubiect to manifold con≈øtructions, vpon Scripture vnder≈øtood according to the interpretation and doctrine of the Fathers,
nothing doubting but that as long as you held the Faith of them whom wee verily belieue to bee ≈øaued, your ≈øelfe could neuer peri≈øh through misbeliefe. In which an≈øwer, how≈øoeuer in word you ≈øeeme to attribute ≈øome force and vertue to the Scriptures, yet in truth you doe but cancell them and make them of none effect. For if the Scriptures lie rather in the Sen≈øe then in the Letter, and the Sen≈øe by rea≈øon of the darkne≈ø≈øe and ambiguity of them, bee not to bee found in them≈øelues, but el≈øewhere out of them, in the writings of the Fathers: it followeth clearely that in your account Paul and Peter and Iames and Iohn and the other Pen-men of holy writ are no better then Cyphers, vnle≈ø≈øe Cyrill and Ambro≈øe and Hierome and Augustin and the re≈øt of that ranke as digit numbers vouch≈øafe to adde ≈øome value and ≈øignification vnto them. So that now by your fauor this mu≈øt bee my taske briefly and plainely to demon≈øtrate, that hauing remoued your Faith from the authority of Scripture vpon the expo≈øition of the Fathers, you haue built quite be≈øide the rocke, and layd your foundation vpon the ≈øand.

But take this prote≈øtation fir≈øt, that wee neither di≈øe≈øteeme nor de≈øpi≈øe the Fathers, as by Prie≈øts and Ie≈øuites wee are ordinarily ≈ølandered: but contrarywi≈øe, with all duty wee ri≈øe vp to their gray haires, and reuerence their venerable antiquity. Withall wee acknowledge that they were in their times excellent ornaments and lights of the Church, endued not onely with ≈øingular knowledge in the my≈øtery of Faith, but al≈øo with admirable ≈øanctity and vprightne≈ø≈øe of life. Whereby, in all their combats and bickerins with Hereticks, they maintained the truth of God ≈øo wi≈øely and couragiou≈øly,
that they euer remained more then conquerors. And now as they haue left behind them a pretious name among the Saints ≈øo wee doubt not but their ≈øoules are bound vp in the bundle of life, and enioy the ble≈ø≈øed: making vi≈øion of God for euermore. Such books of theirs as are come to our hands we e≈øteeme as rich trea≈øures, and value them aboue gold. Them doe wee ≈øearch and peru≈øe with all diligence: bee it ≈øpoken without offence, no Papi≈øts more. Yet can wee not throughout them meet with tho≈øe terrible Bugbears you ≈øo much complain of: rather wee wonder how you could mi≈ø≈øe all tho≈øe good Angels ≈øo frequently appearing in them to comfirme and ≈øettle you in your fir≈øt Faith. For I wil bee bold to ≈øay, notwith≈øtanding all the brags and crakes of that ≈øide, that the Fathers are ours not yours: or if they bee yours in any thing, it is in the pettie≈øt and ≈ømalle≈øt matters, for in the maine and great que≈øtions controuerted between vs, they are expre≈øly for vs and again≈øt you, as hereafter God willing ≈øhall in part appeare. Vpon confidence whereof, when≈øoeuer wee were ≈øummond and called vnto the Fathers by you, wee neuer refu≈øed their triall, but euer haue beene ready to aduenture all vpon their verdict. The chalenge of that famous Prelate, Ser. at Pauls Cro≈ø≈øe. Doctor Iewell Bi≈øhop of Salisbury, is yet fre≈øh in memory, that if any learned man of our aduer≈øaries, or if all the learned men that bee aliue, be able to bring any one ≈øufficient ≈øentence out of any old Catholicke Doctor or Father, or out of any old generall Councell, or out of the holy Scriptures of God, or any one example of the Primitiue Church, whereby it may clearly and plainly be proued, that there was any priuate Ma≈ø≈øe in the whole world at that time for the ≈øpace of ≈øixe hundred yeares after
Chri≈øt, and ≈øo foorth in ≈øeuen and twenty ≈øeuerall articles, hee would bee content to yeeld and to ≈øub≈øcribe. Reply to Hardings An≈ø. This chalenge as that renowned Bi≈øhop in his life-time made good him≈øelfe again≈øt his aduer≈øary Ma≈øter Harding: ≈øo was it neuer yet retracted by any of vs, but hath ≈øtoutly beene maintained by ≈øundry ≈øucceeding champions. Heare one for all. That, ≈øayth worthy Whitaker, Con. Camp. tat. 5. which Iewell mo≈øt truly and constantly vttered that day when hee appealed to the antiquity of ≈øixe hundred yeeres, and offered vnto you that if you could bring foorth but one ≈øentence cleere and euident, out of any Father or Councell, he would not refu≈øe to yeeld the victory vnto you: the ≈øame doe we all profe≈øse, we all promi≈øe the ≈øame, we will not ≈øhrinke from our word. Thus you ≈øee how wee reiect not the Fathers, as you would beare the world in hand, but triumph rather in the te≈øtimony they giue vs, and in our Apologies and Defences alledge them plentifully again≈øt you.

Howbeit neither doe wee nor dare wee make Gods of them, or equall them with the holy Apo≈øtles, as if they were infallible and could not erre. Clouen tongues neuer ≈øate vpon them, as they did vpon the≈øe: neither did the Spirit of God ≈øo guide and direct their pens, but that ≈øometimes they might faile, and write ami≈ø≈øe. Had they had infallibility of iudgement, ≈øafely might wee build our Faith vpon them: but this they vtterly di≈øclaime, acknowledging it to bee the peculiar priuiledge of the Apo≈øtles. And ≈øo far are they from making them≈øelues Ma≈øters of our Faith, that they require vs to iudge and cen≈øure of their writings by the Scripture which is the rule of Faith. Neither would they haue vs to tie our ≈øelues vnto their authority more then they tyed them≈øelues vnto the authority of others but freely to accept
or refu≈øe as wee ≈øee iu≈øt cau≈øe.Hom. 13. in 2. Cor. I pray and be≈øeech you all, ≈øaith Chry≈øostome, that leauing this and that mans opinion, you will ≈øearch all the≈øe things out of the Scripture. In Eu≈øeb. hi≈øt. l. 7. c. 24. Let it bee commended, ≈øaith Diony≈øius of Alexandria, and without enuy a≈ø≈øented vnto which is rightly ≈øpoken: but if any thing bee vn≈øoundly written, let that bee looked into and corrected. Epi≈øt. 62. I know I my ≈øelfe, ≈øaith Hierome, esteeme of the Apo≈øtles in one ≈øort, and of other Writers in another: that the fir≈øt alwayes ≈øpeake truth, and the latter as men doe in ≈øome things erre. De Trinit. l. 3. c. 1. In all my writings, ≈øaith Saint Augu≈øtin, I de≈øire not only a godly Reader, but al≈øo a free corrector: yet as I would haue the Reader addicted vnto mee, ≈øo neither would I haue a corrector addicted to him≈øelfe. De lib. arb. l. 2. c. 32. And againe, I am not bound to the authority of this man, meaning Cyprian, but I examine his ≈øaying by the authority of Scripture, and what agreeth therewith I receiue with his commendation: what agreeth not, by his leaue I refu≈øe. And yet againe,Epi≈øt. 111. ad Fortunat. Neither are wee to e≈øteeme the di≈øputations of any men although Catholicke and prai≈øe worthy as the Canonicall Scriptures, that wee may not ≈øauing the honour which is due to tho≈øe men di≈ølike and reiect ≈øomething in their writings, if happily wee find them to haue thought otherwi≈øe then the truth either by others or our ≈øelues through Gods help vnderstood. Such am I in the writings of others, and ≈øuch would I haue the vnder≈øtanders of mine to bee. Epi≈øt. 19. ad Hieron. Finally, I, ≈øaith the ≈øame Saint Augu≈øtin, confe≈øse vnto your charity, that I haue learned to yeeld vnto tho≈øe books of Scripture alone, which now are called Canonicall, this reuerence and honor, that I mo≈øt firmely belieue no Author of them to haue erred any thing in writing: And if I find any thing in their writings which ≈øeemeth contrary to truth, I will not ≈øticke to ≈øay, that either, the copie is
faulty, or the tran≈ølator apprehended not what is ≈øpoken, or I vnderstand it not. But others I ≈øo read, that how much ≈øoeuer they excell in holyne≈ø≈øe and learning, I thinke it not therefore true becau≈øe they thought ≈øo, but becau≈øe either by tho≈øe Canonicall Authors, or by probable rea≈øon not abhorring from truth they were able to per≈øwade mee. Thus the Fathers: who≈øe ≈øteps if wee tread in, and who≈øe coun≈øell if wee follow, and not taking vp euery thing vpon tru≈øt, but examining them by the touch≈øtone of truth, I hope wee are rather to bee commended then blamed.

And rea≈øon: for neither were the Fathers more then men, neither are wee of this age le≈ø≈øe then men. And I wonder, why we may not iudge of the ≈øayings of tho≈øe, who are but men as well as our ≈øelues. What? haue wee not rea≈øonable ≈øoules as well as they? are we not endued with the ≈øame faculty of vnder≈øtanding and di≈øcour≈øing? haue wee not ≈øtill the ≈øame helps both of nature and art which they had? Or when they died, did the Holy Gho≈øt al≈øo giue vp the gho≈øt with them? or doth hee deny to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the≈øe latter times with his enlightning grace as hee did the former?Ioh. 16.13. Certainly the Spirit that leadeth into all truth is yet, and euer ≈øhall bee among≈øt vs vnto the end of the world. And as before the writings of the Fathers were, hee directed his Church vnto the true ≈øence of Scripture: ≈øo now I doubt not but if all what≈øoeuer they haue written were vtterly lo≈øt, he would ≈øtill guide vs therein as hee did them. And verily vnle≈ø≈øe wee will bee too vnthankfull wee cannot but confe≈ø≈øe, that as age through Gods bounty hath had more meanes then tho≈øe heretofore: ≈øo through his ble≈ø≈øing it hath made further proceedings al≈øo in the knowledge of Scripture. For be≈øides
that wee haue what≈øoeuer helps they had, we haue ouer and aboue the benefit of all their works, together with much skilfulnes in the Originall of the old Te≈øtament, which mo≈øt of them wanted, and of the new al≈øo, wherewith ≈øome were but little acquainted. In regard whereof who≈øoeuer ≈øhall duly compare the ancient Commentaries with tho≈øe of latter times, mu≈øt needs bee either weake in iudgement, or ob≈øtinate in preiudice if hee preferre not the≈øe. Your owne men ingenuou≈øly acknowledge ≈øo much.Art. 18. cont. Luther. It cannot bee vnknowne to any, ≈øaith Fi≈øher B. of Roche≈øter, that there are many things as well in other Scriptures as the Go≈øpels now more cleerely di≈øcu≈øsed and throughly vnder≈øtood then in ancient times: namely becau≈øe the Ancients had not the yce broken vnto them, or becau≈øe their age ≈øufficed not exactly to ≈øound the whole ≈øea of Scripture. In Rom. 5. di≈øp. 51. And Salmeron, God hath not giuen to all men all, that euery age might enioy ≈øome truths which the former knew not. Euery age hath euer a≈øcribed much to antiquity: yet this wee auouch, the yonger the Doctors the cleerer ≈øighted. And Dominicus Bannes, Jt is not nece≈øsary that the more remote the Church is from the Apostles times, the le≈øse perfect knowledge of the my≈øterie of Faith ≈øhould bee therein: becau≈øe after the Apo≈øtles time there were not the most learned in the Church which had dexterity in vnder≈øtanding the matters of Faith. Wee are not therefore enwrapped in the more darkne≈øse, for that in re≈øpect of time wee are more distant from Christ: but rather the Doctors of the≈øe latter times being godly, and treading in the ≈øteps of the ancient Fathers haue attained more expre≈øse vnder≈øtanding in ≈øome things then they had. For they are like children ≈øtanding on the ≈øhoulders of Giants, who being lifted by the talne≈ø≈øe of Giants, no maruell

This ≈øimilitude Stella al≈øo v≈øeth to the ≈øame purpo≈øe, God forbid, ≈øaith he that I ≈øhould condemne what ≈øuch and ≈øo many wi≈øe men haue with one accord affirmed yet wee know well that Pigmies ≈øet on the ≈øhoulders of Giants, ≈øee further then the Giants them≈øelues doe. Thus they. Whereby you ≈øee the Fathers haue no prerogatiue aboue vs, becau≈øe they were before vs: but wee rather haue the aduantage becau≈øe wee come after them. In a word, bee they what≈øoeuer you will, their ≈øeruants wee are not, but their fellow ≈øeruants: ≈øent from God with the ≈øame commi≈ø≈øion, to the ≈øame end, and with the ≈øame promi≈øes that they were. The ancient Fathers ≈øay you, are the ground of your Faith. What? ≈øeuerally and ≈øingle by them≈øelues?
„Äà‚óä„Äâ 12. I ≈øuppo≈øe no: for there is not one of them, as your owne ≈øide confe≈ø≈øeth, but hath his error, and I pre≈øume you would bee loth to follow them therein. The Fathers therefore, either all iointly, or the more part of them agreeing in one. So Canus, Loc. lib. 7. c. 3. ‚Ä¢ ea an infallible rule iudging. And Onuphrius, Prim. Pap. p. 1. c. 6. the vnanimous con≈øent of the Fathers. This then vndoubtedly being your a≈ø≈øertion, as euery way according with the Tenet of the Church of Rome, let vs in Gods name trie the ≈øtrength thereof, and ≈øee with what ≈øecurity and ≈øafety a man may aduenture his Faith, and con≈øequently his eternall ≈øaluation vpon this ground.

And fir≈øt, who≈øoeuer will ≈øtedfa≈øtly repo≈øe his Faith vpon con≈øent of Fathers, had need be right well a≈ø≈øured which are the authenticall writings of the Fathers. Nor Origen, nor Athana≈øius, nor Ba≈øil, nor Chry≈øo≈øtome, nor Cyril, nor Tertullian, nor Cyprian, nor Ambro≈øe, nor Hier ‚Ä¢ me, nor Augu≈øtin, nor any one almo≈øt of all the Fathers, but hath ≈øuffered notorious wrong in this kind, hauing ba≈øe brats and misbegotten ba≈øtards fathered vpon him. Which al≈øo is ≈øo cleere and manife≈øt, that Po≈ø≈øeuin, and Salmeron, and Maldonat, and Baronius, and Bellarmine, and all the re≈øt of that ≈øide, though too frequently they make v≈øe of ≈øuch refu≈øe ≈øtuffe, yet euery where in their writings are con≈øtrained to acknowledge ≈øo much.Biblioth. l. 4. But among≈øt the re≈øt Sixtus Senen≈øis e≈øpecially, who purpo≈øely recording the works of all the Fathers, taketh vpon him to demon≈øtrate as much in euery one of them, as in his Catalogue hee pa≈ø≈øeth from one Father to another. Only, becau≈øe in our Conference you ≈øo confidently affirmed that Diony≈øius the Areopagite, euen he who was Saint Pauls conuert and Scholler, was the right Author of all tho≈øe books that are now extant vnder his name: I mu≈øt entreat you to haue a little patience, while I maintaine again≈øt you the negatiue which I then held, and for which I ≈øtand ≈øtill engaged vnto you.

That this Deni≈øe is but a counterfait, but Diuines proue by ≈øundry vnan≈øwerable arguments: I will not vrge them all, but cull out the choice≈øt. Omitting therefore the Stile ≈øauouring more of three hundred yeeres after, then tho≈øe Apo≈øtolicall times, and his curious ≈øpeculations in the ≈øecrets of heauen, as if hee had beene ≈øurueyer thereof, or had taken a mu≈øter of all the heauenly ho≈øte of the ble≈ø≈øed. Spirits therein, whereas Saint Paul him≈øelfe though hee had beene raui≈øhed vp into the third heauen, euen into the Paradi≈øe of God,2 Cor. 12.3.4. yet returning backe neyther dur≈øt nor did vtter any ≈øuch thing, and la≈øtly that hee talken ≈øo familiarly of Churches and Chancels and Monks and diuers other orders and ceremonies which are well knowne to be of a much latter date: omitting I ≈øay the≈øe and the like obiections, although perhaps not ≈øo ea≈øy to bee an≈øwered, con≈øider with mee I be≈øeech you the≈øe few rea≈øons following. Fir≈øt, if the≈øe were the books of that Den ‚Ä¢

Secondly, to bani≈øh Con≈øequences from Diuinity, is to bani≈øh the v≈øe of right rea≈øon and di≈øcour≈øe al≈øo: and that religion mu≈øt needs bee driuen to narrow ≈øhifts, which cannot ≈øub≈øi≈øt vnle≈ø≈øe men turne fooles or bea≈øts. Thirdly, the nece≈ø≈øity of a Con≈øequence doth not any way depend vpon the per≈øon of him that inferreth it, but onely vpon the mutuall relation and ≈øtrait coniunction betweene the premi≈ø≈øes and it: ≈øo that by him who de≈øires to bee ≈øatisfied in the truth, not the per≈øon of him that deduceth it, but the Con≈øequence it ≈øelfe is to bee looked too, whether it bee rightly deduced or no. But who ≈øhall iudge that will you ≈øay? Indeed if you ≈øtand re≈øolued vtterly to renounce all the helps and directions both of rea≈øon and art, nor will yeeld to any Con≈øequence of Scripture how cleere and euident ≈øoeuer, but will only rely on the mouth and ≈øentence of your humane externall Iudge: I confe≈ø≈øe I am at Dulkarnon, to v≈øe Chaucers phra≈øe, and you are pa≈øt my skill infallibly to per≈øwade you. But if, as wee haue
≈øhewed, nor Scripture nor Fathers acknowledge ≈øuch a Iudge, if all what≈øoeuer is nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øaluation bee ≈øo plainely laid downe in Scripture as a man of meane capacity may vnder≈øtand it, if what is more ob≈øcurely deliuered in one place is more plainely expre≈ø≈øed in another, if God haue appointed that out of the plainer places wee ≈øhould with ≈øtudy and indu≈øtrie picke the meaning of tho≈øe that are harder, if hee haue promi≈øed that tho≈øe that aske ≈øhall haue, tho≈øe that ≈øeeke ≈øhall find, and to tho≈øe that knocke it ≈øhall bee opened, if finally though wee mi≈ø≈øe the true meaning of tho≈øe harder places, yet firmely adhering vnto the plainer, wee are ≈øafe and out of danger: then certainely the readie≈øt and ≈øure≈øt way to to interpret Scripture is by Scripture, and there is no other way to determine controuer≈øies and to ≈øatisfy the con≈øcience but onely this. If any notwith≈øtanding this li≈øt ≈øtill to bee contentious,1. Cor. 11. Wee, ≈øaith S. Paul haue no ≈øuch cu≈øtome, nor the Churches of God. The rule it ≈øelfe is infallible and al-≈øufficient: if wee either through ignorance cannot, or through negligence doe not v≈øe it as we ought, the fault is not in God, but in our ≈øelues, neither doth hee faile in his prouidence, but wee in our dutie. In nece≈ø≈øaries hee will neuer faile: if in other things all be not of one mind, yet let vs ≈øtill proceed by the ≈øame rule, and in≈øtruct one another in the ≈øpirit of meekne≈ø≈øe, and God will reueale that al≈øo in due time.

And now, M. Bayly, you haue what I intended for the pre≈øent: it remaines that you peru≈øe it attentiuely. The ≈øumme is. The Fathers may be Mini≈øters by whom you belieue, but their Con≈øent is no ground of Faith. Your

To tru≈øt anothers application of it for you, and that in the point of ≈øaluation, is not Chri≈øtian mode≈øtie, but meere childi≈øhne≈ø≈øe, and fooli≈øh credulity. Remember what Lactantius ≈øaith, It behoueth a man, Div. In≈øtit. l. 2. c. 8. ≈øpecially in that thing wherein the ≈øtate of our life con≈øi≈øteth, to tru≈øt him≈øelfe, and to rely vpon his own iudgement and vnder≈øtanding for finding out & examining the truth, rather then belieuing anothers errors to be deceiued, as if him≈øelfe were void of rea≈øon. God hath giuen to all men ≈øome portion of wi≈øedome, whereby they may both find out what they haue not heard, and examine what they haue heard. This gift of God, this Wi≈ødome I meane, and illumination of Gods Spirit, v≈øe I be≈øeech you to the glory of the donour, and the building of your ≈øelfe vp in your mo≈øt holy Faith. This you ≈øhall doe, if ≈øhaking off this blind beliefe of the dictates and decrees of men, you ≈øimply and ab≈øolutely yeeld all credence to God alone & his word,
and to men no otherwi≈øe then vnder God, and for God. For as the ≈øame Lactantius ≈øaith, with who≈øe words I conclude, Wi≈ødome and Religion are ≈øo neerely ioyned together, Ib. l. 4. c. 4. & 1. c. 1. that they may not bee ≈øeuered one from the other: in ≈øo much as neither any religion is to bee embraced without wi≈ødome, nor any wi≈ødome to be approued without religion. The Lord giue you a cleane heart, and renew within you a right Spirit: ≈øo prayeth for you from the bottome of his heart,

div.head: OF SITTING AND KNEELING AT THE COMMVNION.
div.p:
VNTO the ≈øchedule you ≈øent mee, contayning your be≈øt rea≈øons for Sitting again≈øt Kneeling, I here returne you this ≈øhort an≈øwer. Your end doubtle≈ø≈øe was by ≈øtrength of argument to withdraw mee from conformity in Kneeling: my intent is, by di≈øcouering the weakne≈ø≈øe of your arguments, to worke you from ≈øingularity in Sitting. The i≈ø≈øue I leaue vnto God: yet I tru≈øt that as my per≈øua≈øion and example this la≈øt Ea≈øter, as you know, reduced diuers, ≈øo my Reply through the ble≈ø≈øing of God may al≈øo reclaime
you. God grant that being brethren, and children of one common mother: wee may with one accord ob≈øerue her orders, and honor her authority.

Your writing fir≈øt maintaines ≈øitting, then oppo≈øes kneeling. Of ≈øitting you affirme thus, Wee ought to ≈øit at the receiuing of the Elements of the Lords Supper. In which Propo≈øition I doubt of one tearme, and ≈øu≈øpect another. The tearme I doubt of is this, Wee ought to ≈øit, namely what you meane thereby. For if either the nature of the Phra≈øe, or the Conclu≈øion of your third Syllogi≈øme may determine it, then is it equiualent vnto this, We mu≈øt ≈øit, & imports a nece≈ø≈øity of ≈øitting, or that ≈øitting is the only lawful I ge≈øture. But if we iudge thereof by the probable intention of the two fir≈øt Syllogi≈ømes, then the meaning thereof ≈øeemes to bee no more then this, We may ≈øit, or ≈øitting is a lawfull ge≈øture. In which ≈øence now vnder≈øtand you this Propo≈øition? In the fir≈øt? Then I deny it, and ≈øay Sitting is not the onely lawfull ge≈øture. In the ≈øecond? Then I an≈øwer two things. Fir≈øt you haue ill expre≈øt your ≈øelfe, v≈øing words that beare not your meaning: for Wee ought, imports a nece≈ø≈øary duty, and Wee may, free choice and liberty. Secondly I di≈øtingui≈øh. For if you vnder≈øtand it Ab≈øolutely and Simply in it ≈øelfe, then I grant Wee may ≈øit, for ≈øitting is indifferent and ≈øo there ≈øhall bee no controuer≈øie betwixt vs. But if you vnder≈øtand it re≈øpectiuely and with regard vnto the Canons and con≈øtitutions of the Church, then I ≈øay wee may not ≈øit: for the Church, vnto whom wee owe obedience, hath ordained otherwi≈øe.

Againe, I ≈øu≈øpect tho≈øe words, at the receiuing of the Elements of the Lords Supper: for why doe you not ≈øay rather, at the receiuing of the Body and Blood of our Lord
and Sauiour Ie≈øus Chri≈øt? e≈øpecially ≈øeeing this is the nobler part of the Sacrament, and the Elements are but ≈øhadowes of this ≈øub≈øtance. Was it, le≈øt ≈øitting might ≈øeeme too perfunctory, and kneeling neuer a whit too reuerent for ≈øo ≈øacred an action? If ≈øo, then are you guilty of no ≈ømall fault, thus to ≈øleight the holy Sacrament for ≈øo poore an aduantage. But perhaps it was done out of ≈øimplicity, rather then cunning. Howbeit taking vpon you to play the Logician and to di≈øpute Syllogi≈øtically, you ought to haue been more wary of your tearmes.
