q.p: 1 A comely ge≈øture ought to be v≈øed. 1 Cor. 14.40.
Sitting is a comely ge≈øture; (for the affection of ioy mu≈øt then bee ≈øtirred vp, with which it agrees. Mar. 14.22, 23, 24, 25, 26. Ergo, ≈øitting ought to bee v≈øed.

div.p:
This is rather a Paralogi≈øme then Syllogi≈øme: for the Propo≈øitions are indefinite, and of no quantity, and out of ≈øuch Propo≈øitions nothing can Logically bee concluded. But I will help to rectify your Syllogi≈øme, if fir≈øt I may know what you would conclude. The Conclu≈øion mu≈øt needs bee one of two, either this, Wee may ≈øit, or this, Wee mu≈øt ≈øit. Would you conclude, Wee may ≈øit, in the ≈øence aboue denied? (for ≈øo you ought), Then mu≈øt it thus bee formed, Any comely gesture may be v≈øed notwith≈øtanding the Churches ordinance: ≈øitting is a comely ge≈øture: Ergo, ≈øitting may bee v≈øed notwithstanding the Churches ordinance. But ≈øo the Maior is vntrue. For Magi≈øtrates haue authority to order things indifferent, as
they find it expedient, to auoid confu≈øion, and to ≈øettle an vniformity: and wee are bound not onely for feare, but al≈øo for Con≈øcience to obey.Rom. 13.5. Neither doth the pa≈ø≈øage you quote for proofe of your Maior, euince the contrary. For Saint Paul commanding that all things bee done decently, permitteth not euery one to v≈øe his liberty as hee li≈øteth,In. 1. Cor. 14.40. but ≈øetteth bounds vnto vs rather, as Caluin ≈øaith & e≈øtabli≈øheth the lawfull orders of the Church: ≈øeeing it cannot bee decent to affront authority, and doe as we plea≈øe.

But it may bee you would conclude that wee mu≈øt ≈øit, or that ≈øitting is the onely lawfull ge≈øture. Then mu≈øt your argument bee thus framed, A comely ge≈øture onely is to bee v≈øed: ≈øitting onely is comely: Ergo, ≈øitting onely is to bee v≈øed. The Maior whereof I grant, and acknowledge to bee ≈øufficiently prooued; but I deny the Minor. For if ≈øitting bee the onely comely ge≈øture, then is not onely the Church of England to bee condemned for kneeling, but ≈øundry other reformed Churches al≈øo for ≈øtanding, yea our Sauiour him≈øelfe with all his Apo≈øtles, who (as in due place ≈øhall bee demon≈øtrated) ≈øate not: to ≈øay nothing, that it is your ≈øingular opinion, and that the man cannot bee named who held the ≈øame before you, or holds it be≈øides you.

For as for your rea≈øon, that ≈øitting agrees with the affection of ioy, which then must bee ≈øtirred vp, it is a very ≈øtrange and vnrea≈øonable one. For fir≈øt, bee it that ioy mu≈øt then bee ≈øtirred vp: ≈øo mu≈øt humility, reuerence, thankfulne≈ø≈øe al≈øo. And therefore if ≈øitting beecomely becau≈øe it agreeth with the one: Kneeling al≈øo is comely, becau≈øe it agreeth with the other. Againe, ≈øuppo≈øe that ≈øitting agree with Ioy: ≈øo doth leaping, dancing, exultation
al≈øo. Why then if Sitting by vertue of this agreement be comely, are not the re≈øt in like manner comely? La≈øtly, that Sitting is the embleme of Re≈øt and that ≈øuch po≈øture of the body is fit for ≈øtudy, coun≈øell, meditation, I haue often heard: and ≈øo much is meant by tho≈øe old ≈øayings, The Romans conquer by ≈øitting, and By ≈øitting men become wi≈øe. But how it agreeth with the affection of ioy, neither doe you ≈øhew it, neither can you: and therefore I leaue it as a fancy, vnkith vnki≈øt, as they ≈øay, and pa≈ø≈øe to your ≈øecond argument, which you conceiue in this forme.

q.p: 2 Ge≈øture according to order mu≈øt be v≈øed. 1 Cor. 14.40. Sitting is an orderly ge≈øture: for Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles ≈øate, ≈øo did the Iewes al≈øo eating the Pa≈øseouer.

div.p:
This argument is euery way twin vnto the former, and in a manner needs no other an≈øwer then is already giuen. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, for fuller ≈øatisfaction let vs examine both the Propo≈øitions. The Maior being rightly vnder≈øtood I grant: for no ge≈øture may be v≈øed but that which is orderly, it being the Apo≈øtles expre≈ø≈øe commandement in the place by you alledged, that all things bee done decently and according vnto order. I ≈øay, being rightly vnder≈øtood: for there is a double Order, the one Intrin≈øecall & in the things theÃÑ≈øelues, the other Externall & vnto vs. The former is that habitude, di≈øpo≈øition, or corre≈øpoÃÑdence which one thing naturally hath vnto another: in regard whereof it may al≈øo be called a Phy≈øicall order or an order of Nature. The latter is that which is made ≈øo vnto vs, being pre≈øcribed by lawfull authority: in re≈øpect
whereof it may further bee tearmed, a morall order, or an order of Prudence. Now if you vnder≈øtand your Maior thus, No ge≈øture mu≈øt be v≈øed but that which is at lea≈øt one of the≈øe two wayes orderly, you vnder≈øtand it aright: for ≈øo is S. Pauls meaning, and in that ≈øence it is granted vnto you. But if you vnder≈øtand it thus, that any ge≈øture which is in it ≈øelfe orderly may indifferently bee v≈øed by any, albeit the Church haue for orders ≈øake among many ≈øuch cho≈øen out, and authorized one only: then doe you mi≈øunder≈øtand it, and it is denied you: for S. Paul both here and el≈øewhere plainely declares him≈øelfe to bee a great enemy vnto all ≈øuch Anarchicall di≈øorder and confu≈øion.

Your Minor is, that Sitting is an orderlie ge≈øture. Whereunto I an≈øwere, that it is ≈øo indeed in it ≈øelfe, there being a naturall aptnes and fitnes in it to be v≈øed at the receiving of the Sacrament yet is it not in this ≈øence the only orderlie ge≈øture: for Standing and Kneeling are ≈øo al≈øo, and may put in for a place as well as Sitting. Neither is it unto us orderlie, becau≈øe publick authority hath commanded Kneeling onely, which to di≈øobey, is, as S. Paul ≈øaith, to re≈øist the ordinance of God. Nor doth the example and practice of Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles, and the Iewes proue the contrary. For the ge≈øture they v≈øed, as it was orderly in it ≈øelfe, ≈øo was it generally received and approved by the Church at that time: but among us not Sitting but Kneeling is the ge≈øture that is allowed and enioyned.

But if, this notwith≈øtanding, you will needs have that ge≈øture orderly unto us now which Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles, v≈øed, becau≈øe it was at that time orderlie, unto them: then know their ge≈øture was not Sitting, and you
bewray your ≈øelfe to bee but a bad Antiquary in affirming it. For as all ≈øtory te≈øtifieth, it was the manner of tho≈øe times and long before, at meales to lie on their beds, leaning on their elbowes, and ≈øupporting them≈øelues with pillowes. And hereunto agree the words which the Euangelists v≈øe to expre≈ø≈øe their ge≈øture: for „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ in Mathew and Marke, and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ in Luke and Iohn, import no other then lying at the table. Neither can you otherwi≈øe vnder≈øtand that which is ≈øaid of him whom Chri≈øt loued, that at ≈øupper hee lay or leaned on Ie≈øus brea≈øt, vnles it be by this ge≈øture. Wherfore you mu≈øt of force either quit ‚Ä¢ Sitting, and vrge vpon vs a nece≈ø≈øity of lying: or acknowledge that Sitting may not bee orderly vnto us, though anciently vnto Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles it were ≈øo. Your third and la≈øt argument is.

q.p: 3. If ≈øitting bee the only warranted gesture by Gods word, then it ought only to be v≈øed.
But it is the only warranted ge≈øture: for it only was v≈øed by the Iewes at the Pa≈ø≈øeover, and by Chri≈øt & his Apo≈øtles at his Supper.
Ergo ≈øitting only is to be v≈øed.

div.p:
That the word written (for ≈øo you meane) is the only warrant of all actions, is more then you will euer be able to proue. For the law of nature written in the hart, and the light of rea≈øon are ≈øufficient warrants for many things. Otherwi≈øe, how could the Gentiles which had not the law written, be as S. Paul ≈øaith a law vnto them≈øelves? and how could their con≈øciences either accu≈øe them for breaking the law, or excu≈øe them for doing thereafter? Neither do I herein derogate ought from
Scripture: only I yeeld vnto Rea≈øon that which is her due. They are both from God, and both are to be our directors: the one in tho≈øe things that fall within the compa≈ø≈øe of nature, the other in tho≈øe things that are aboue nature. In things ≈øupernaturall Scripture is the only warrant, Rea≈øon being therein ≈øtarkblind: In things Morall it is the ≈øafe≈øt warrant, Rea≈øon therein being but dim≈øighted. But to make Scripture the only warrant in all things without exception, is to put out the ≈øight of Rea≈øon, and to make it ≈øtarke blind in euery thing. Scripture I confe≈ø≈øe is perfect, but as a creature perfect in its kinde. What≈øoeuer is nece≈ø≈øarie vnto that end whereto it was ordained,2. Tim. 3.15. namely to make the man of God wi≈øe vnto Saluation, it containeth abundantlie, and with Tertullian, Contra. Hermog. c. 22. I adore the fulnes thereof. Other things if it warrant not, it no way impeacheth the perfection thereof, becau≈øe they are impertinent and make not vnto the end thereof. The ≈øequele therefore of your Maior is not good, and it is ab≈øurd and idle, in things not nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øaluation to argue, from authority of Scripture negatiuely, it ≈øaith not ≈øo Ergo it is not ≈øo.

But ≈øuppo≈øing the Con≈øequence of your Maior to be good, how proue you the Minor, that Sitting is onely warranted by Gods word? For≈øooth, becau≈øe it onely was v≈øed by the Iewes at the Pa≈ø≈øeouer, and by Christ and his Apostles at his Supper. Fir≈øt I haue ≈øufficiently demon≈øtrated aboue, that they ≈øate not: and therefore Sitting is ≈øo farre from being only warranted, that by your rule it is not warranted at all. Secondly, grant they ≈øate, yet it followes not thereupon that Sitting only is warranted. For as for the Iewes,Ex. 124 11. neither do their Ceremonies concerne us, and at the fir≈øt it ≈øeemes they ≈øtood. For they
were commanded to eat the Pa≈ø≈øeouer, with their loines girt, their ≈øhoos on their feet, & their ≈øtaues in their hands, v. 25. and in hast: and, as they were commanded, ≈øo they did. As touching Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles,(Suppo≈øing they ≈øate.) their act indeed ≈øufficiently proues that Sitting is in it ≈øelfe, and was vnto them lawfull, ≈øeing the wi≈øedome of Chri≈øt otherwi≈øe, would not haue v≈øed it: but that it is the onely lawfull ge≈øture it cannot po≈ø≈øibly prooue. If it could, by the ≈øame rea≈øon it would follow that the Euchari≈øt is only to bee admini≈øtred at euening and after ≈øupper, becau≈øe Chri≈øt then admini≈øtred it. For they are both circum≈øtances, and not e≈ø≈øentiall: & idem jus Titio quod Sejo, there is the ≈øame rea≈øon of both.

You will yet happily demand, why wee make not Chri≈øts ge≈øture a precedent for ours? are we wi≈øer then Chri≈øt? And I againe demand of you, why you lie not on your beds as Chri≈øt did: know you what is conuenient better then he? your an≈øwer I ≈øuppo≈øe will be, that Chri≈øts ge≈øture, was that which ordinarily they then v≈øed at meales: and Sitting is that which ordinarily they now v≈øe. And I an≈øwer, becau≈øe wee receiue not the Sacrament with our meales, as Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles fir≈øt did, therefore do we not v≈øe the ge≈øture of meales. The cau≈øe of the ge≈øture being taken away, the ge≈øture it ≈øelfe may bee changed al≈øo. The Iewes at the fir≈øt are the Pa≈ø≈øeouer ≈øtanding, as wee haue ≈øhewed, to ≈øignifie their ha≈øtie departure out of Egypt: but being now ≈øafely e≈øcaped thence, they alter that ge≈øture,Cap.
‚Ä¢ 8. Cap. 74. and our Sauiour by his practice approues their ≈øo doeing. The Councels of Laodicea, and of Trullo forbidding Agapas, that is, the loue fea≈øts, with which they were wont to receive the Communion, forbad al≈øo accubitus sternere to lie any
more in the Churches vpon their beds. So that in the wi≈ødome of the Churches of both Te≈øtaments, ≈øuch circum≈øtances may iu≈øtly bee varied as the cau≈øes or rea≈øons of them doe vary.

And thus of your arguments for ≈øitting: now let vs take a view al≈øo of your rea≈øons again≈øt Kneeling. They are in number foure, all as you thinke demon≈øtratiue, and out of nece≈ø≈øary premi≈ø≈øes concluding, that we may at no hand Kneele. The fir≈øt is this:
1 If Kneeling ought to bee v≈øed, then it is conuenient. But it is not conuenient. 2 Chron. 6.13. Dan. 6.11. Ergo, it is not to be v≈øed.

The Maior of this Syllogi≈øme is Hypotheticall or Conditionall, the Con≈øequence whereof is grounded vpon this Categoricall, or ≈øimple Propo≈øition, Nothing ought to be v≈øed but that which is conuenient.Rom. 3.8. Whereunto I an≈øwer, fir≈øt, as we may not doe euill that good may come of it: ≈øo neither may we forbeare that good which is coÃÑmanded vs for any euill or inconuenience that may follow thereof. Secondly, in things indifferent which are neither good nor euill, if they bee not ordered by authority, but are ≈øtill arbitrary and left vnto our choice, then as wee may v≈øe them becau≈øe they are lawfull, ≈øo may wee not v≈øe them when they proue inexpedient. The rule of charity mu≈øt ouerrule vs in this ca≈øe. But if once they bee ordered by publicke authority, then nece≈ø≈øity is laid vpon vs, and wee mu≈øt conforme our ≈øelues vnto order notwith≈øtanding any pretended inconuenience. The rule of loyalty mu≈øt ≈øway with vs in this ca≈øe. Bee it then that Kneeling is inconuenient; it was the fault of our ≈øuperiors
to command i ‚Ä¢ . Now it is commanded, and it is our duty to obey them. If it bee inconuenient to Kneele: it is more inconuenient to di≈øobey, and for not Kneeling to bee barred from the Sacrament. The ≈øequele therefore of your Maior is not good, and I require you to proue it.

The A≈ø≈øumption is, Kneeling is not conuenient. I deny it. You proue it by two places of Scripture, which te≈øtify that Salomon & Daniel kneeled when they prayed. The weakne≈ø≈øe of which proofe that you may the more readily perceiue, I reduce it into forme, thus. That ge≈øture which is v≈øed in prayer, is not conuenient at the Sacrament. But Kneeling is a ge≈øture v≈øed in Prayer. Ergo, it is inconuenient at the Sacrament. The Minor whereof I grant: but I deny the Maior as being too palpably ab≈øurd. For fir≈øt, neuer man yet dreamed that Kneeling is proper quarto modo vnto it, and may not bee v≈øed in any other action. Secondly, then may wee neither ≈øit nor ≈øtand at the Sacrament,1 King. 19.4. becau≈øe Elias prayed ≈øitting and the Publican ≈øtanding:Luc. 18.13. yea happily no ge≈øture is left for the Sacrament, ≈øeeing Prayer hath ingro≈øt them all before hand. La≈øtly, for as much as at the time of receiuing our affections are to bee aduanced and lifted vp vnto God in prayer and thanke≈øgiuing: it mu≈øt needs be by your owne rule, that Kneeling is a ge≈øture euery way conuenient for it. Your ≈øecond argument is,
2 No will-wor≈øhip may bee v≈øed. Mat. 15.9. Kneeling is will-wor≈øhip: for Pope Honorius fir≈øt devi≈øed it. Acts & Mon. pag. 1390.
Ergo, Kneeling may not bee v≈øed.

To yeeld vnto God that Wor≈øhip which he him≈øelfe
hath reuealed and pre≈øcribed, is an Act of true Religion: but to obtrude and thru≈øt vpon him a Wor≈øhip forged and deui≈øed of our ≈øelues, is meere ≈øuper≈øtition. The one hee rigourou≈øly exacteth of vs, the other hee expre≈øly forbiddeth.Ex. 15.38.39. In the law, God commandeth the Iewes to make them fringes in the borders of their garments, and to put a blew ribband vpon it throughout their generations, that yee may looke vpon it, ≈øaith he, and remember all the Commandements of the Lord to doe them: and that yee ≈øeeke not after your owne heart, and your owne eyes after which yee v≈øe to goe a whoaring. In the Prophets, he oftentimes vpbraideth them with their owne inuentions, and di≈ødainfully ≈øaith vnto them, Who hath required the≈øe things at your hands? And in the new Te≈øtament, our Sauiour in the place by you quoted,Mat. 15.9. Col. 2.23. ≈øeuerely taxeth the Phari≈øees, for teaching their owne fanta≈øies, and placing the wor≈øhip of God in the ob≈øeruation of mens precepts: and Saint Paul to the Colo≈øsians in plaine tearmes condemneth „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Wil-wor≈øhip, notwith≈øtaÃÑding what≈øoeuer ≈øhew of Wi≈ødome or humility it carry with it. All which con≈øidered, I yeeld you your Maior as true, No Wil-wor≈øhip may be v≈øed.

Your A≈ø≈øumption that Kneeling is Wil-wor≈øhip I deny: telling you further that you doe intolerable wrong vnto the Church of England, charging her with ≈øo gro≈ø≈øe a Super≈øtition. For the world knoweth, and you mu≈øt needs be a great ≈øtranger in I≈ørael if you be ignorant, that the Gouernors of our Church pre≈ø≈øe not their ceremonies vpon the con≈øciences of men, as if they were in them≈øelues nece≈ø≈øary and not indifferent: neither place any part of Religion or diuine wor≈øhip in them. This they leaue vnto that Man of ≈øin, who challengeth power vnto
him≈øelfe, as to create new articles of faith, ≈øo to pre≈øcribe new formes of Wor≈øhip al≈øo. That their intent is not Wil-wor≈øhip, but order & vniformity, they haue oftentimes publi≈øhed, if I may ≈øo ≈øay, with ≈øound of trumpet: which if you haue not heard, it is extreme deafenes: if you haue heard, and yet will not bee ≈øatisfied, to ≈øay no more, it proceeds of meere wilfulnes and frowardne≈ø≈øe.

Howbeit to proue your Minor you affirme that Pope Honorius fir≈øt deui≈øed it.Cap. Sanc, de celeb ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Mi≈ø≈ø. It is true indeed that Honorius the third decreed, that Prie≈øts ≈øhould often teach their people, reuerently to bow theÃÑ≈øelues at the Eleuation of the Ho≈øte when Ma≈ø≈øe is ≈øaid, and when the Prie≈øt carries it to one that is ≈øicke, and I deny not but thereby he inteÃÑ ded the Adoration of the Ho≈øte. But you ≈øhould know that it is one thing to receiue the Communion Kneeling, another thing to Kneele at the Eleuation when there is no Receiuing. This Honorius decreed, not that, for ought I can learne. Nay further, what that ge≈øture was which ≈øucceeded accubitus, lying on beds, whether it were kneeling, or ≈øtanding, or ≈øitting, I ≈øuppo≈øe he who is well acquainted with Eccle≈øia≈øticall Story can hardly determine, much le≈ø≈øe you who≈øe reading therein pa≈ø≈øeth not beyond the booke of Martyrs. Let euery one herein abound in his owne ≈øence: I for my part thinke it was Kneeling rather then any other, becau≈øe it is a ge≈øture of mo≈øt reuerence.Lib. 4. c. 8. Ho≈øpinian a learned man who wrote the ≈øtory of this Sacrament, hath the≈øe words, This Sacrament ought to bee handled with great Religion and reuerence, according to the cu≈øtome of euery Church, with decent apparell, temperate behauiour, ≈øoberly, religiou≈øly, the head bare, the knees bent, and other ≈øuch like free ceremonies. And this reuerence or honour I doubt not but
≈øome of the Fathers aboue cited vnder≈øtood by the word Adoration. For to Adore ≈øometime ≈øignifieth, as all know, externall reuerence and veneration exhibited by bodily ge≈øtures and ≈øpeech vnto a thing, as when the knees are bent, the body is bowed, the head vncouered, the hands lifted vp, &c. Thus far Ho≈øpinian, by who≈øe iudgement Kneeling in all likely-hood was v≈øed long before Honorius liued, or the Reall Pre≈øence was dreamed of. How≈øoeuer, it is meere foppery to imagine that a thing in it ≈øelfe lawfull once abu≈øed to a bad end, can neuer recouer its right againe and bee lawfully v≈øed: and then taking this for granted, to preiudice our reuerent receiuing by Romi≈øh practice and ≈øuper≈øtition. I conclude therefore this point with that excellent ≈øaying of Origen, Hom. 5. in Euang. when thou receiue≈øt that holy meat and incorruptible banket, when thou enioye≈øt that Bread and Cup of life, and eate≈øt and drinke≈øt the Body and Bloud of the Lord, then the Lord entreth vnder thy roofe. Thou therefore humbling thy ≈øelfe, imitate the Centurion and ≈øay, Lord I am not worthy that thou ≈øhould≈øt come vnder my roofe. The third argument.
div.q: 3 All ≈øhew of euill mu≈øt bee e≈øchewed. 1. The≈øs. 5.22. Kneeling is a ≈øhew of euill, as of Bread wor≈øhip. Ergo, Kneeling mu≈øt bee e≈øchewed.
div.p:
Fir≈øt I interprete the Maior. Saint Pauls words in the place by you quoted are the≈øe, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ : which may bee rendred thus, Abstaine from all kind of euill. For the word
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ≈øignifieth kinde: and in this ≈øence the Syriacke tran≈ølation vnder≈øtandeth it. And interpreting it thus, the Maior is vniuer≈øally and without exception true: for no euill what≈øoeuer, being intrin≈øecally
and formally ≈øo, may in any ca≈øe bee done. Be≈øides this expo≈øition there is another more generally approued, Ab≈øtaine from all ≈øhew of euill or euill ≈øhew. For as euill it ≈øelfe mu≈øt bee refrained that God bee not offended nor our Con≈øciences di≈øquieted: ≈øo mu≈øt ≈øhew of euill al≈øo bee auoided, that wee ≈øcandall not our brother, nor di≈øcredit our profe≈ø≈øion. But in this ≈øence the Maior is not vniuer≈øally and without exception true. For fir≈øt, it holds not in nece≈ø≈øary duties commanded by God, nor in things indifferent ordered by man. For the ≈øub≈øtance mu≈øt not bee neglected becau≈øe of a ≈øhadow: nor wee fall into the reall euils of Di≈øobedience and Di≈øloyalty, to auoid the ≈øhew of euill. Againe it holds not in Imaginary ≈øhewes, ≈øuch as are without ground fancied in the ≈øicke braines of humorous and malecontented people: but ≈øuch onely as indeed carry with them a ≈øhrewd pre≈øumption of that euill whereof it is a ≈øhew. And thus the Maior is granted vnto you, in the former ≈øence ab≈øolutely and ≈øimply, in the latter re≈øpectiuely with the≈øe re≈øtrictions and limitations.

Now to the Minor I an≈øwere, fir≈øt Kneeling is not formally euill, but of an indifferent and middle nature, neither good nor euill: and therefore is not forbidden by the former interpretation, Ab≈øtaine from all kind of euill. Secondly, I denie it to bee a ≈øhew of euill. For whereof? Of Bread wor≈øhip you ≈øay. How ≈øo, ≈øeing we are neither Tran≈øubstantiators nor Con≈øub≈øtantiators, and haue long ≈øince openly before all men di≈øclaimed both Eleuation & Ad ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ tion? And to whom? To Papi≈øt or Prote≈øtant? Certainly neither: for the one condemnes vs for not adoring, and the other ≈øu≈øpects vs not for adoring. So that the Shew of Breadwor≈øhip lieth not in our
Kneeling, but in your Imagination. Which if it be a ≈øufficient rea≈øon to barre vs from Kneeling, I mu≈øt entreat you for the ≈øame rea≈øon to ab≈øtaine from Sitting:See Tertull. de orat. c. 12. for I can ea≈øily imagine in it a ≈øhew of euill, namely of Sleighting and Contemning the Sacrament. Nay I mu≈øt pray you to ≈øit ≈øtill and do nothing: for what is it wherein a man may not fancie ≈øome euill ≈øhew or other? La≈øtly, ≈øuppo≈øe Kneeling haue the ≈øhew you ≈øpeake of, yet is it not to be forborne, becau≈øe it is in the number of tho≈øe things that are excepted from the generall rule. For it is commanded by authority, and to receiue the Communion is a nece≈ø≈øary duty which among us without Kneeling cannot bee done. Now as I haue ≈øaid, to auoid ≈øeeming euill we may not be euill, and for feare of a ≈øhadow loo≈øe the ≈øub≈øtance, I meane the benefit and comfort of the Sacrament. And thus your argument drawen from the ≈øhew of euill proues as you ≈øee but the ≈øhew of an argument. I come to the la≈øt rea≈øon.

q.p: 4 If we may kneele to Bread and wine, much more may We kneele to Angels.
But wee may not kneele to Angels. Rev. 19.10.
Ergo wee may not kneele to bread and wine.

div.p:
This is that Fallacie which Logicians call Ignorance of the Elench, when that is concluded which is not in que≈øtion. For our Que≈øtion is, Whether we may kneele at the receauing of the Sacrament: but your Conclu≈øion is wee may not kneele to Bread and Wine. Neither ≈øhall there bee any quarell betweene vs about this point: for we readily grant it you, acknowledging further that your argument
from the greater to the le≈ø≈øe ≈øufficiently euinceth it. For if we may not fall downe to adore an Angell, much le≈ø≈øe may we do ≈øo to bread and wine. And as we may not, ≈øo wee do not. Our Kneeling is not intended unto bread and wine, but vnto God who in the Sacrament offereth vnto vs the ble≈ø≈øed body and bloud of his ≈øonne, who is God al≈øo, and to bee wor≈øhipped of vs for euermore. You might therefore well haue forborne this argument which neither preiudiceth vs, nor aduantageth your ≈øelfe any whit at all: or if you haue any other meaning, you ≈øhould haue better expre≈øt it. For my part I cannot gue≈ø≈øe what it ≈øhould bee, nor will I trouble my braine in ≈øeeking it. Happily your ≈øelfe know not what you would.

And thus haue I though breefly, yet fully an≈øwered all your rea≈øons. It now remaineth, that either you produce ≈øounder arguments then yet you haue giuen vs, or adde more vigor and ≈øtrength vnto the≈øe: or (becau≈øe I feare you can do neither) that con≈øidering the weaknes of tho≈øe reeds whereon you haue hitherto leaned, hence forward you tru≈øt them no more. It can bee no di≈øgrace vnto you to bee ouercome of Truth: neither is it leuity or incon≈øtancy vpon ≈øight of your errour to change both your opinion and practice. Take therefore vnto you Chri≈øtian ≈øeuerity, and ingenuou≈øly reuoke what you haue held or done ami≈ø≈øe: ≈øo ≈øhall you giue glorie vnto God, and God ≈øhall honour you in the ≈øight of all his Saints. But if, notwith≈øtanding all that hath beene ≈øaid, you meane ≈øtill to per≈øi≈øt in your error, and will not bee per≈øuaded although you be per≈øwaded: I feare le≈øt after ≈øtraining at the≈øe gnats, you fall to ≈øwallowing downe of Camels, and proceed from di≈ølike of a few
indifferent ceremonies, vnto flat ≈øchi≈øme and ≈øeparation. which God forbid for his mercies ≈øake. Amen.

div.head: HOW S. PAVL AND S. IAMES ARE TO BEE reconciled in the matter of IVSTIFICATION.
div.p: YOV demand how Saint Paul teaching Iu≈øtification by Faith onely without the Works of the Law,Ro. 5.20.28. Gal. 2.16. Iam. 2.24. and Saint Iames affirming that of Works a man is iu≈øtified and not of Faith only, may bee reconciled. I will endeuour to giue you the be≈øt ≈øatisfaction I can in a few Propo≈øitions.

1 Scripture being the Word of God who is truth and who≈øe promi≈øes are not yea and nay, 2. Cor. 1.17.18.19.20. but yea and Amen, although ≈øometime there may ≈øeeme contrariety in it, yet reall difference and repugnancy there can bee
none, truth euer agreeing and neuer contradicting it ≈øelfe.

2 Paul therefore and Iames being in≈øpired by the ≈øame ≈øpirit mu≈øt needs con≈øpire in the ≈øame truth: although the one exclude Works from Faith in the matter of Iustification, the other include Works together with Faith.

3 The readie≈øt way to reconcile this ≈øeeming contradiction is to ob≈øerue carefully the Occa≈øions whereupon they were moued to deliuer the≈øe doctrines, and to di≈øtingui≈øh the Equiuocation and diuers v≈øe of the≈øe two words Iu≈øtification and Faith. For if there bee the ≈øame meaning in both, and no ambiguity in either of the≈øe tearmes, it cannot bee auoided but they mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity cro≈ø≈øe one the other.

4 Saint Pauls occa≈øion was this. Hee ≈øaw with what eagerne≈ø≈øe & contention certaine Iewes maintained,Act. 15.1. that vnle≈ø≈øe the law of Mo≈øes were kept and ob≈øerued together with the Go≈øpell, there could bee no Iu≈øtification: and that thereby mans Works were either ≈øub≈øtituted in the roome of, or yoked together with Faith, to the great preiudice of Gods free Grace.Ro. 2.24. And therefore again≈øt the≈øe he proues by the te≈øtimony of the Law & the Prophets, that we are Iustified by Faith in Chri≈øt freely without the works of the Law.

5 Hereupon ≈øome there were, who like ≈øpiders ≈øucking venome out of the whol≈øome≈øt flowers, ≈øo interpreted this comfortable doctrine, as if it skilled not whether they practized good works, and led a godly & vertuous life, ≈øo as they did belieue. And again≈øt this ≈øort of men the Apo≈øtle Saint Iames thought it nece≈ø≈øary to oppo≈øe him≈øelfe.

6 So that Saint Iames doth not di≈øpute again≈øt Saint Paul, but for the right meaning of S. Paul again≈øt tho≈øe that depraued and wre≈øted his doctrine to a wrong ≈øence. Paul ≈øo defending Iu≈øtification by Faith without Works, as hee denies not the nece≈ø≈øary practice of them, but only denies the power of Iu≈øtification vnto them: Iames ≈øo e≈øtabli≈øhing good Works, not as giuing them force to make a man acceptable and iu≈øt in the ≈øight of Gods iu≈øtice, but onely di≈øabling that Faith from hauing any power to Iu≈øtify vs, which is not accompanied with them.

7 And thus Saint Augu≈øtin vnder≈øtandeth it. When, De fide & oper. l. 1. c. 14. ≈øaith he, the Apostle ≈øaith, that a man is iustified by Faith without the Works of the Law, hee meaneth not that Faith being receiued and profe≈øsed; the works of Iu≈øtice ≈øhould bee contemned: but that euery one ≈øhould know that he may be iu≈øtified by Faith, although the works of the law goe not before. For they follow him that is iu≈øtified, but goe not before him that is to bee iu≈øtified. And againe,83. quae≈øt. q. 16. When as Paul ≈øpeakes of the good works of Abraham which accompanied his Faith, it is manife≈øt that by the example of Abraham he doth not ≈øo teach that a man is iustified by Faith without works, that if hee doe belieue it concernes him not to worke well: but to to this end rather, that no man ≈øhould thinke that by the merit of his former good Works he hath attained the gift of iu≈øtification which is by Faith.

8 As the con≈øideration of the different occa≈øions which moued the≈øe two Apo≈øtles to ≈øpeake ≈øo differently doth in part cleere this que≈øtion: ≈øo will it yet bee more euident if wee know the ≈øeuerall acceptions and v≈øes of the≈øe words Iu≈øtification and Faith, and in what ≈øence either Apo≈øtle vnder≈øtands them.

9 Iustification v≈øually in the Scripture phra≈øe ≈øignifieth, not to make iu≈øt by infu≈øing the quality of Iu≈øtice into the ≈øoule,2. King. 15.4. Deut. 25.1. P≈øal. 81.3. Prov. 17.15. Mat. 12.37. Ro. 8.33.34. but to pronounce and declare to be iu≈øt: being indeed a Law-terme, and drawne from ciuill Courts of iudicature, and is oppo≈øed to Condemnation. And this is ≈øo cleere, that Tolet a Ie≈øuite confe≈ø≈øeth it mo≈øt frequently ≈øo to ≈øignify in Scripture: Pineda, Vega, and Salmeron three great Papi≈øts acknowledge it in this ≈øence to be v≈øed by S. Paul in his Epi≈øtle to the Romans, where hee di≈øputeth purpo≈øely of Iustification.

10 Now there is a double tribunall where wee are to bee iudged, one is Gods, the other Mans: and therefore God is ≈øayd to Iu≈øtify, and Man al≈øo. God when he acquits a ≈øinner from his ≈øinnes for the merit of his Son Chri≈øt: Man when ≈øeeing our good works (which are the fruites and te≈øtimonies of our grace with God) out of the iudgement of Charity hee accounts vs the Sonnes of God. Of the former Saint Paul ≈øpeakes, of the latter S. Iames. S. Paul enquireth how wee are made lu≈øt before God, namely by Faith: S. James how it may appeare vnto men that wee are Iu≈øt, namely by Works. Faith is the principle of Exi≈øtence by which we are Iu≈øt: Works of Knowledge by which we are knowne to be Iu≈øt.

Iac. 2.10. In id cap.11 That Saint Iames vnder≈øtandeth ≈øuch a Declaratiue Iu≈øtification is plaine by that he ≈øaith. Shew mee thy Faith by thy Works? And Thomas of Aquin affirmeth, that Workes following Faith are not ≈øaid to Iu≈øtify, as Iu≈øtification is an infu≈øion of iu≈øtice but as it is an exerci≈øe or declaration or perfection of Faith.

12 Concerning the word Faith, ≈øometimes it ≈øignifieth that ≈øanctifying grace of Gods ≈øpirit whereby wee
beleeue in or on God, that is, put all our affiance vpon God in Chri≈øt for Iu≈øtification and Saluation: ≈øometimes a naked a≈ø≈øent or agreeing to all the truths contained in the Scripture, ≈øpecially ≈øuch as are Euangelicall. That is only of the Elect: this the Diuels haue. That either hath works following it, as in Abraham: or is great in child of works, ready to trauell and bring forth if God giue time, as in the theefe on the cro≈ø≈øe. This many times is without works, and therefore dead and ≈øpiritles. Of that S. Paul ≈øpeaketh: of this S. Iames. That ≈øole but not ≈øolitary iu≈øtifies: this being ≈øolitary iu≈øtifies not.

13 In a word, S. Paul ≈øpeaks of the cau≈øe of Iu≈øtification: S. Iames of the Effect. S. Paul de≈øcends from the Cau≈øe to the Effect: S. Iames a≈øcends from the Effects to the Cau≈øe. S. Paul re≈øolues how wee may bee iu≈øtified: S. Iames how wee may bee knowne to bee iu≈øtified. S. Paul excludes works as being no Cau≈øe of Iu≈øtification: S. Iames requires works as fruites of Iu≈øtification. S. Paul denies works to go before them that are to bee iu≈øtified: S. Iames affirmeth that they follow him that is iu≈øtified.

14 Others di≈øtingui≈øh, and reconcile them thus. Iu≈øtification is ≈øometime vnder≈øtood without implying Sanctification, ≈øometime as it implyeth al≈øo Sanctification with it. In the former ≈øence S. Paul taketh it, when hee proueth that a man is iu≈øtified by Faith without works: S. Iames in the latter, when he concludeth that a man is iu≈øtified by works and not by Faith only. And this I ≈øuppo≈øe to be a very ≈øound interpretation.

15 How≈øoeuer, that Faith alone without the works of the Law in the ≈øence aboue deliuered doth iu≈øtifie,
the≈øe ancient Fathers auouch together with us, Origen, Cyprian, Eu≈øebius Cae≈øarien≈øis, Hilarie, Ba≈øil, Chry≈øo≈øtome, Ambro≈øe, Augu≈øtin, Cyril, Prima≈øius, He≈øychius, Gennadius, Oecumenius, who≈øe direct and expre≈ø≈øe words I can at any time produce. Nay the≈øe late Papi≈øts al≈øo (lea≈øt it ≈øhould be thought that none but Prote≈øtants hold it) the Canons of Collein, the authors of the booke offered by Cae≈øar vnto the Protestant Collocutors in the a≈ø≈øemblie of Rati≈øbon, Pighius, Ca≈ø≈øander, Stapulen≈øis, Peraldus, Ferus, and others who count them≈øelues as good Catholiks as they that hold otherwi≈øe.

16 And this only Faith is ≈øo ≈øure an anchor of our ≈øoules, and ≈øuch ‚Ä¢ fountaine of true comfort both, in life and death, that Charles the fift, Steuen Gardiner, Sir Christopher Blunt, and ≈øundrie others dur≈øt not at their death tru≈øt vnto their works, but vnto Faith in Chri≈øt only. And Cardinal Bellarmin after a long di≈øputation touching the merit of works is faine to conclude, that becau≈øe of the vncertenty of our owne iu≈øtice, and the danger of vaineglory, the Safe≈øt cour≈øe is to repo≈øe all our affiance in the only mercy and goodnes of God. So that in his iudgement wee Prote≈øtants haue cho≈øen the Safe≈øt cour≈øe: & I for my part will neuer tru≈øt my ≈øoule vnto them who leauing ≈øo ≈øafe a cour≈øe, meane to hazard it through a more dangerous way.

div.head: OF THE AVTHORS AND AVTHORITY OF THE CREED, AND WHY IT IS CALLED a Symbole.
div.p:
THE in≈øcription of the Creed ≈øeemes to father it on the holy Apo≈øtles, calling it the Symbole of the Apo≈øtles. So doe almo≈øt all the Fathers of the fourth age after Chri≈øt and downeward, affirming that the Apo≈øtles hauing receiued the Holy Gho≈øt at Ieru≈øalem, and being now ready to di≈øper≈øe them≈øelues into all parts of the world to preach the
Go≈øpell, thought it good before their parting to compile this Symbole, that it might ≈øerue as a pledge of their vnity in the Faith, and a canon for their doctrine and teaching. Yea ≈øome of them proceed ≈øo farre as particularly to ≈øet downe what article was made by what Apo≈øtle: whereof ≈øee Augu≈øtin in his hundred and fifteenth Sermon de tempore. Now although it bee very hard for mee to ≈øway again≈øt the ≈øtreame of ≈øo maine authority: yet can I not but doubt thereof,Paraphr. in Mat. Praef. and confe≈ø≈øe with Era≈ømus I know not who made the Creed, e≈øpecially hauing ≈øo great probabilities (for demon≈øtrations I dare not call them) that it ≈øhould not bee done by the twelue Apo≈øtles.

For fir≈øt, were it compiled by them, is it likely that Saint Luke writing the hi≈øtory of their Acts, would haue omitted ≈øo principall a matter? Sundry other things of farre le≈ø≈øe con≈øequence hee hath carefully recorded: but of this ≈øo important and weighty a bu≈øine≈ø≈øe hee makes not ≈øo much as one word mention, which certainly hee would neuer haue failed to doe, had they done ≈øo. Adde hereunto that not one of the ancient Fathers who liued within the three fir≈øt Centuries of Chri≈øt ≈øpeake of any ≈øuch thing in any of their writings: and yet they ≈øhould be≈øt know it who≈øe times were neere≈øt vnto the Apo≈øtles. This deep ≈øilence both of Saint Luke and all tho≈øe ancient Doctors, make it vnto mee more then probable that the Apo≈øtles neuer compo≈øed it.

Secondly, as the ≈øilence of the≈øe worthies, ≈øo the very language of the Creed conuinceth it to bee yonger then the Apo≈øtles. For the word Catholike v≈øed in the Creed was not knowne in their time. Can any man thinke that the Church ≈øhould then bee called Catholike when it
was not Catholike? For when they ≈øay this Creed was compiled, the Church was ≈øcarce begunne among the Iewes, and the Apo≈øtles had no where as yet preached the Go≈øpell among the Gentils. But heare the expre≈ø≈øe words of Pacianus Bi≈øhop of Barcilona, Sed ≈øub Apo≈øtolis, Ad Sympronian Epi≈øt. 1. inquies, nemo Catholicus vocabatur. E≈øto, ≈øic fuerit. Vel illud indulge, cum po≈øt Apo≈øtolos haere≈øes extiti≈ø≈øent, diuer≈øi≈ø
que nominibus columbam Dei at
que Reginam lacerare per partes & ≈øcindere niterentur: nonne cognomen ≈øuum plebs Apo≈øtolica po≈øtulabat, quo incorrupti populi di≈øtingueret vnitatem, neintemeratam Dei virginem error aliquorum per membra laceraret? In the Apo≈øtles times, you will ≈øay, no man was called Catholicke. Bee it ≈øo. Yet by your leaue when after the Apo≈øtles here≈øies were ri≈øen vp, and by diuer≈øity of names they laboured to rent and teare in peeces the done and queene of God: was it not requi≈øite that tho≈øe which were Apo≈øtolike ≈øhould haue a ≈øirname of their owne, whereby the vnity of tho≈øe that are vncorrupt might bee di≈øtingui≈øhed, and the error of none might rent in peeces the immaculate virgin of God? Thus hee. Again≈øt which if it bee obiected, that the Epi≈øtles of Iames, Peter, Iohn, and Iude are called Catholicke: I an≈øwer, the In≈øcriptions and Sub≈øcriptions of the Epi≈øtles are not Apo≈øtolicall, but added to them by ≈øome other, and ≈øometime vntruly. Neither is there any rea≈øon they ≈øhould bee ≈øo ≈øtiled aboue the re≈øt. For neither is the doctrine contained in them more Catholicke then of all the other Epi≈øtles, neither were they written to all the Iewes, more then the Epi≈øtle to the Hebrewes, neither were they all written to all Catholicks, for the ≈øecond and third of Iohn were ≈øent vnto priuate per≈øons onely, and all the re≈øt as vniuer≈øally concerne all Catholicks
as the≈øe few tearmed Catholicke doe. I conclude therefore, the word Catholicke being latter then the Apo≈øtles, ≈øo mu≈øt the Creed bee al≈øo which v≈øes it.

Thirdly, the different relation of the ≈øtory bewrayes the vncertainty of it: for they giue not all the ≈øame article vnto the ≈øame Apo≈øtle. Some mar≈øhall them iu≈øt as S. Luke doth in the fir≈øt of the Acts: others thus, Peter, Andrew, Iohn, Iames the elder, Thomas, Iames the younger, Bartlemew, Mathew, Simon, Iude, Mathias. Againe, ≈øome of them attribute vnto Peter part onely of the fir≈øt article, I belieue in God the Father almighty, and vnto Iohn the other part Maker of Heauen and Earth. But others attribute the whole article vnto Peter, and giue another vnto Iohn. The like may bee ob≈øerued in other articles. If then they bee certaine of the tradition, why doe they differ thus in their reports? If they differ thus one from another, who can bee certaine of the tradition.

Fourthly, if the Creed both for matter & forme were from the Apo≈øtles, and they deliuered it preci≈øely in tho≈øe words in which we now haue it, why is it not placed in the Canon of Scripture? Certainly in the Church although it euer haue been much e≈øteemed, yet was it neuer counted Canonicall. Neither hath it been pre≈øerued ≈øo ≈øafe from addition, detraction, mutation, as the re≈øt of the Scriptures always haue been. For euen in the anciente≈øt times we find great variety in it. Ruffin writing a iu≈øt comment on it, omits that clau≈øe Maker of Heauen and Earth. And who knowes not how many there are who relating this Creed leaue out the article of Chri≈øt de≈øcending into hell?De Chri≈øti anima. c. 6 Euen Bellarmin him≈øelfe, confe≈ø≈øeth
that it was not found anciently in all Creeds: and hee voucheth for it Irenaeus, Origen, Tertullian, and Augustin though fiue times he expouÃÑd it, and finally the Creed of the Roman Church al≈øo as Ruffin witne≈ø≈øeth vnto whom if hee had been ≈øo plea≈øed, he might haue added a whole armie of others, whom for breuities ≈øake I omit. Finally the ancient Doctors were ≈øo farre from equalling it with Scripture, that they appealed from it thereunto as to an higher authority.Catech. 4. Cyril plainely affirmeth that wee may not beleeue the Creed without Scripture.Biblioth. ≈øanc. Patr. tom. 9. And Pa≈øcha≈øius again≈øt Macedonius ≈øhrowding him≈øelfe vnder ≈øome words of the Creed, appealeth vnto the Canonicall Scripture, for that of it, ≈øaith hee, the text of the Creed dependeth. Which had they thought it had been from the Apo≈øtles in ≈øuch forme and as now we haue it, without que≈øtion they neuer would haue done.

Fiftly, the rea≈øon which they a≈ø≈øigne why they compo≈øed this Creed, di≈øcouers the vanity thereof. What was that? That it might be for≈øooth vnto the Apo≈øtles a canon & rule, according to which they ≈øhould ≈øquare and conforme their preaching. What vnto the Apo≈øtles to whom Chri≈øt promi≈øed his ble≈ø≈øed Spirit that ≈øhould lead them into all truth? And that him≈øelfe would put into their mouths a ready an≈øwer vpon all occa≈øions, ≈øo that they ≈øhould not need to bethinke them≈øelues what to ≈øay? Could they po≈ø≈øibly doubt le≈øt any difference or di≈øcord ≈øhould grow among them in matter of Faith, who were ≈øo guided by the Spirit of truth and vnity that they could not in any point either erre them≈øelues, or lead any other into error? Surely, ≈øo to thinke, derogateth much from the truth of Chri≈øt, and imputeth much weakne≈ø≈øe vnto the Spirit of God, and detracteth from the certainty of
our Faith which dependeth on their preaching. So that for this cau≈øe it is vnlikely they made this Creed, at lea≈øtwi≈øe to this end.

De Symb. ad Cat. l. 1. c. 1.La≈øtly, Saint Augu≈øtin ≈øaith thus (not that fal≈øe Augu≈øtin vpon whom tho≈øe Sermons de tempore are fathered, and who≈øe authority is v≈øually alledged to warrant this legend, but the true S. Augu≈øtin ≈øaith) Illa verba (Symboli) qua audiui≈øtis per Scripturas ≈øpar≈øa ≈øunt, & inde collecta, & ad vnum redacta: tho≈øe words of the Creed which you haue heard, are di≈øper≈øed through the Scriptures, and being gathered from thence, are reduced into one. With him agreeth Pa≈øcha≈øius, De Spirit. Sanct. c. 1. De ≈øacris omnin√≤ voluminibus quae ≈øunt credenda ≈øumamus, de quorum fonte ≈øymboli ip≈øius ≈øeries deriuata con≈øi≈øtit: Let vs take out of the ≈øacred volumes what things wee are to belieue, out of which fountaine the order of the Creed is deriued.Centur. 1. l. 2. c. 4. And Marcellus a Bi≈øhop in a letter to Iulius Bi≈øhop of Rome profe≈ø≈øeth hauing rehear≈øed the words of the Creed, Se hanc fidem ex Scripturis accepi≈ø≈øe, & a maioribus ≈øecundum Deum accepi≈ø≈øe, & candem in Eccle≈øi√¢ Dei praedicare: that he receiued this Faith out of the Scriptures, and next after God from his ance≈øtors, and that hee preached it in the Church of God. If then, as the≈øe Fathers affirme, the Creed bee gathered out of the Scriptures, how can the Apo≈øtles bee authors thereof? For out of the old Te≈øtament they could not gather that Chri≈øt was borne of the Virgin Mary, or that hee ≈øuffered vnder Pontius Pilate. And as for the new, many of the Apo≈øtles were dead before all was written, and Iames before any was written: be≈øides that no part of it was written when the Creed was compiled, if it bee true which the legend ≈øaith. And the≈øe are the rea≈øons for which it ≈øeemeth vnto me more
then probable that the Apo≈øtles were neuer Authors of this Creed.

If it be ≈øo will ≈øome ≈øay, why doth it then beare the Apo≈øtles name? I an≈øwere, becau≈øe, as out of S. Augu≈øtin and others we haue ≈øhewed, the matter therein contayned is perfectly agreeable with the Apo≈øtles writings and was collected out of them. Moreouer, Apo≈øtolicall is a terme extended by writers vnto the fir≈øt three hundred years after Chri≈øt. Haet ≈øola fides, ≈øaith Dama≈øus, Ep. 5. quae Nicaeae Apo≈øtolorum authoritate fundata e≈øt, perpetua est firmitate ≈øeruanda: this only Faith which was e≈øtabli≈øhed at Nice by the authority of the Apo≈øtles, is firmely and perpetually to be held. So Scythianus and Terebinthus are ≈øaid to haue liued temporibus Apostolorum in the time of the Apo≈øtles,Epiph. Haer. 66. who yet liued in Aurelians time, towards three hundred years after Chri≈øt. And I≈øidor di≈øtingui≈øhing betweene Apo≈øtles and the Fir≈øt Apo≈øtles, ≈øaith that Apo≈øtles continued downe vntill Pope Sylue≈øter, and that the times before the great Councell of Nice were Apo≈øtolicall. Although therefore the fir≈øt Apo≈øtles were not the founders of this Creed: yet tho≈øe ≈øucceeding Apo≈øtles were, of whom it may be called the Apo≈øtles Creed.

The≈øe things being ≈øo, let it bee ob≈øerued thereupon, fir≈øt how friuolou≈øly Papi≈øts cauill and quarell with vs, affirming that wee hold not the Faith of the Creed becau≈øe we que≈øtion it whether the Apo≈øtles were authors of it or no. As if to doubt of the author were to doubt of the truth of the matter: or as if all tho≈øe Ancients reiected the epi≈øtle to the Hebrewes for Apocryphall, which were not re≈øolued who wrote it, whether Paul, or Barnabas, or Luke, or Clemens. Secondly, how weaklie
Popi≈øh traditions are ≈øupported by the tradition of this Creed. For not being the Apo≈øtles, how can it be a tradition of the Apo≈øtles? or if it be a tradition of theirs, yet is it ≈øuch a tradition as is written & contayned in Scripture: and ≈øuch wee willingly receiue. Let them proue the re≈øt of their pretended traditions to be ≈øuch, and we will readily embrace them al≈øo. But returne wee to our purpo≈øe.

This Creed by whom≈øoeuer it was made is intituled
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
a Symbol: the rea≈øon whereof we are now to inquire. To let pa≈ø≈øe tho≈øe barbarous and iocular notations which ignorant Monks haue giuen of it, le≈øt relating them I ≈øhould both ≈øpend time, & defile my paper: ≈øome deriue it from „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ≈øignifying as they ≈øay a ≈øhote or reckoning, Ruff. Symb. Aug. ≈øer. de tem. 115. for that the Apo≈øtles meeting together to compile it, did each conferre his article as it were his ≈øymbole for defraying of this heauenly banket. But fir≈øt the Apo≈øtles, as we haue declared, neuer compiled this Creed. Secondly, if they compiled it, yet, as Antonius Nebri≈øen≈øis ≈øaith,Quinquag. c. 40. it is neither credible nor likely that each of them conferred his particle: ≈øeeing in tho≈øe things that are con≈øtituted and decreed by many, it is not the manner for euery one ≈øeuerally to put his word or ≈øaying into it, but for all iointly to agree vpon the whole. Adde hereunto, that if it were ≈øo, men would neuer haue diuided the Creed as they haue done, ≈øome into ≈øeuen articles, becau≈øe of the ≈øeuen gifts of the holy gho≈øt, very many others into fourteen: but onely into twelue, according to the number of the Apo≈øtles, who dictated each of them his article. La≈øtly, not „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ but „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ≈øignifieth a ≈øhote, as the learned know, neither can it bee ≈øhewed to bee otherwi≈øe in any Greeke writer.
Indeed in Latine writers yee ≈øhall ≈øometimes find Symbolum ≈øo v≈øed: yet that it is found ≈øo in any ≈økilfull Criticks impute it to the ignorance of Notaries, and by the warrant of the be≈øt Manu≈øcripts re≈øtore the Feminine Symbola into the roome thereof.

Others fetch it from Symbolum ≈øignifying a Pledge or token and fir≈øt ≈øuch a pledge whereby per≈øons e≈øpou≈øed bind them≈øelues to bee faithfull and true one vnto another: becau≈øe likewi≈øe in our ≈øpirituall e≈øpou≈øals with Chri≈øt, as he giues vnto vs his ble≈ø≈øed ≈øpirit as an earne≈øt of his con≈øtant loue to vs, ≈øo wee returne backe againe the profe≈ø≈øion of our faith as a firme pledge of our loyalty and ≈øubiection to him. This rea≈øon caries good likelyhood and proportion with it. So doth al≈øo the next, when it ≈øignifieth te≈ø≈øeram ho≈øpitalem, ≈øuch a token as Cities were wont to giue vnto their friends, that ≈øhewing it they might find friendly entertainment in confederate townes: or ≈øuch as one friend was wont to giue vnto an other to the like end. Which how it fits the amitie and frien≈øhip betweene Chri≈øt & vs, who ≈øees not?

Neuerthele≈ø≈øe I rather thinke it is ≈øo called from
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ as it ≈øignifieth a watchword. For the Primitiue Church ≈øeemeth much to haue beene delighted with militare terms: I ≈øuppo≈øe becau≈øe in Scripture Chri≈øtians are ≈øo often compared vnto ≈øouldiers. And hence it is that the Church is di≈øtingui≈øhed into Militant and Triumphant, that Heathen are called Pagans in oppo≈øition vnto ≈øouldiers, that the two my≈øteries of the Church are termed Sacraments, a word importing that oath of obedience which ≈øouldiers take vnto their Generals. In like manner may the Creed be called a Symbole, becau≈øe it is as a watchword by which true Orthodoxe Christians
many di≈øcerne one from the other. Painims, Iewes, Turks, and Hereticks. Heerwith agreeth Maximus Taurinen≈øis, Symbolum te≈ø≈øera e≈øt & ≈øignaculum quo inter fideles perfido≈øque ≈øecernitur: Hom. de trad. Symb. the Symbole is a watchword or marke by which Faithfull and Faithles men are di≈øcerned. And Ambro≈øe, De voland. Virg. l. 3. Symbolum cordis ≈øignaculum e≈øt, & no≈øtrae militiae ≈øacramentum: the Symbole is the ≈øeale of the heart, and the ≈øacrament of our warfare.In Symb. And Ruffin, Nequa doli ≈øurreptio fiat, ≈øymbola di≈øcreta unu≈øqui≈øque dux ≈øuis militibus tradit, quae Latine vel ≈øigna vel indicia nominantur, ut ≈øi forte occurrerit quis de quo dubitetur, interrogatus ≈øymbolum prodat ≈øi ≈øit ho≈øtis an ≈øocius: le≈øt there ≈øhould be any ≈øurreption or deceit, euery captaine deliuereth vnto his Souldiers a di≈øtinct watchword, that if they meet with any of whom they doubt, by demanding the watchward they may di≈øcouer whether hee bee a friend or an enimy. And this hee accommodateth vnto the pre≈øent purpo≈øe. Now ≈øeing the Gentiles were wont to giue for their watchword the names of ≈øome of their Gods,Xenoph paed. l. 3. & 7. Pau≈øan. l. 10. Suet. Calig. c. 18. as
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Minerua, Iupiter, and the like: what fitter Symbole could Chri≈øtians haue, then their Faith in the holy & indiuiduall Trinity? And thus much of the title of the Creed: proceed wee yet further.

Be≈øides this Creed there are diuers others verie ancient, both Generall of the whole Church, ≈øuch as are tho≈øe foure famous ones of Nice, of Ephe≈øus, of Constantinople, of Chalcedon: and Particular, either of ≈øeuerall Churches, or of priuate men, among which that of Athana≈øius is mo≈øt renowned. All which though in forme of words they vary, yet for ≈øub≈øtance are all one, there being,Eph. 4.5. as S. Paul ≈øaith, but vna fides, one faith. Neither
yet was this number of Creeds needles or endles. For when here≈øies began to encrea≈øe and preuaile, the Church thought it nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øet forth ≈øome ≈øhort Confe≈ø≈øions, by which the people as by a touch≈øtone might di≈øcerne the gold of Orthodoxe truth from the copper of errors and here≈øies. Saith S. Hilarie, Nihil mirum videri debet, fratres chari≈øsimi, quod tam frequenter exponi fides caeptae ≈øint: nece≈øsitatem hanc furor haereticus imponit: you ought not to maruell much, beloued brethren, that nowadayes Creeds are ≈øo frequently ≈øet forth: the fury of hereticks hath layd this nece≈ø≈øity vpon vs. Thus again≈øt Arius denying the diuinity of Chri≈øt was the Nicene Creed framed: again≈øt Macedonius and Eudoxius denying the Deity of the holy Gho≈øt, and his proceeding from the Father and the Sonne; the Con≈øtantinopolitane: again≈øt Ne≈øtorius denying the vnion of both natures of Chri≈øt in one per≈øon, the Ephe≈øine: again≈øt Eutyches confounding both natures, and ≈øwallowing vp the humane, in the diuine, that of Chalcedon. Thus of late the reformed Churches to quit them≈øelues of the vniu≈øt imputations of here≈øie and apo≈øta≈øie wherewith they were charged, haue beene forced ≈øundrie times to ≈øet forth ≈øeuerall Confe≈ø≈øions of their Faith, all which, or mo≈øt of which are recorded in the harmonie of Confe≈ø≈øions. Scurrilous therefore is that taunt of Papi≈øts, who for this cau≈øe terme vs Confe≈ø≈øioni≈øts. For what haue we done herein, whereunto their ≈ølanderous criminations haue not compelled vs? what, whereof we haue, not example from the Primiue Church? Nay, what whereof we haue not Gods expre≈ø≈øe commandement,1 Pet. 3.16. charging vs to bee ready on euery occa≈øion to render an account of the Hope that is in vs?

But yet among all the ancient Creeds, this of the Apo≈øtles, hath euer beene counted of greate≈øt authority, and ought ≈øtill ≈øo to bee counted. Among the ancient Creeds I ≈øay: for the Scripture is peerles, and equall authority with it neither may it chalenge vnto it ≈øelfe, neither did any of the ancient Fathers giue it, as aboue wee haue touched. For although the ≈øub≈øtance and matter of the Creed be diuine and perfectly according with the Scripture, yet for forme and order of words it is humane: whereas the Scripture both for ≈øub≈øtance and circum≈øtance, matter and forme and all is no way humane, but wholly and entirely diuine. The greater the bla≈øphemie of Rhemi≈øh Ie≈øuites auouching this Creed to be the Rule whereby all the writings of the new Te≈øtament are to be tried,In Ro. 12.6. and approued: whereas contrarily the Scripture out of which the Creed is collected, is the only Rule by which both it and all other Creeds are to bee examined. Howbeit the ≈øecond place, as it is its due, ≈øo we willingly yeeld vnto it. Fir≈øt in regard of the antiquity thereof, becau≈øe of all other it is the elde≈øt. Secondly, for the perfection and fulnes thereof, there being no one article of ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity vnto Saluation, which is not either in expre≈ø≈øe tearmes or impliedly and in its principles contayned therein. Thirdly and la≈øtly, becau≈øe it hath had the vniuer≈øall approbation of all Churches, in all times, both ancient and moderne. The ancient Fathers giue vnto it mo≈øt honorable and magnificent titles. They call it, the key of Faith, the rule of Faith, the foundation of Faith, the ≈øumme of Faith, the forme of Faith, the body of Faith, the rule of truth, the ≈øacrament of humane ≈øaluation, the my≈øterie of religion, the character of the Church, and the like. On it they commented
rather then on any other Creed: vnto it all others were conformed, ≈øo as they ≈øeeme to be but expo≈øitions of it. Finally, it was their manner neuer to admit any that was adultus either to the Sacrament of Bapti≈øme, or to the holy Eucharist without making confe≈ø≈øion of his Faith by rehear≈øing this Creed. In like manner, all the reformed Churches with all reuerence and duty receiue it: they v≈øe it in their publick Liturgies, and expound it in their Catechi≈ømes. The more malitious is the ≈ølander of Gregorie Martin and others,Di≈øc. of Eng. tran≈ø. c. 12. who ≈øhame not to ≈øay that we hold not the Chri≈øtian Faith of the articles of the Creed. div.head: A SHORT CATECHISME.
div.p: QVae≈øt. Who placed you here in this World?
An≈ø. God the maker and Gouernour of all things.
Q. Wherefore did hee place you here?
A. To ≈øerue and glorify him.
Q. How will he be ≈øerued?
A. By doing his holy Will and Commandements.
Q. What Commandments hath hee giuen you?
A. The ten Commandements of the Morall law.
Q. Repeat them vnto me.
A. Heare I≈ørael, I am the Lord thy God, which &c.
Q. What duties doth God require of you in this law?
A. Two: to loue God aboue all, and my neighbour as my ≈øelfe.
Q. Haue you done this perfectly?

A. Very mi≈øerable vnle≈ø≈øe God bee mercifull in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt.
Q. What is Ie≈øus Chri≈øt?

Q. Wherefore was he made Man?

A. No, but true belieuers onely.
Q. Who are true Belieuers?
A. They who by faith accept him for their only Mediatour and Sauiour.
Q. How is this Faith wrought?
A. By the preaching of the Go≈øpell.
Q. What is the ≈øumme of the Go≈øpell?
A. It is contained in the Apo≈øtles Creed.
Q. Repeat the ≈øame vnto me.
A. I Belieue in God the Father Almighty, maker &c.
Q. How may we know that we haue true Faith?
A. By the fruites thereof.
Q. What are the fruites of Faith?
A. New Obedience and Repentance.
Q. What is new Obedience?
A. A ≈øincere practice of holyne≈ø≈øe and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe all the dayes of my life.
Q. Can you doe this perfectly?

Q. But what if you fall into ≈øinne againe?
A. I am to ri≈øe againe by ≈øpeedy repentance:

A. Becau≈øe if I bee preuented by death I peri≈øh eternally.

Q. What is a Sacrament?

Q. What is Bapti≈øme?

Q. What is the Lords Supper?

Q. What is the thing ≈øignified?

div.head: In≈øtructions for preparation vnto the holy COMMVNION.
div.p: Q. I ≈øee you are de≈øirous with the re≈øt of Gods people to bee admitted to the holy Communion: tell me for what cau≈øe are you ≈øo de≈øirous thereof?

A. I am de≈øirous thereof for two cau≈øes. Fir≈øt, that I may di≈øcharge my duty to God, who commandeth mee to receiue ≈øo often as conueniently I may: ≈øecondly that I may reap the benefit & comfort which God hath promi≈øed vnto mee thereby.

A. That as by Bapti≈øme my fir≈øt incorporation into the my≈øticall Body of Chri≈øt is already ≈øealed vp vnto me: ≈øo by this holy Sacrament my continuall nouri≈øhment and pre≈øeruation in the ≈øame Body ≈øhall likewi≈øe be ≈øealed vp vnto me.
Q. But doe all reape this benefit that receiue this Sacrament?
A. No, but the worthy receiuer only: for they that receiue vnworthily, eat and drinke to them≈øelues their owne damnation.
Q. What things are nece≈ø≈øarily required vnto worthy Receiuing?
A. Two things: ≈øufficient knowledge in the vnder≈øtanding, and ≈øanctifying grace in the heart.
Q. What knowledge count you ≈øufficient?

A. A knowledge of the law ≈øentencing vnto death for ≈øinne: ≈øecondly, a knowledge of the Go≈øpell promi≈øing euerla≈øting life vpon condition of Faith and true repentance: thirdly a knowledge of the Sacraments, and principally of the Sacrament of the Lords Supper.
Q. What knowledge is required touching the Lords Supper?

A. That the ≈øen≈øible ≈øignes v≈øed therein haue ≈øpirituall ≈øignifications: and therefore as the Mini≈øter hauing ble≈ø≈øed the bread and wine, breaketh the one and poureth out the other, and I receiuing them into my hands conuey them into my Body for the nouri≈øhmeÃÑt thereof: ≈øo God the Father hauing prede≈øtinated his Son to be our Mediator and Redeemer hath giuen his Body
to bee broken and his Blood to be ≈øhed for vs, that wee receiuing the ≈øame by Faith may thereby be nouri≈øhed both bodies and ≈øoules vnto euerla≈øting life.
Q. But what ≈øanctifying graces are required in the heart?

A. Fir≈øt true and vnfained repentance for ≈øinne: ≈øecondly a liuely Faith vpon the merits of Chri≈øt for remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øinne: thirdly ≈øincere loue and charity with our brethren: fourthly, renewed Faith and repentance for our new ≈øins, and renewed loue in regard of our new breaches with our brethren.

Q. Well then I ≈øee you know with what knowledge and grace you ought to bee furni≈øhed before you can worthily receiue: tell me now how mu≈øt you behaue your ≈øelfe during the time of admini≈øtring this Sacrament?

A. With feare and reuerence as in the pre≈øence of God who ≈øeeth the very ≈øecret of my heart: and therefore bani≈øhing out of my mind all earthly and impertinent thoughts, I am onely and wholly to attend this heauenly action.

A. Fir≈øt, I am humbly to thanke Almighty God who hath vouch≈øafed to receiue mee as a gue≈øt at his holy Table: ≈øecondly, I am to pray vnto God that pardoning my want of due preparation and all other my infirmities hee would ble≈ø≈øe this holy Sacrament to the nouri≈øhment of my ≈øoule: thirdly, I am carefully to v≈øe all other meanes ordained by God whereby I may ≈øtill grow forward in grace till I come to be a perfect man in Chri≈øt.
