Though all things be pure, yet is it euill to eat with offence. When wee ≈øo ≈øin again≈øt the Brethren and wound their weake con≈øcience, we ≈øinne again≈øt Chri≈øt. 1. Cor. 8.13.14. Wherefore S. Paul re≈øolued rather then by eating he would offend his brother he would not eat fle≈øh while the world ≈øtandeth.

10. Secondly, by Temperance and Sobriety. For repletion and fulne≈ø≈øe nouri≈øh in vs our inordinate lu≈øts, and make vs like pampered hor≈øes grow head-≈øtrong and vnruly.Rom. 13.13. Wee may not therefore abu≈øe our liberty vnto ≈øurfetting and drunkenne≈ø≈øe: yea if wee find that ≈øome meats or drinks, though not exce≈ø≈øiuely taken, doe inflame our lu≈øts, wee mu≈øt ab≈øtaine. And this was the cau≈øe,2. Cor. 6.6. as I ≈øuppo≈øe, why the Apo≈øtle Saint Paul knits the≈øe two together, in Fa≈øting, in Cha≈øtity. For according to the old ≈øaying, Sine Cerere & Baccho friget Venus, without bread and wine venery and lu≈øt waxeth cold.

11. And here I cannot but wonder at the vanity and peruer≈øne≈ø≈øe of Romani≈øts, who for the ≈øubduing and taming of the fle≈øh, at times forbid the eating of fle≈øh, but in the meane ≈øea≈øon giue leaue to feed on all ≈øorts of fi≈øhes, marmelades, and con≈øerues, and to drinke the ≈øtronge≈øt and choice≈øt wines, which without que≈øtion prouoke and ≈øtirre vp lu≈øt as well as fle≈øh. As if to eat a bit of cour≈øe fle≈øh vpon a prohibited day were gluttony: but to cram our ≈øelues with all other delicates were ab≈øtinence and fa≈øting. O blindne≈ø≈øe! O ≈øtupidity!

12 Thirdly by Piety and Religion. For although Ab≈øtinence as Hierome ≈øaith, bee not in it ≈øelfe a vertue, nor any part of Diuine wor≈øhip, yet is it an in≈øtrument, help, and furtherance thereunto. And therefore if wee would humble our≈øelues by repentance, or pray vnto God with feruency for the auerting of dangers imminent, or calamities incumbent vpon vs: we are then by fa≈øting to te≈øtify our humiliation, and to quicken our deuotion, as wee read the faithfull both vnder the Law and Go≈øpell were euer wont to doe.

13. La≈øtly by Loialtie and Dutifull ≈øubiection. For if the Magi≈øtrate, either for a publick ciuill good ≈øhall at times forbid the v≈øe of ≈øome meats, as of fle≈øh on fridayes, ≈øaturdayes, emberweeks, lent, and the like, or for the pacifying of Gods wrath in the common calamity of the ≈øtate, ≈øhall command a generall Fa≈øt: wee are accordingly to ab≈øtaine,Rom. 13.6. and to yeeld obedience vnto the Magi≈øtrate, not only for feare, but al≈øo for Con≈øcience ≈øake.

14. Thus then fir≈øt you haue Libertie by Chri≈øt to eate of all kind of meats: ≈øecondly, you are bound to ≈øtand fa≈øt in your Liberty and not to put your ≈øelfe vnder bondage againe: thirdly, you may not wantonlie abu≈øe you liberty by doing ≈øuch things as are inconuenient, and hurt rather then edifie: la≈øtly, our v≈øe thereof mu≈øt be moderated and directed by Charity, Temperance, Piety and Loyalty. This if you know, and thus if you doe, you cannot erre nor doe ami≈ø≈øe.

15. Which that you may both know and doe you are to pray him that is the donor and giuer of all good things, to make you both wi≈øe and prudent. Wi≈øe in the knowledge and practice of what≈øoeuer is of ab≈øolute nene≈ø≈øity vnto ≈øaluation: prudent in the di≈øcretion and right v≈øe of things indifferent. This God grant you for his Chri≈øts ≈øake. Amen.

div.head: AN ANSWER VNTO CERTAINE REASONS FOR SEPARATION.
div.p:
I Could haue wi≈øhed withall my hart that in this particular I might haue proued a fal≈øe prophet: and that my feares concerning you, though they were not without cau≈øe, yet might haue been without effect. But now I plainly perceiue that my words were no le≈ø≈øe then oracle, and what I feared is accordingly come to pa≈ø≈øe. For, as I foretold you, from ≈øtrayning at gnats, you are fallen to ≈øwallowing of Camels: that is, from ≈øcrupulou≈ønes and nicenes in Kneeling at the Communion, and other ≈øuch like indifferent ceremonies, you haue head-longly ca≈øt your ≈øelfe into the gulfe of Schi≈øme and Separation. In regard whereof, hauing heretofore in the matter of Kneeling be≈øtowed my labour in vaine vpon you, I feare, now that you are thus farre proceeded, and ≈øetled as it were on your lees, I ≈øhall much le≈ø≈øe preuayle with you. Neuertheles, becau≈øe it plea≈øed you to ≈øend me in writing the rea≈øons of your Separation, promi≈øing to returne with all ≈øpeed if they were ≈øufficiently an≈øwered:
I may not, vnle≈ø≈øe I will betray the truth, and faile in the duties of Charity, refu≈øe to take a little further paines with you. Here therefore I ≈øend you this ≈øhort, and, as I conceiue, full an≈øwer: the peru≈øall whereof I leaue vnto you, the cen≈øure vnto Gods Church, and the i≈ø≈øue vnto God him≈øelfe. Whom I humbly be≈øeech of his goodne≈ø≈øe eft≈øoones to reduce you.

Two grounds you ≈øay there are whereon you haue built your Separation: the fir≈øt whereof you lay downe in the≈øe tearmes, That the Hierarchie and Mini≈øtrie of Arch-bi≈øhops, Lord Bi≈øhops, &c. and Priests may not bee ≈øet ouer the Church of Christ, nor retained therein. From whence, as I vnder≈øtand it, you would argue and conclude thus.

argument.p: Where are ≈øuch Church Officers as may not bee ≈øet ouer nor retained in the Church, there is no true vi≈øible Church, and con≈øequently Separation mu≈øt bee made from it.
But here in England are ≈øuch Church Officers, as Arch-bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops &c. and Prie≈øts.
Ergo, here in England is no true vi≈øible Church, and con≈øequently Separation mu≈øt bee made from it.

div.p:
To this argument thus formed I an≈øwer, fir≈øt by denying the Maior Propo≈øition: which in that you goe not about to proue, you commit that fault in rea≈øoning which Logicians call Petitionem Principij, taking that for granted which is mo≈øt que≈øtioned. For ≈øuppo≈øe that Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, and Prie≈øts were ≈øuperfluous officers, yet it is not euery ≈øuperfluity in a Church that takes away the nature and e≈ø≈øence thereof: and euen they who mi≈ølike the pre≈øent Church gouernement, doe not
all of them, as you Separati≈øts doe, inferre thereupon a nullity, but onely a corruption or aberration in the Church. It would haue beene much more to the purpo≈øe, if you could haue demon≈øtrated that the Church of England is defectiue in ≈øuch officers as are e≈ø≈øentiall, and without which a Church cannot be. Here therefore I mu≈øt entreat you either to acknowledge your ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe, or el≈øe to be≈øtow a little more paines in the proofe of that which without euidence of rea≈øon will neuer be yeelded you.

Againe I deny the Minor Propo≈øition, affirming contrarily that Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, and Prie≈øts are lawfull Church-Officers, and may bee both ≈øet ouer and retained in the Church. For I hope you vnder≈øtand the≈øe tearmes not cauillingly and equiuocally, but according to the meaning and definition of the Church of England. Otherwi≈øe you ≈øhall but iangle about words, and bewray that you haue more de≈øire to picke quarels, then ability to iu≈øtify your Separation. But you endeauour to fortify your Minor by twelue rea≈øons ≈øupplying in the tale if ought bee wanting in the weight. Let vs examine them ≈øeuerally. The fir≈øt is this.

argument.p: 1 No Antichristian mini≈øtrie may bee ≈øet ouer the Church of Chri≈øt, nor retained therein.2. The≈ø. 2.3.4.11.12. Ro. 14.9 10. with Ex. 4.5. Deut. 7.26. P≈ø. 119.21.128.

But the Mini≈øtrie of Arch-bi≈øhops, Lord-Bi≈øhops & Prie≈øts is Antichristian, becau≈øe the Churches of Antichrist cannot bee compleate, if they haue not this Prelacy, as appeareth by the Popes Canons and Pontificall, and by their Church-Con≈øtitution.
Therefore they are not to bee ≈øet ouer the Church of Christ, nor retained therein.

div.p:
What meane you by the word Antichri≈øtian? For although I know well what properly it ≈øignifies, yet I doubt much what you vnder≈øtand thereby: it being your manner either through negligence or ignorance too often to ≈øpeake improperly. If you vnder≈øtand it properly, and as you ought, for that which is again≈øt Chri≈øt and his ordinance, or, as your men ≈øometimes expre≈ø≈øe them≈øelues, which is a ≈øpeciall part of Antichri≈øts apo≈øta≈øie, then I yeeld you your Maior, and confe≈ø≈øe that no ≈øuch Mini≈øtrie may bee ≈øet ouer the Church nor retained therein. But if you meane thereby either that which was fir≈øt in≈øtituted and deuized by Antichri≈øt, or that which being formerly in≈øtituted is v≈øed and approued in the Church of Antichri≈øt, then I deny the Maior. For fir≈øt, euery thing (by Antichri≈øt ordained) is not pre≈øently vnlawfull and Antichri≈øtian, no more then euery act of a tyrant is vniu≈øt and tyrannous. How many good and whole≈øome lawes were enacted vnder the raigne of Richard the third, who yet was a mo≈øt bloody and cruell tyrant? Neither were they afterward repealed by ≈øucceeding Kings, but ≈øtand ≈øtill in force notwith≈øtanding
his tyranny: for they proceeded from him non qu√† tyrannus, not as hee was a tyrant, but as hee was a wi≈øe and politicke gouernour. In like manner, not euery thing ordained by Antichri≈øt is foorthwith to bee reiected, but onely that which hee doth qu√† Antichristus, as hee is Antichri≈øt, and is meerely Antichri≈øtian. It is a great folly to refu≈øe good coun≈øell becau≈øe it is giuen by an euill man. Wi≈øe men will con≈øider non quis ≈øed quid, not ≈øo much who doth a thing, as what is done. For as truth is Gods in who≈øe mouth ≈øoeuer it bee found: ≈øo is good al≈øo who≈øoeuer bee the Author thereof. Againe, if tho≈øe things whereof Antichri≈øt is the fir≈øt founder bee not therefore by and by vnlawfull, much le≈ø≈øe are tho≈øe things ≈øo, which being of a former in≈øtitution are onely v≈øed and ob≈øerued by him. Were it otherwi≈øe, how many ordinances of God him≈øelfe, and whole≈øome con≈øtitutions of the primitiue Church would proue vnlawfull being ≈øtill retained in Popery?

This Maior you endeauour to fortify with ≈øundry pa≈ø≈øages of Scripture. But as Ca≈øsius of old was wont to ≈øay, Cui bono? to what end? For if you would proue it in the ≈øen≈øe granted you, they are alledged needle≈øly: if in the ≈øen≈øe denied, friuolou≈øly; and to ≈øpeake the truth euery way vainely and impertinently, as the very reading of them will manife≈øt to any one that will but take the paines to peru≈øe them. But this is the manner of your men to paint your margents with multitude of quotations nothing to the purpo≈øe: whereas one allegation directly concluding is more then a hundred demon≈øtrations, as being the words of the fir≈øt and infallible verity. What you intend hereby I wot not, whether to amu≈øe the Reader and ouerwhelme him with your numbers, or
to win you credit and e≈øtimation with the vulgar, as if you were the onely skilfull Text-men. But ≈øure I am that ≈øuch ≈øleighting of Scripture is no le≈ø≈øe then the taking of Gods Name in vaine: which who≈øoeuer doth, the Lord profe≈ø≈øeth he will not hold him guiltle≈øse. Scripture is not made nor appointed for pompe and ≈øhew, but for conque≈øt and victory.

To the Minor Propo≈øition I an≈øwer negatiuely, The mini≈øtrie of Arch-bi≈øhops, Lord-Bi≈øhops, and Prie≈øts is not Antichri≈øtian, whether you vnder≈øtand it as fir≈øt inuented by Antichri≈øt, or again≈øt Chri≈øt. That it is not of Antichri≈øts inuention is as cleere as the Sunne. For fir≈øt Prie≈øts are of diuine in≈øtitution, being no other then tho≈øe Presbyters or Pa≈øtors, to whom the admini≈øtration of the Word and Sacraments is committed, and who are ordained by Chri≈øt for the building vp of his Church vnto the end of the world. The Prie≈øts of the Church of Rome indeed are of Antichri≈øts founding, who≈øe office is to ≈øacrifice and offer vp Chri≈øt him≈øelfe in the Ma≈ø≈øe vnto his Father both for the quicke and the dead. But our Prie≈øts haue nothing common with them ≈øaue the name onely: their idolatry wee dete≈øt and abhorre, although wee retaine the name. Theirs are Ma≈ø≈øe-Prie≈øts, ours are Preaching or Mini≈øtring Prie≈øts. Neither let the name offend you: for notwith≈øtanding Papi≈øts haue abu≈øed it to ≈øignifie a Sacrificer, yet properly it doth not ≈øo, being originally deriued from Presbyter, neither among vs is it now ≈øo vnder≈øtood. To ≈øay nothing that the ancieÃÑt Fathers (who I pre≈øume were not Antichri≈øtian) v≈øually call the Mini≈øters of the Go≈øpell Sacerdotes, Prie≈øts. As therefore you cannot without great ab≈øurdity rea≈øon from the name to the thing, thus, your Ministers
are called Prie≈øts, Ergo, your Mini≈øtrie is Antichri≈øtian: ≈øo neither can you without greater ab≈øurdity ≈øeparate your ≈øelfe from the thing becau≈øe of the name, and becau≈øe our Mini≈øters are called Prie≈øts withdraw your ≈øelfe from our Mini≈øtrie.

Secondly, Arch-bi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops if they be not of diuine in≈øtitution, yet were they ≈øome Centuries of yeeres before euer Antichri≈øt appeared in the world, as all antiquity and Eccle≈øia≈øticall Story te≈øtifieth. That mo≈øt famous fir≈øt generall Councell of Nice a≈ø≈øembled by Con≈øtantin the Great about the yeere of our Lord 327 not onely approueth them, but al≈øo affirmeth that the Church anciently and long before that time had been gouerned by them. Epiphanius & Augu≈øtin both reckon Aerius among the number of Hereticks, for denying the then-receiued and allowed di≈øtinction between a Bi≈øhop and a Presbyter. But to ≈øpeake my mind plainely, I am for my part per≈øwaded, that the ≈øuperiority of Bi≈øhops ouer the Mini≈øters was of Apo≈øtolicall in≈øtitution. Tho≈øe Angels to whom Saint Iohn in the ≈øecond and third of the Reuelation is commanded to write, what other were they then the Bi≈øhops of tho≈øe Churches of A≈øia? In Ephe≈øus, one of tho≈øe ≈øeuen Churches, it is reported by S. Luke that there were many Presbyters, and I doubt not but it was ≈øo in other of the Churches al≈øo: howbeit the Apo≈øtle writeth vnto one onely whom hee calleth the Angell, as being ≈øingular and eminent aboue the re≈øt. And the ancient ≈øtory of the Church recordeth the particular Bi≈øhops of euery one of tho≈øe Churches together with their ≈øucce≈ø≈øors for a long time. So that Bi≈øhops being in the Apo≈øtles time, and ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuely continued in the Primitiue Church, without any contradiction either
of the Apo≈øtles them≈øelues or any other, yea rather with their approbation and allowance, as appeareth by tho≈øe ≈øeuen Epi≈øtles vnto the ≈øeuen Angels, and all the writings of the ancient Fathers: how can it bee imagined but that Bi≈øhops and their ≈øuperiority ouer others was of Apo≈øtolicall in≈øtitution?

Now if Prie≈øts or Pastors (for as wee haue ≈øayd, in ≈øub≈øtance they be all one) were ordained by God him≈øelfe, and Bi≈øhops deriue their pedigree al≈øo from the holy Apostles of God: it followeth by nece≈ø≈øary con≈øequence, that as our Mini≈øtery is not from Antichrist, ≈øo neither is it again≈øt Chri≈øt. Were it again≈øt Chri≈øt, it would be either becau≈øe he hath forbidden it, or for that it de≈øtroyeth rather then edifieth the Church. But it is no where forbidden. If it bee, ≈øhew the place, and wee yeeld. Neither doth it hinder the edification of the Church. For fir≈øt it is the office both of Bi≈øhops & Prie≈øts to preach the Go≈øpell of Chri≈øt, and to admini≈øter his holy Sacraments. Secondly, the aduancement of one Pre≈øbyter aboue the re≈øt, was for the preuention of Schi≈øme. For when Factions began to ari≈øe in the Church, ≈øome ≈øaying I am of Paul, others I am of Apollos, I am of Cephas: then, ≈øayth Hierom, was it decreed through the whole world, that one being cho≈øen from among the Pre≈øbyters ≈øhould be ≈øet ouer the re≈øt. Who being ≈øo preferred, his duty is to ouer≈øee the re≈øt of his brethren, that they carefully di≈øcharge the office impo≈øed vpon them, and frame their liues according to the worthines of their calling: All which I am ≈øure furthereth the building of the Church, ≈øo farre is it from de≈øtroying: ≈øo that nor Prie≈øts nor Bi≈øhops, whether yee regard their offices, or the end of their ordination, can be ≈øayd to be again≈øt Chri≈øt.

Peraduenture (for I would willingly let nothing pa≈ø≈øe vnan≈øwered) there lies a mi≈øtery in the word Lord-Bi≈øhops, and you intend that they are the more Antichri≈øtian for that they are ≈øo called. Surely if they ≈øhould ambitiou≈øly affect the title of Lord, Mat. 23. as the Phari≈øees ≈øomtimes did the title of Rabbi, it were great pride and vanity in them: and if they ≈øhould „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Lord it, and as it were domineere ouer the flock of Chri≈øt as if the inheritance were theirs, it would be intollerable pre≈øumption & tyranny. But, that a title of honour may be giuen vnto Bi≈øhops in regard of their honorable place and calling, as there is no rea≈øon to the contrary, ≈øo it mu≈øt needs proceed from much enuie or frowardne≈ø≈øe to deny.Gen. 31.35. 1 King. 18.7.13. Let it not bee di≈øplea≈øing in the eyes of my Lord, ≈øaith Rahel to her Father. Art not thou my Lord Elias? And againe, Was it not told my Lord what I did when Iezebel flew the Prophets of the Lord, ≈øaid good Obadiah vnto the Prophet? If Laban becau≈øe he was a naturall Father vnto Rahel, and Eliah, becau≈øe hee was a Prophet might iu≈øtly bee ≈øo ≈øtiled: why may not Bi≈øhops al≈øo, who are the ≈øpirituall Fathers, and Prophets, yea and Angels of the Church?Luc. 22.25.26. you will ≈øay, our Sauiour expre≈øly forbiddeth them to bee called Gratious Lords. I deny it. For although it plea≈øed the tran≈ølator ≈øo to render the originall word „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , becau≈øe anciently it was a title of honour giuen vnto Princes: yet doth it not properly ≈øignify ≈øo, but Benefactors, or Wel-doers. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe ≈øuppo≈øe it ≈øo ≈øignified, yet is it not ≈øimply the title, but the ambitious affectation of the title which Chri≈øt di≈øliketh.Act. 10.38. If a man imitating Ie≈øus Chri≈øt ≈øhould goe about „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
doing good, were it a ≈øinne trow you to giue him his de≈øerued name and to call him „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ a wel-doer?
Had it been ≈øimply vnlawfull for a Mini≈øter to be called Lord, would Paul and Silas haue admitted it, and not rather haue reprehended the keeper of the pri≈øon ≈øaying vnto them, My Lords, Act. 16.30. what ought I to doe that I may bee ≈øaued? Our Sauiour Chri≈øt ≈øaith vnto his di≈øciples, Bee not yee called Ma≈øters, Bee not yee called Doctors: Mat. 23.8.10. and yet among you ≈øome Mini≈øters are called Doctors, and all Ma≈øters. So that it appeareth by your owne practice, that the name of Lord maketh not Bi≈øhops Antichri≈øtian, but as wee haue ≈øaid, it is the affecting of the name which is forbidden. And thus you ≈øee your Minor is no way true.

Notwith≈øtanding you endeauour to proue it thus, Becau≈øe the Churches of Antichri≈øt cannot be compleate without this Prelacy, as appeareth, you ≈øay, by the Popes Canons, and Pontificall, and by their Church-con≈øtitutions. A ≈øeely and ≈øory argument. For fir≈øt, the Mini≈øtrie of the Church of England is ≈øo farre from being a complement of the Churches of Antichri≈øt, that the Church of Rome doth Anathematize and accur≈øe it, e≈øteeming vs (right as you doe) to bee no Church at all becau≈øe wee want their Mini≈øtry. Againe, may not I with as good rea≈øon as you argue thus? The ≈øtate and Kingdome of Antichri≈øt cannot be compleate without the authority of Ciuill Magi≈øtrates: Ergo, Ciuill Magi≈øtrates are Antichri≈øtian. If this kinde of rea≈øoning bee not good, neither is yours; for they are both of one mould. La≈øtly Antichri≈øtianity being a My≈øterie, and not an Heathni≈øh or Turki≈øh oppo≈øition vnto Chri≈øt, it cannot be compleate except it retaine many of Chri≈øts ordinances, which therefore I tru≈øt you will not ≈øay to bee Antichri≈øtian. A lie cannot ≈øub≈øi≈øt but vpon truth, nor euill but in good:
nor Antichri≈øts hypocri≈øie but vpon the Religion and di≈øcipline of Chri≈øt. And thus haue I fully an≈øwered your fir≈øt argument: whereon I haue been the longer becau≈øe it is the Ba≈øis and ground as it were of all the re≈øt, and the an≈øwer thereunto will in a manner ≈øerue them all, or the mo≈øt part of them. Your ≈øecond argument is this.

argument.p: 2 Becau≈øe it cannot be approued by the testament of Chri≈øt, as the Mini≈øtrie had in his Church may and ought to bee.Eph. 4.11.12. 1. Cor. 12.4.5.6.28.29. Ro. 12.7.8. 1. Tim. 3. & 5.3.9.17. & 6.13.14. And if ≈øuch (as could not proue by their genealogie that they were of Aaron) were depo≈øed from their Mini≈øtrie under Mo≈øes LawEzr. 2.62.63. Heb. 3.2.3. & 2.1.2.3. & 12.25., much more ≈øhould ≈øuch bee now depo≈øed, as haue not their offices warranted by Chri≈øts Te≈øtament.

div.p:
If wee reduce your argument into forme it is this, That Mini≈øtrie which cannot bee approued by the Testament of Christ is not to bee allowed in the Church. But the Mini≈øtrie of the Church of England cannot bee approued by the Te≈øtament of Chri≈øt. Ergo, it is not to bee allowed in the Church. The Minor which you might be ≈øure we would deny, you haue left naked to the wide world without proofe: the Maior which you ≈øaw wee could not well deny, you endeauour to fortifie with a double rea≈øon. Let it be ≈øuppo≈øed then that it is denied how proue you it? Fir≈øt, The Ministerie had in the Church may and ought to bee ≈øo approued. How doth this appeare? By the places quoted in the margent? Nothing le≈ø≈øe: They approue indeed certaine officers in the Church: but affirme not that euery officer ought to bee ≈øo approued. Secondly, if, ≈øay you, ≈øuch as could not deriue their genealogy from Aaron were depo≈øed, much more are they to be
depo≈øed who cannot warrant their offices by Christs Testament. A poore argument God wot. For in the law there was an expre≈ø≈øe commandment that none might execute the Prie≈øts office but hee that was of the linage of Aaron: but that no office might bee admitted nor retained in the Church vnle≈ø≈øe it were ≈øo commanded, I find no where in Scripture. Wherefore to argue thus, Nothing that is against Gods Word may bee allowed, Ergo, nor any thing that is not commanded, is a plaine Non ≈øequitur, and it followes not. Thus you ≈øee, if a man were ≈øo di≈øpo≈øed, how ea≈øie it is to quarell with your Maior, which yet ≈øimply I deny not.

Briefly therefore to cleare all, I di≈øtingui≈øh of the≈øe tearmes, Approued and Warranted by the Word. A thing may bee ≈øaid to bee warranted or approued by the Word two wayes, both when it is commanded, and when it is not forbidden: for things neither commanded nor forbidden, are indifferent, and ≈øubiect vnto the Churches power. Hereupon thus I an≈øwer, if you meane it in the former ≈øence only, then proue your Maior that what is not by commandment approued is vnlawfull: if in the latter then I grant you the Maior, that what≈øoeuer is forbidden is vnlawfull. But withall I deny the Minor, that Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, Prie≈øts are forbidden, requiring you to proue it, which I know you can neuer doe. For as touching ≈øo much of their dutie as is common to them all, to wit, the preaching of the Word, and the admini≈øtration of the Sacraments, they are all Pa≈øtors and Teachers, and ≈øo warranted in the Texts by you quoted: but in regard of preeminence and ≈øuperiority one aboue another Bi≈øhops are no other then were the Angels of the ≈øeuen Churches, as wee haue aboue demon≈øtrated.
How≈øoeuer, if Bi≈øhops bee not commanded, yet are they not forbidden: and their office making not again≈øt edification, but for it rather, it cannot being ordained by the Church but be lawfull. Your third argument.

argument.p: 3 Becau≈øe the Church is the Spou≈øe, Kingdome and Body of Chri≈øt, and therefore may not haue Antichri≈øts Hierarchie and mini≈øtrie ≈øet ouer it, or retained in it. For what concord hath Chri≈øt with Beliall?

div.p:
Antichri≈øts Hierarchie and Mini≈øtrie may not be≈øet ouer the Church nor retained in it. Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, Prie≈øts, are Antichri≈øts Hierarchie and Mini≈øtrie. Ergo, Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, Priests, may not bee ≈øet ouer the Church nor retained in it. The Maior of this Syllogi≈øme you are very carefull to maintaine, becau≈øe the Church is the Spou≈øe, the Kingdome, the Body of Chri≈øt: as al≈øo becau≈øe there can bee no concord betwixt Chri≈øt and Belial. But to what end all this? and with ≈øuch a ≈øtirre to proue that which no man gain≈øayes? for wee confe≈ø≈øe Chri≈øts Kingdome may not be gouerned by Antichri≈øts policie. You ≈øhould rather haue laboured to ≈øtrengthen the Minor, that Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, and Prie≈øts are Antichri≈øts Hierarchie and Ministrie: for you might be well a≈ø≈øured wee would neuer yeeld you that vnle≈ø≈øe by ≈øtrength of rea≈øon you con≈øtrained vs. Here therefore again≈øt the rule of Logicke againe you beg the principall matter in que≈øtion, taking for granted that tho≈øe offices are meerely Antichri≈øtian. But you mu≈øt proue it, and not looke that what≈øoeuer you fancie to be true, others vpon your bare word mu≈øt pre≈øently belieue and
take to bee true. See the an≈øwer to the fir≈øt argument. I proceed to the fourth.

argument.p: 4 If when a King ≈øub≈øtituteth Iudges, Iu≈øtices &c. no ≈øubiects may either refu≈øe to bee gouerned by the≈øe, or ≈øet ouer them≈øelues officers of other Kingdomes, as the Roman tribunes &c. how can it be lawfull for any Christians? &c.

div.p:
It is an old ≈øaying that Symbolical diuinitie is no argumeÃÑt of proofe: and that Similitudes ≈øerue rather to illu≈øtrate and cleare a mans meaning, then to proue and conuince the vnder≈øtanding. In regard whereof if I had ≈øo plea≈øed, I might well haue ≈øleighted this fourth rea≈øon, and not haue vouch≈øafed it any an≈øwere at all. For what is it other then a bare and naked Similitude? neuertheles for further ≈øatisfaction let vs trie the ≈øtrength thereof. Two things you auouch, fir≈øt that Chri≈øtians may not refu≈øe to bee gouerned by tho≈øe officers which Chri≈øt hath ≈øet ouer them: ≈øecondly, that Chri≈øtians may not ≈øet ouer them≈øelues officers of Antichri≈øts kingdome. The former I confe≈ø≈øe is true, but nothing to the purpo≈øe. For we reiect not the officers ordained by Chri≈øt, nor refu≈øe to be gouerned by them. If we doe, ≈øo haue all Churches al≈øo done, downe from S. Iohns time vnto this pre≈øent age. within which compa≈ø≈øe you caÃÑnot name any one Church at any time moulded after your platforme: and I am ≈øure all orthodoxall Churches haue euer beene gouerned by the ≈øame officers that ours is. Whence it followeth that if for want of ≈øuch a Politie and ≈øuch Officers as you dreame of we haue in England no true Church: neither hath there beene for certaine hundred of yeares aboue a
thou≈øand any true Church through the whole world. Which how it can agree with the word of God affirming that of his kingdome there ≈øhall be none end, I cannot conceiue. For by your reckoning the kingdome of Chri≈øt cea≈øed ≈øoone after the departure of the Apo≈øtles, and ≈øuffered an interruption of about fourteen hundred yeares vntill Browne and Barrow began to play the Schi≈ømatickes.

The ≈øecond Propo≈øition I acknowledge al≈øo to be true but withall denie that we haue ≈øet ouer our ≈øelues any Antichri≈øtian or forraigne Officers. For as we haue aboue both ≈øayd and ≈øhewed, Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, Priests are of diuine in≈øtitution: and now I further adde that they were fir≈øt bred in the kingdome of Chri≈øt, and not taken from any other kingdome. your a≈ø≈øertion to the contrary without due proofe argues that you build to your ≈øelfe ca≈øtles in the aire, and haue no ground for your pre≈øumption. Your fift argument followeth.

argument.p: 5. Becau≈øe the Church being Chri≈øts ≈øpou≈øe, kingdome, and body mu≈øt haue his Mini≈øtrie ≈øet and kept in it, and no other. And if no man can make a finger or the lea≈øt member of a naturall humane body, or adde any other limme thereto without deformity then God hath created, and can much le≈ø≈øe giue life to any ≈øuch counterfait member of his owne making: how is it po≈øsible that he can ≈øet vp another Mini≈øtrie?

div.p:
1. Cor. 12.12.20 27.28.The argument is thus to bee formed, The Ministrie of Christ and no other is to be ≈øet ouer and kept in the Church. The Mini≈øtrie of Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, and Priests is not Christs. Ergo, it is not to be ≈øet ouer nor kept in the Church.
The Maior I grant confe≈ø≈øing that no office may bee allowed in the Church but that which is from Chri≈øt, eyther immediately, or mediatly, that is, from tho≈øe vnto who≈øe wi≈ødome and di≈øcretion hee hath delegated ≈øome part of his authority to order many things in the Church. For as the Church may not alter that Mini≈øtry which Chri≈øt hath ≈øetled to continue for euer: ≈øo may ≈øhee by vertue of her delegate authority ordaine ≈øuch offices as are not forbidden, and tend to edification. And being ≈øo ordeined they are though not immediatly, yet mediately from Chri≈øt. Neither yet doth the Church ≈øo doing pre≈øume to make (as you ≈øay) either a finger, or any other member or limme that is e≈ø≈øentiall vnto the body, much le≈ø≈øe to giue life thereunto: but onely to prouide a gloue as it were for the finger, or a ≈øute of apparell for the body the better to pre≈øerue it in life.

The Minor that the Ministrie of Archbi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, and Priests is not of Christ, I deny, affirming the cleane contrary, that they are tho≈øe Pa≈øtors and Angels authorized and allowed by Chri≈øt in his word. It is the greate≈øt vanity and idlene≈ø≈øe that can bee in di≈øputing, onely with boldne≈ø≈øe to affirme that which is denied, and neuer to endeauour the proofe thereof: which yet is your ≈øolemne fault almo≈øt in euery argument. Your ≈øixt rea≈øon.

argument.p: 6 Becau≈øe Chri≈øtians are the Temples of the Holy Ghost,1. Cor. 3.16.17. 2. Cor. 6.16. 2. The≈ø. 2.4. Col. 2.18. Act. 20.17.28. and their con≈øciences wrought vpon by Mini≈øtrie in the Church: and therefore may not be defiled by the Hierarchie of Arch-bi≈øhops &c. whom the Holy Gho≈øt neuer made Ouer≈øeers.

div.p:
The argument in forme ≈øtands thus, Tho≈øe offices that
defile the Temples of the Holy Ghost and con≈øciences of men may not bee ≈øet ouer nor retained in the Church. But the Hierarchie of Arch-bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, and Prie≈øts defiles the Temples of the Holy Ghost and con≈øciences of men. Ergo, the Hierarchie of Arch-bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, and Priests may not bee ≈øet ouer nor retained in the Church. The Maior wee readily yeeld you: but how proue you the Minor, that the≈øe Officers defile the Con≈øcience? For≈øooth becau≈øe the Holy Gho≈øt hath not made them Ouer≈øeers. argument.p: 7 Becau≈øe Chri≈øt alone is the Head of the Church in whom all fulne≈ø≈øe of power dwelleth,Eph. 1.22.23.4.11.16. Col. 1.18.19.2.8.9.10.18.19.1. Cor. 12.4.5.6.12.27.28. 1. Tim. 3. & 5.8.6.13.14. div.p: It is true, there is but one Head of the Church from whom ≈øhee receiueth life and Power: yet are there al≈øo vnder Chri≈øt gouernors in the Church, who by vertue of that power which they haue receiued from him may ordaine many things touching the well gouernment thereof, and to ≈øubmit our ≈øelues thereunto is not to bee ≈øubiect to another power or head, but to the ordinance of Chri≈øt him≈øelfe. Rev. 14.6.7.8. &. 17. &. 18. &. 19. if our Mini≈øtrie were Antichri≈øtian, how by retaining it wee ≈øhould wor≈øhip the Roman Empire. The eleuenth argument.

argument.p: 11 Becau≈øe all are ≈øtraitly bound and charged by the Lord to depart from and witne≈øse again≈øt the afore≈øaid Prelacy and Prie≈øt-hood being a ≈øtrange Ministrie, and ≈øuch as is oppo≈øed again≈øt and exalted aboue the holy ordinance and Mini≈øtrie of Chri≈øt, and ≈øhall be aboli≈øhed by him appearing in the light and power of the Go≈øpell.

div.p:
Our Mini≈øtrie neither is a ≈øtrange Mini≈øtrie, nor oppo≈øed
or exalted aboue Chri≈øts Mini≈øtrie, but Chri≈øts owne Mini≈øtrie, as now once againe I tell you: and therefore no man is charged either to depart from it, or to witne≈ø≈øe again≈øt it. As for that you ≈øay our Mini≈øtrie ≈øhall bee aboli≈øhed by Chri≈øt appearing in the light and power of the Go≈øpell, it bewrayes what you de≈øire ≈øhould bee, but is no certaine Oracle of what indeed ≈øhall be. Your ob≈øtinate begging of the principall matter in que≈øtion conuinceth you to bee but a bad di≈øputant, and this ra≈øh and vnadui≈øed prediction now dubbeth you for a fal≈øe Prophet al≈øo. div.p:
Here againe you take for granted that our Mini≈øtrie is but a fal≈øe Mini≈øtrie, and that Arch-bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops,
and Prie≈øts are no le≈ø≈øe Antichri≈øtian then Abbots, Friers, Nuns, Cardinals, which is euer denied but neuer confirmed by you. Vaine man, proue our Mini≈øtrie to bee fal≈øe, and wee will grant it is to be rooted out: otherwi≈øe outfacing and de≈øperate a≈ø≈øeueration will not ≈øerue the turne.

And thus haue I briefly examined all your twelue rea≈øons whereby you goe about to proue the Minor of your principall Syllogi≈øme, namely that our Church-officers Arch-bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops and Prie≈øts are not to be ≈øet ouer nor retained in the Church. Whereupon I inferre, ≈øeeing your Maior is barely affirmed being vntrue, and your Minor ≈øo weakly and in≈øufficiently proued: you haue not as yet ≈øoundly concluded the lawfulne≈ø≈øe and nece≈ø≈øity of your ≈øeparation. Let vs proceed to the ≈øecond ground which you coÃÑceiue in the≈øe words, A true vi≈øible Church is a company of people called and ≈øeparated from the world by the Word of God, Act. 2.39.19.9. Ro. 1.6.7.10.14.15.16. Iob. 17.14.20. Ezek. 36.38. Phil. 1.5. Act. 2.41:42.47.11.21.24.13.4.34. Ro. 12.5. 2. Cor. 9.13. P≈ø. 110.13. Es. 14.1.44.5.60.8. Zach. 4.6.8.21.22.23. and ioyned together by voluntary profe≈øsion of the Faith of Chri≈øt in the Fellow≈øhip of the Go≈øpell. div.p:
I di≈øtingui≈øh of the middle tearme Called: for there is
a double calling, the one is Gratiae oblatae, where by God onely inuites men vnto Chri≈øt, and offers them Grace, the other Gratiae inditae & infu≈øae, whereby hee not only offers but infu≈øeth grace al≈øo into them. The former Calling maketh not a man of the Church: for hee that is no otherwi≈øe called, an≈øwereth not by Faith, nor commeth vnto Chri≈øt, but remaineth ≈øtill in infidelity, and ≈øo is vtterly excluded out of the Church. Of the latter Calling I di≈øtingui≈øh againe, for it is either that whereby hee be≈øtoweth vpon man Faith of Doctrine, or that whereby ouer and aboue hee giues them Iu≈øtification together with true Sanctification. Faith of Doctrine is either a Partiall or an Entire Faith: a Partiall Faith whereby part onely of the Chri≈øtian verity is held, or an Entire Faith by which the whole ≈øauing truth is belieued and profe≈ø≈øed: And this againe either in Vnity or in Schi≈øme, in Vnity with other Churches of God, or in Schi≈øme with Separation from them. Now all the≈øe and eueryone of them are of the Chri≈øtian Church: for they are neither Gentiles, nor Iewes, nor Turks, being by the calling of grace brought to the profe≈ø≈øion of the Chri≈øtian Religion. But yet among them there is exceeding great difference: for they that hold the entire truth of Chri≈øt are of that Chri≈øtian Church, which is called Oxthodoxall: they that hold it in part onely, are of that Chri≈øtian Church which is Hereticall. They that entirely hold the truth in Vnity with other Churches of God, are of that Chri≈øtian Orthodoxall Church which is Catholicke: they that hold the ≈øame whole truth in Separation from them are of that Chri≈øtian Orthodoxall Church which is Schi≈ømaticall. And ≈øuch is the Church of Browni≈øts to which you haue adioyned your
≈øelfe. But they who hold the whole truth of Chri≈øt not onely in Vnity but al≈øo in Sincerity, being truly iu≈øtified by Faith and Sanctified in the lauour of Regeneration, they I ≈øay are of that Chri≈øtian Orthodoxall Catholicke Church which is Inui≈øible and knowne only vnto God. For although both the per≈øons and profe≈ø≈øion of tho≈øe that are thus called, be vi≈øible, and may by outward ≈øen≈øe bee di≈øcerned, whereby in the eye of Charity they are to bee counted Gods elect people: yet the inward truth and ≈øincerity of the heart is to vs inui≈øible, and ≈øeene of none but onely him who trieth the heart and raines, and ≈øo alone knoweth who are his.

The≈øe di≈øtinctions thus promi≈øed I come at length to an≈øwer your Syllogi≈øme, and demand of you which of the≈øe Callings it is that you meane. If the la≈øt, whereby wee haue receiued entirely to belieue the whole truth of Chri≈øt, and that not onely in Vnity, but al≈øo in Sincerity and with a ≈øanctified heart: then I deny the Maior, for it is not the Vi≈øible but the Inui≈øible Church alone that coÃÑ≈øi≈øts of ≈øuch members. Neither can ≈øuch a Vi≈øible Church bee found vpon the face of the earth: for here corne and cockle, chaffe and wheat, Saints and hypochrits are mingled together, neither can you affirme other of that Church whereunto now you a≈ø≈øociate your ≈øelfe. If you meane any other of the Callings aboue mentioned, or all of them be≈øides this la≈øt, then I deny your Minor. For here in England wee are a company of people to whom not onely grace hath beene offered, but who al≈øo haue receiued grace to belieue the truth of Chri≈øt, and therefore are not Infidels but of the Church of Chri≈øt. Againe we haue receiued to belieue the whole truth, and therefore are an Oxthodoxall not an Hereticall
Church. La≈øtly, wee hold the whole truth of God in Unity with other Churches, and among≈øt vs there are thou≈øands al≈øo who profe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame with ≈øincere and ≈øanctified hearts, and therefore wee are not a Schi≈ømaticall as you are, but a true Catholicke Church. This Minor thus denied you goe not about to ≈øtrengthen with ≈øo much as one argument, and yet hither ≈øhould you haue bent all your forces. About the Maior you be≈øtow a little more paines, endeuouring to fortify it with ≈øixe rea≈øons: which although they bee to little purpo≈øe, yet to giue you the more ≈øatisfaction, let vs briefly examine them. And fir≈øt that which is in order fir≈øt.

argument.p: 1. Cor. 12.27. Exod. 19.5.6. 1. Cor. 14.33. 1. Tim. 3.15. Mat. 13.24.31. P≈øal. 46.4.5.80.1. 1. Pet. 2.5.9. Rev. 1.11.12.13.20. 1. Becau≈øe a true vi≈øible Church is the body of Christ, a Kingdome of Priests, a Church of Saints, the hou≈øhold of God, the Kingdome of heauen, the Citie of God, the ≈øheep of the Lord, a cho≈øen generation, a golden Candle≈øtick &c.

div.p:
The≈øe titles properly belong vnto the inui≈øible Church con≈øi≈øting of tho≈øe who are effectually called by ≈øauing grace. And when they are ≈øaid & affirmed of any vi≈øible Church, you mu≈øt vnder≈øtand that the denomination is in regard of the better part thereof, namely tho≈øe Saints who haue receiued the ≈øpirit of adoption, the earne≈øt penny of their euerla≈øting inheritance, not that no euill men are mixed with them. In Corinth and Galatia as there were many holy and faithfull ≈øeruants of God, ≈øo were there many lewd and vngodly men al≈øo: for it is well knowen that they were much pe≈øtered both with error in doctrine, and corruption in manners. And yet the Apo≈øtle S. Paul neuer ≈øticketh at it to acknowledge
them vi≈øible Churches: which I am ≈øure he would not haue done, had he thought that the mixture of bad and good in the ≈øame ≈øociety did nullify a Church. Nay rather if he had beene of your humour he would haue aduized a ≈øeparation.

argument.p: 1. How ≈øhould it els haue Chri≈øt for the Prophet, Prie≈øt,Heb. 3.1.2.3. & 5, 6.9. &. 12.28. Mat. 28.18.19.20. P≈ø. 110.1.4.1. Pet. 2.4.5.25. Act. 2.41.47. Eph. 1.22.23.2.19.22. & King thereof? or how ≈øhould men know where to ioine and become members of the body of Chri≈øt, with a≈øsurance to haue him their head? &c.

div.p:
It is the Inui≈øible Church, the Church of the fir≈øt borne, as S. Paul calleth it, who≈øe names are enrolled in heauen, Heb. 12.23. vnto which Chri≈øt properly and vniuocally is a Prophet, Prie≈øt, and King. For he is a Head in ≈øuch manner vnto tho≈øe only who are knit together with him in the ≈øame my≈øticall body by the vnity of the ≈øame ≈øpirit, and to whom hee communicateth from him≈øelfe the ≈øweet influence of life, ≈øen≈øe, motion, euen grace for grace, Ioh. 1.16. as S. Iohn ≈øpeaketh. Is he not then a Head al≈øo of the vi≈øible Church? yes, as it is a Church: it is a Church equiuocally, and ≈øo is Chri≈øt the Head thereof. For hypocrits and wicked men mingled with the good are not members of Chri≈øt, as Ambro≈øe ≈øaith, but of the diuell, and therefore Chri≈øt properly is not their Head, Head, and Body being Correlatiues. Who are Elected and by true Iu≈øtifying Faith are ingrafted into Chri≈øts body you may charitably iudge, but cannot certenly know: for God only knoweth who are his. Neuertheles where you ≈øee a Society of men profe≈ø≈øing entirely and in vnity the truth of Chri≈øt, ioine your ≈øelfe vnto them, knowing that they are a Chri≈øtian orthodoxall Catholick Church.
And a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelfe that there are among them ≈øundry who are the deare Saints of God and profe≈ø≈øe the truth in ≈øincerity and vprightnes of heart al≈øo: which if you ≈øhall do together with them, you need not doubt but you ≈øhall haue Chri≈øt to be your head.

argument.p: Mat. 28.18.19.20. 2. Cor. 6.17.18. Lev. 26.11.12. P≈ø. 46.4.5. E≈ø. 59.20.21. Ez. 37.27.28. & 48.35. 3. How ≈øhould it els haue a≈ø≈øurance of the promi≈øes & ≈øeales of Gods Couenant, pre≈øence, and ble≈øsing to belong and appertaine vnto them?

div.p: The promi≈øes of Chri≈øt are proclaimed in ≈øuch mixed companies vnto all on condition of faith & repentance, though actually performed vnto tho≈øe only who actually haue performed the condition by repenting and beleeuing. And to the≈øe the Seales of the Couenant of grace, the pre≈øence of God, & his ble≈ø≈øings do appertaine al≈øo. If then you would bee a≈ø≈øured that both the promi≈øes & ≈øeales belong vnto you, ioine your ≈øelfe to ≈øuch companies, and performe the condition with them, and the Spirit of adoption will certifie and a≈ø≈øure you thereof. If you will not, you mu≈øt ≈øeek out of the world, or hang euer in doubt: for in the world there are none but ≈øuch companies.

argument.p: Act. 2.41.42.47.11.21.24.18.27. Mat. 18.17.20. 1. Cor. 5.4.5.12.13. P≈ø. 149.9. 4. How els ≈øhould it haue or v≈øe the power of Chri≈øt to receiue in members ioyning vnto them, or to ca≈øt out ≈øuch as are ob≈øtinate offenders?

div.p:
It is true there is a power giuen by Chri≈øt vnto the Church ‚Ä¢ o receiue into their Society ≈øuch as profe≈ø≈øe the entire Faith of Chri≈øt in Vnity: but whether they profe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame in ≈øincerity al≈øo, that the Church cannot
tell, and yet receiues them. Againe ≈øhee hath power to cen≈øure and ca≈øt out ob≈øtinate offenders: but yet hereby it appeares that the Church vi≈øible is a mingled coÃÑpany, and that offenders are to bee accounted members thereof vntill by a legall proceeding they be cut off. Suppo≈øe that the Church grow remi≈ø≈øe in denouncing offenders, and tolerate them too much: this argues that corruption is crept into the Church, not that is no Church.

argument.p: 5. Becau≈øe that euery Church as they haue Communion with Chri≈øt, and are one body with him:1. Cor. 10.16.17. Hag. 2.12.14. 1. Cor. 5.6. Num. 19.13.20.22. & 5.2.3. Heb. 12.15. ≈øo haue they Communion al≈øo one with another, and are all one body: and by communion with open wicked retained among them are all defiled.

div.p: The members of euery Church haue (I grant) both Vnion and Communion one with another: the Chri≈øtian Church in the Chri≈øtian Faith, the Orthodoxall Church in the entire Chri≈øtian Faith, the Catholicke Church in the entire Chri≈øtian Faith with Vnity, the Inui≈øible Church in the entire Chri≈øtian Faith with Unity and Sanctity. This la≈øt Vnion and Communion is onely among the Saints: the former may bee both betweene good and bad. That if you ≈øpeake of, you ≈øpeake not of a Vi≈øible Church; and ≈øo nothing to the purpo≈øe: this if you ≈øpeake of, you ≈øpeake vntruly, as wee haue ≈øhewed.

Moreouer, to ≈øay that the toleration or pre≈øence of open wicked ≈øinners in the Church defiles either the godly or the holy things of the godly, is to make the ≈øin of the wicked more powerfull to hinder the de≈øcent of heauenly ble≈ø≈øings, then Chri≈øts loue and vnion with vs is auayleable to conuay them vnto vs. And then was
Chri≈øt much to blame, who ≈øuffered the Sacrament euen at the fir≈øt in≈øtitution to be polluted with Iudas pre≈øence. But you ≈øhould con≈øider that priuate conuer≈øation is one thing, and publicke Church-meetings another; which you ignorantly confounding beguile your ≈øelfe. Priuatly you may refu≈øe at plea≈øure to conuer≈øe with the wicked: in publike a≈ø≈øemblies you cannot auoid them. That is in your owne power, but to remoue them thence is in the Magi≈øtrats only.

argument.p: P≈ø. 84.10. Cant. 16.7. O≈ø. 2.2.19.20. 2. Cor. 6.15. Reu. 1.11.12.20.17.1.5. 6 How el≈øe ≈øhould a true and vi≈øible Church bee truly and rightly di≈øtingui≈øhed from all fal≈øe Churches?

div.p:
Here at length haue you di≈øcouered vnto vs the very ground of your errour, in that you cannot ≈øee how a true vi≈øible Church can bee di≈øtingui≈øhed from a fal≈øe, if notorious offenders bee ≈øuffered to haue any communion therein. Learne then that true and fal≈øe Churches are differenced by hauing or wanting the forme and e≈ø≈øence of a Church. The Chri≈øtian Church is di≈øcerned from Heathni≈øh, Iewi≈øh, Turki≈øh congregations by the Chri≈øtian Faith; an Orthodoxe Church from an Hereticall by an entire Faith: a Catholicke from a Schi≈ømaticall by an entire Faith held in Unity: and the Inui≈øible Church from all other by the Sanctity of euery member: but this is knowne to God onely, the re≈øt may bee di≈øcerned by man al≈øo. You ought therefore to put a difference between a Corrupt Church and a fal≈øe Church. A fal≈øe Church wanteth the e≈ø≈øence and therefore is no Church: a corrupt Church wanteth onely the purity it ≈øhould haue, yet hauing the e≈ø≈øence it is a Church. Which if you had well con≈øidered you would not haue condemned
our Church (if yet ≈øo corrupt as you weene) for no Church, vnle≈ø≈øe you would al≈øo ≈øay a ≈øicke man were no man: much le≈ø≈øe would you haue rent your ≈øelfe from it.

And thus you ≈øee your ≈øecond ground failes you al≈øo, and that you haue not demon≈øtrated that ≈øound members are to ≈øeparate them≈øelues from the communion of the whole body becau≈øe of a few rotten meÃÑbers. Now therfore except you haue ≈øtronger arguments then here you haue ≈øent me, or can adde more ≈øtrength and vertue to the≈øe: I mu≈øt intreate you to remember your promi≈øe that if it could appeare by euident remon≈øtrance that your grounds were ≈øandy & deceitfull, you would retire your ≈øelfe into the bo≈øome of that Church out of which you haue ≈øo ≈øcandalou≈øly withdrawne your ≈øelfe. Which if you ≈øhall ≈øincerely doe, you ≈øhall both quit your ≈øelfe of the fearfull ≈øin of Schi≈øme into which you are fallen, and reunite your≈øelfe vnto as glorious a Church, as I verily beleeue hath beene ≈øince the Apo≈øtolicall and Primitiue times.

q.p: Remember from whence thou art fallen and repent.

div.head: OF VOWES AND SPECIALLY THAT OF VIRGINITY.
div.p: YOVR de≈øire to bee re≈øolued touching the vow of Virginity or Single life, both how lawfull it is, & how farre it bindes. I will endeauour to ≈øatisfie you as breefly and plainly as I can: fir≈øt ≈øhewing you what is the nature and definition of a vow in generall, and then applying it vnto your particular que≈øtion for the more ea≈øie and fuller determination thereof.

1. A vow rightly defined is a promi≈øe made vnto God of things lawfull, by ≈øuch as haue power ≈øo to doe, thereby to te≈øtify their affection and duty towards him. This ≈øhort definition containing the whole and entire nature of a lawfull Vow, I will for your better vnder≈øtanding vnfold in the ≈øeuerall parts thereof.

2. I call it a Promi≈øe not a Purpo≈øe: for a Purpo≈øe being only an inclination of the minde to do ≈øomething,
binds not vnto performance, and is alterable without ≈øin: But a Promi≈øe comprehendeth both a Purpo≈øe and Obligation al≈øo, binding the Con≈øcience vnto performance: ab≈øolutely, if the forme of the Promi≈øe be ab≈øolute, conditionally if conditionall.

3. And this promi≈øe whether it be internally conceiued in the heart or externally vttered by the mouth, it is all one vnto God, who vnder≈øtandeth as well the language of the one as of the other. Yet as in Praying ≈øo in Vowing ≈øpeech is not vnprofitable, the ≈øolemnity thereof both more inwardly affecting our ≈øelues, and by example more edifying others.

4. The Party to whom Vowes are to bee directed is God only: for it is a part of diuine wor≈øhip, and enioyned in the third commandement. A part of diuine wor≈øhip I ≈øay ≈øimply if it bee of things commanded, if of things indifferent accidentally only, ina≈ømuch as it is referred to the wor≈øhip of God, and therefore cannot without ≈øacriledge be giuen to any creature.

5.Theol. Pract. comp. tract. 2. c. 8. art. 33. How then can the Popi≈øh Church vowing vnto Saints quit her≈øelfe of notorious Idolatrie? ≈øpecially ≈øeing by the confe≈ø≈øion of Molanus a principall champion of hers, a Vow is an act of latria, that is of ≈øuch wor≈øhip as is due vnto God. Neither can ≈øhe cloake her Super≈øtition, with any ≈øhew of Scripture:De cult. Sanct. c. 9. for Bellarmin him≈øelfe freely acknowledgeth, that when the holy Scriptures were written, the cu≈øtome of vowing vnto Saints was not yet begun.

6. The matter of a vow is things lawfull, whether they be nece≈ø≈øary as being commanded, or arbitrary as being neither forbidden nor commanded. For that duties commanded may be vowed appeareth euen by the
vow in Bapti≈øme.In P≈øal. 46. And although vertues, as Chry≈øo≈øtom ≈øaith, be due vnto God albeit they be not promi≈øed: yet what letteth but what God bindeth vs vnto by precept, we by vow as by a new knot may al≈øo bind our ≈øelues vnto.

De Monach. c. 19.7. Bellarmin indeed is bold and affirmeth that it is the common opinion of Diuines, that the Promi≈øe in Bapti≈øme is not properly a vow: In≈øtit. Mor. l. 11. c. 14. but Azorius his fellow. Ie≈øuite can tell him otherwi≈øe, that the ancient Diuines together with the Ma≈øter of the Sentences ≈øeeme to thinke that Bapti≈øme is a vow properly and truly ≈øo called.

8. That things of an indifferent and middle nature may al≈øo be Vowed is granted of all hands, God hauing permitted vnto the Church and members thereof iudgement and di≈øpen≈øation of them. Yet this mu≈øt be vnder≈øtood with caution: for ≈øeeing as Saint Paul ≈øaith, tho≈øe things that are lawfull are not alwayes expedient, and things otherwi≈øe lawfull may in regard of circum≈øtance become vnlawfull, tho≈øe indifferent things that are inue≈øted with ≈øuch circum≈øtances cea≈øe during the while to be the matter of a Vow.

9. Iu≈øtly therefore are excluded from being the matter of a Uow, fir≈øt all ≈øuch actions as are in their owne nature euill, next ≈øuch as hinder a greater good, then tho≈øe that cro≈ø≈øe the generall Vow made in Bapti≈øme, farther ≈øuch as are impo≈ø≈øible and out of our power, moreouer ≈øuch as are friuolous and vnprofitable, finally tho≈øe things that are naturally nece≈ø≈øary, and if there be any other be≈øides of the like quality.

10. I adde farther by ≈øuch as haue power ≈øo to doe: for none may Vow but they who by their vocation haue liberty thereunto. Now this vocation in regard of things commanded extendeth vniuer≈øally vnto all, and therefore
it is free for euery man to vow them. But in re≈øpect of things indifferent it ≈øtretcheth not ≈øo farre: For fir≈øt they who by rea≈øon of age or di≈øtemper haue not the v≈øe of rea≈øon or iudgment, ≈øecondly they who are vnder the authority, and iuri≈ødiction of others, hauing not power of them≈øelues becau≈øe of their calling may not nor cannot lawfully vow without the con≈øent and good liking of their ≈øuperiors.Num. 30.

11. This condemnes the impious practice of Popi≈øh Friers, who inueigle yong youths from the obedience of their parents, and without their con≈øents intangle them in the vow of Mona≈øticall life, treading directly in the ≈øteps of their Great-grand-father Eu≈øtathius, again≈øt who≈øe wicked doctrine the Councell of Gangra thus decreed,Can. 16. If any children ≈øhall for≈øake their Parents e≈øpecially being faithfull vpon occa≈øion of Religion thinking it iu≈øt ≈øo to doe, and ≈øhall not rather performe due honor vnto them, reuerencing euen this in them that they are faithfull let them be accur≈øed.

12. Finally the End of a Vow is partly to te≈øtify our affection to God, as namely our thankfulne≈ø≈øe for benefits receiued: and partly our duty in carefulne≈ø≈øe to preuent ≈øinne, and to pre≈øerue and increa≈øe Gods graces in vs. In a word it ≈øerues as an in≈øtrument or helping meanes to further our obedience to Gods Lawes. And becau≈øe the End it ≈øelfe is of greater importance then the meanes conducing vnto the End, ≈øurely Obedience mu≈øt needs bee better then Sacrifice, that is, then the Vow which fitteth only vnto it.

13. The Romi≈øh Church therefore teaching that vowes are of greater perfection in this life, and de≈øerue an higher degree of glory in the next, then the very works
of the Morall law, cannot be excu≈øed of manife≈øt bla≈øphemie.Comment. in Mat. 19. Which it ≈øeemes Cardinal Cajetan al≈øo ≈øaw when he ≈øaid, that Chri≈øt pre≈øcribeth no vow to him that will obtaine perfection of life: becau≈øe the obtaining of perfection con≈øisteth not in the bonds of vowes but in the works them≈øelues.

14. This being the true nature and definition of a vow, I conclude as touching the Obligation or bond thereof, that euery vow thus made vnto God, in ≈øuch Forme, of ≈øuch Matter, by ≈øuch Per≈øons, to ≈øuch End, as wee haue ≈øaid, bindeth the Con≈øcience vnto performance: in ≈øo much as the breach thereof is no le≈ø≈øe then mortall ≈øin, and very di≈øhonorable vnto God. For if lawfull promi≈øes are to bee held with men, much more with God.P≈øal. 15. And if we bee ≈ølack to pay them hee will ≈øurely require them of us, and ≈øo ≈øhould it be ≈øin vnto us.

Deut. 23.21.15. But what if a man haue ra≈øhly vowed that which is vnlawfull? Surely in ≈øuch a ca≈øe it is better to retract the vow, then by keeping it to adde ≈øin vnto ≈øin. For a vow, ≈øaith the Canon, may not be the bond of iniquity: and excellently to this purpo≈øe coun≈øelleth Philo the Iew, De leg. ≈øpec. Let ≈øuch a one therefore ab≈øtaine, ≈øaith he, and humbly entreat God of his Clemency to pardon the vnadui≈øed ra≈øhnes wherby he was ≈øo headlongly carried to ≈øweare: for to double the offence when thou may≈øt di≈øcharge thy ≈øelfe of the one halfe, is extreame madnes, and ≈øcarcely euer curable.

16. Now let vs apply what hath beene ≈øaid vnto the particular vow of virginity, or ≈øingle life. And fir≈øt whereas nothing may be the Matter of a vow but that which is lawfull, and things lawfull are of two ≈øorts, eyther ≈øimply and morally good, or arbitrary and indifferent:
≈øurely Virginity cannot be ranked in the fir≈øt order. For to v≈øe no other then Ger≈øons rea≈øons,P. 3. de Con≈øil. Euang. & ≈øtat. perfect. Morall vertues are commanded, and are not de≈øtroyed but by vice, and being lo≈øt may bee recouered by repentance. But Virginity is no where commanded, and is de≈øtroyed by Matrimony which is no ≈øinne (although Pope Syricius heretically call it vncleanne≈ø≈øe and pollution of the fle≈øh) and being lo≈øt cannot po≈ø≈øibly be recouered. And therefore how≈øoeuer it may giue a kind of lu≈øter and grace vnto vertue, yet vertue it can be none.

17. Hereupon it followeth that Virginity and Mariage are not in them≈øelues acceptable vnto God one more then another, but that it is the mind which rightly v≈øeth both the one and the other which is plea≈øing vnto him: and that they are rather diuers ≈øorts of life, then differences or degrees of liuing better or wor≈øe. Specially, ≈øeeing as Gregory Nazianzen ≈øaith,In laud Ba≈øil. A man may in mariage attaine as great glory of vertue as in Virginity or ≈øingle life. In a word it is onely a matter of indifferencie.

10. And being indiffereÃÑt, although in it ≈øelfe to be lawfull and free, yet (according to the nature of indifferent things) circum≈øtance may alter the lawfulne≈ø≈øe and freedome of it vnto particular per≈øons. As namely to tho≈øe who want either the Calling, or the Gift: the Gift by which they know them≈øelues able to containe, the Calling by which they are in their owne power, and to di≈øpo≈øe of them≈øelues for their ≈øtate of life.

19. That euery one hath not the Calling becau≈øe it is euident; I will ≈øpare labour to proue it. That euery one hath not the gift, our Sauiour Chri≈øt him≈øelfe witne≈ø≈øeth ≈øaying,Mat. 19 ‚Ä¢ 1.12. All men cannot receiue this ≈øaying but they to whom
it is giuen, and againe, Hee that is able to receiue this let him receiue it: 1. Cor. 7.7.9. and Saint Paul, Euery man hath his proper gift of God, and if hee cannot containe. Whereupon Saint Hierome, Contr. Iouin. l. 1. If all could bee Virgins our Lord Chri≈øt would neuer haue ≈øaid, Hee that can receiue it, let him receiue it: Contr. Iulian. l. 5. c. 10. otherwi≈øe as Saint Augu≈øtin ≈øaith, Hee might haue ≈øaid, All receiue not this ≈øaying but they that will, if it be true which they ≈øay.

20. Now they that want the Calling and yet Vow ≈øo, tran≈øgre≈ø≈øe the fift Commandement withdrawing their obedience from their ≈øuperiors in tho≈øe things wherein they owe obedience.Ep. 199. In regard whereof S. Augu≈øtin ≈øharply reproueth Editia for Vowing continency without her husbands con≈øent. And they that want the Gift ≈øo doing intolerably abu≈øe, and in mo≈øt pre≈øumptuous manner tempt the Diuine Maie≈øty, promi≈øing vnto him impo≈ø≈øibilities, or which they are not a≈ø≈øured they can performe. So that vnto tho≈øe which either want liberty by rea≈øon of the Calling, or ability in re≈øpect of the Gift, ≈øuch a Vow is vtterly vnlawfull.

21. But perhaps you will ≈øay, the Gift may bee obtained by Fa≈øting and Prayer, Chri≈øt him≈øelfe hauing thus promi≈øed, Aske and you ≈øhall haue. Fir≈øt grant it bee ≈øo, yet is it very prepo≈øterous fir≈øt to vow, and then to ≈øeeke for the Gift:Pro. 20.25. for as Salomon ≈øaith, It is a ≈ønare for a man after the vow to make inquirie. Otherwi≈øe I deny not but a man may vow Continence if hee be already a≈ø≈øured of the Gift, and that he can containe.

22. Neither doth it follow that euery one which by Prayer ≈øeeketh the Gift ≈øhall obtaine it. For the promi≈øe is to bee vnder≈øtood of tho≈øe nece≈ø≈øary gifts without which there is no ≈øaluation, and not of tho≈øe extraordinary
& peculiar gifts, the want of which no way hindereth ≈øaluation. Tho≈øe if we aske in Faith wee ≈øhall ≈øurely obtaine: the≈øe if we aske we haue no a≈ø≈øuraÃÑce to obtaine,In carm. de rebus ≈øuis & decalam animae ≈øuae. Ad Eu≈øtoch. de cu≈øtod. virg. becau≈øe wee may bee ≈øaued without them. Surely Gregory Nazianzen much complayneth of the inordinate boyling of his lu≈øts in his old age, which he had happily repre≈ø≈øed in his youth. And Hierome al≈øo confe≈ø≈øeth that notwith≈øtanding hee had beene the companion of ≈øcorpions and wild bea≈øts in the wilderne≈ø≈øe, notwith≈øtanding his face was pale with fa≈øting, his body cold, and his fle≈øh dead, yet the fires & heats of lu≈øt ≈øtill were burning in him.

23. But ≈øaith Doctor Bi≈øhop, Continency is nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øaluation vnto all tho≈øe that haue Vowed it: for the breach of the Vow is di≈øhonour vnto God, and damnation vnto them≈øelues, and therefore being nece≈ø≈øary, wee ≈øhall v≈øing the meanes a≈ø≈øuredly obtaine it. This is right to ≈øubiect the prouidence of God in the di≈øpen≈øation of the≈øe peculiar gifts vnto our temerity and ra≈øhnes. I be≈øeech you, if a man haue vowed to prophe≈øie, or to ≈øpeake with ≈øtrange tongues, or to worke miracles, mu≈øt God needs be≈øtow tho≈øe gifts vpon him vpon his importunate ≈øuite, lea≈øt otherwi≈øe hee ≈øhould breake his vow, and hazard his ≈øaluation?

24. Nay rather let ≈øuch a one humbly repent and beg pardon for his ra≈øhne≈ø≈øe, that hee hath ≈øo vnadui≈øedly entangled him≈øelfe in ≈øuch a de≈øperate ≈ønare: and let him in the Name of God v≈øe the remedy which God hath appointed; that is as Saint Paul ≈øaith, to marrie, For ≈øaith he, If they cannot containe, let them marrie: 1. Cor. 7.9. for it is better to marrie then to burne.

25. This indeed, they ≈øay, is good and whole≈øome
coun≈øell for others: but as for Votaries, it is a greater ≈øinne,Sleid. com. l. 4. ≈øaith Cardinall Campegius, for them to marrie then to keep many whores at home. A Prie≈øt marrying, ≈øaith Co≈øter, ≈øinneth more grieuou≈øly then if hee keep a Concubine.Euch. c. 15. Both are euill to marry and to burne, ≈øaith Bellarmine, but the wor≈øe of the two is to marry. Thus you ≈øee, hauing once pa≈øt the bounds of mode≈øtie, how egregiou≈øly impudent and ≈øhamele≈ø≈øe they are growne.

l. 1. ep. 11.26. But of a farre different opinion was Cyprian, If they who haue dedicated them≈øelues to Chri≈øt cannot or will not per≈øeuere, it is better for them to marrie, then through wantonne≈øse to fall into the fire. Haer. 61. Apo≈øtoli ‚Ä¢ i. And Epiphanius, Better is it for a man that is fallen from his cour≈øe of virginity or ≈øingle life, publickely according to the law to take a wife vnto him, and a long time to repent him of falling from virginity, and ≈øo to be re≈øtored into the Church againe, and not dayly to bee wounded with ≈øecret darts, by the wickedne≈øse which the Diuell bringeth vpon him. Thus the Church v≈øeth to teach and with the≈øe medicines ≈øhee healeth. The ≈øame is the coun≈øell both of Hierome and Augu≈øtin.

27. And what madne≈ø≈øe is it for a man hauing incon≈øiderately vowed that which he cannot performe, not to remedy him≈øelfe by marriage which is the ordinance of God, but by fornication, whoredome, and vnnaturall Sodomitrie, which are the works of the Diuell? Is not this with the old Giants furiou≈øly to warre again≈øt God him≈øelfe? And what barbarous cruelty is it ≈øo to tyrannize ouer the Con≈øciences of men in regard of their vnauoidable infirmities, that either they mu≈øt inwardly burne in the ≈øcortching flames of filthy lu≈øt, or quenching them with the ≈øins of fornication or adultery or that which is wor≈øe thru≈øt them≈øelues headlong into the vnquenchable
fire of Hell? But were it not for this doctrine of Diuels wee ≈øhould want one principall argument to proue that Church to be Antichri≈øtian.

28. Which Antichri≈øt, together with his Diuelli≈øh doctrines, as thou ha≈øt already begun to con≈øume with the bla≈øt of thy mouth: ≈øo Come Lord Ie≈øu come quickly, that thou mai≈øt finally al≈øo aboli≈øh them with the brightne≈ø≈øe of thy comming. In the meane ≈øea≈øon of thy goodne≈ø≈øe either grant vs the Gift, or ≈øanctifie the meanes vnto vs, that keeping our ≈øelues cleane both in body and ≈øoule, wee may bee pre≈øented vnto thee as pure and vn≈øpotted Virgins in the la≈øt day. Amen.

div.head: A LETTER.
div.p:
IN≈øteed of a few words which I promi≈øed to write you, I haue here ≈øent this little treati≈øe, which if you diligently read and peru≈øe, it will more fully informe and re≈øolue you then I ≈øhould haue done. Neuerthele≈ø≈øe, that I may in ≈øome ≈øort di≈øcharge my promi≈øe, and not altogether faile your expectation, in few words thus. I would wi≈øh you diligently to remember that to bee grieued and troubled for ≈øinne is a nece≈ø≈øary duty, and that it ought to be ≈øo. For as in the poole of Bethe≈øda there could bee no cure wrought vntill the Angell had troubled the water: ≈øo neither is there any remi≈ø≈øion of ≈øinnes and healing of the ≈øoule, vntill by the worke of Gods Spirit the heart bee bruzed and broken. When ≈øuch an Angell as Peter was, ≈øhall by his powerfull preaching haue pricked the Con≈øcience, and made men both to ≈øee their ≈øinne, and to feele the mi≈øery thereof: then and not before doe they crie out, Men and Brethren what ≈øhall wee doe? Sorrow for ≈øinne is a ble≈ø≈øed ≈øorrow. A broken and contrite ≈øpirit God neuer yet de≈øpi≈øed. Tho≈øe, and tho≈øe alone who feele the heauy
loade and burden of their ≈øinnes doth Chri≈øt inuite vnto him, and vnto them doth hee promi≈øe refre≈øhment. Hee that oftentimes watered his couch with his teares, and as oftenta≈øted the ≈øweet con≈øolations of Gods ble≈ø≈øed Spirit, hath out of his experience ≈øeriou≈øly affirmed that who≈øoeuer ≈øoweth in teares ≈øhall ≈øurely reap in ioy, and a day of reioycing ≈øhall euer ≈øucceed the night of mourning. And to ≈øpeake the truth, ≈øorrow was made for nothing but for ≈øinne. A potion is made onely for that di≈øea≈øe which it is able to cure: and ≈øorrow for that onely which it is able to remedie. Lo≈ø≈øe of friends, health, wealth and the like were neuer yet recouered with weeping: but the teares of true repentance haue euer clean≈øed the ≈øoule from ≈øinne, and purcha≈øed both pardon and fauour from God. Sorrow therefore was made onely for ≈øinne. Mourne then in Gods name for your ≈øinnes: but yet take heed you mourne not as tho≈øe that are without hope. You cannot doe a greater wrong vnto the infinite mercy of God, and the inualuable merits of Chri≈øt your Sauiour, then to thinke them le≈ø≈øe then your ≈øinnes or demerits. If Satan ≈øugge≈øt any ≈øuch thing vnto you, ≈øpare him not, but tell him hee lies: for Gods goodnes cannot bee outreached by mans wickedne≈ø≈øe, and where ≈øinne doth abound, grace doth much more abound. If your ≈øinnes were as red as ≈øcarlet, yet vpon your true repentance God both can and will make you as white as ≈ønow: And of your repentance you cannot well make doubt, there being in you, as you haue confe≈ø≈øed vnto mee, both hearty ≈øorrow for ≈øinnes pa≈øt, and vnfained re≈øolution of amendement for the time to come, which are the two e≈ø≈øentiall parts of true repentance. Yea but you haue committed that ≈øinne which is vnto death and
can neuer bee forgiuen nor in this nor in the next world. If ≈øo, to what end doe you ≈øeeke vnto mee for comfort? And why doe I wa≈øt paper in writing vnto you? But vpon what ground haue you entertayned this conceit? For≈øooth you haue often ≈øworne and for≈øworne again≈øt your knowledge. I will not extenuate your ≈øin: it is I confe≈ø≈øe grieuous and fearefull, neither would I willingly hinder you from a long pennance in ≈øackcloth and a≈øhes for the ≈øame. Howbeit I would adui≈øe you to ≈øteere right betweene the≈øe two dangerous gulfes: for as you mu≈øt not make mole-hils of mountaines, nor frailties of furies, ≈øo neither mu≈øt you of euery ≈øinne, though otherwi≈øe heinous and enormious make that vnpardonable ≈øin again≈øt the Holy Gho≈øt. It is not often ≈øwearing or cur≈øing, no nor for≈øwearing or periury and the like, which God neither can nor will forgiue. For then what ≈øhould become of that worthy Apo≈øtle Saint Peter, who for≈øwore his Lord and Sauiour, euen again≈øt his Con≈øcience, and that not once but thrice, with mo≈øt horrible execration and cur≈øing? you haue not ≈øinned in ≈øo high a nature as Peter did, neuerthele≈ø≈øe now that Chri≈øt looketh backe vpon you as hee did on him, touching your heart with con≈øideration of what you haue done, I giue you good leaue to goe foorth with him and to weep as bitterly as you can. But de≈øpaire not of pardon, nor count it the ≈øinne again≈øt the Holy Gho≈øt, for ≈øo did not hee. That ≈øinne is no le≈ø≈øe then a wilfull, malicious, and ob≈øtinate denying of the foundation, namely that Ie≈øus is the Mediator and Redeemer of the world. It is a totall apo≈øta≈øie from the Faith, when the whole man reuolteth from the whole Chri≈øtian Religion wholly, with an ob≈øtinate re≈øolution neuer to returne to it any more. This
≈øinne I know you are farre from, and you dare not ≈øay you haue committed it. Neither is it po≈ø≈øible for him that is guilty thereof to doe as you now a long time haue done, that is to mourne and lament for his ≈øinnes. His ≈øtubborne and reprobate heart is not ≈øo tender, but being pa≈øt all ≈øorrow and feeling rather reioyceth in his de≈øperate and malicious ob≈øtinacy. More I might write, but let this little booke I ≈øend you bee in≈øteed thereof. It remayneth that henceforward you play the valiant ≈øouldier of Chri≈øt, and ≈øuffer not your ≈øelfe any longer to be led by pa≈ø≈øion, but onely by the rules and directions of Gods ble≈ø≈øed Word. For my part I will not cea≈øe to pray vnto the Father of our Lord Ie≈øus Chri≈øt for you, that this pricke may be eft≈øoones taken from you: or if for you further exerci≈øe and triall hee delay you a little longer, that yet your Faith may ≈øettle and re≈øt vpon that an≈øwer which God gaue vnto Paul being in the like ca≈øe, My grace is ≈øufficient for thee. Farewell.

div.head: THE BLESSED VIRGIN MARY IS TRVLY Deipara, the Mother of GOD.
div.p:
THIS Propo≈øition either in expre≈ø≈øe or equiualent tearmes hath euer been held by all Orthodoxe writers both ancient and moderne: ≈øpecially tho≈øe who haue liued ≈øince Ne≈øtorius broached the contrary here≈øie. This Ne≈øtorius about foure hundred yeeres after Chri≈øt was Patriarch of Con≈øtantinople, who when his Chaplaine Anasta≈øius had publickly taught, that the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Mary ought not to bee called the Mother of God, was ≈øo farre, ≈øaith Socrates,
from checking in him the≈øe bla≈øphemies again≈øt Chri≈øt,L. 7. c. 32. that hee maintained him in it, and reiected him≈øelfe the word Deipara, Euagr. l. 1. c. 7. or Mother of God. Wherefore hee was bani≈øhed into the Ile Oa≈øis: where hee died mi≈øerably, hauing his accur≈øed tongue eaten out with wormes. But as I ≈øay the Church of God hath euer held and defended the contrary, which I proue by vnan≈øwerable rea≈øons. And.

Can. 1.Fir≈øt by generall Councels. In the Councell of Ephe≈øus it was thus decreed. Who≈øoeuer confe≈ø≈øeth not the holy Virgin to bee Genitricem Dei, the Mother of God, let him bee anathema. The Councell of Chalcedon confirmed the ≈øame,Act. 5. ratifying the Acts of the Ephe≈øine Councell. And the fift Councell of Con≈øtantinople thus defines, If any ≈øay the glorious Virgin Mary is not truely but abu≈øiuely Genitrix Dei, that is, the Mother of God, let him bee Anathema or accur≈øed.

Secondly, by ancient Fathers both before and ≈øince Ne≈øtorius, In ad Rom. who all ≈øtile her Deiparam, the Mother of God. Origen largely di≈øcour≈øes, and renders many rea≈øons why ≈øhee ≈øhould bee ≈øo called. Eu≈øebius Pamphili ≈øaith, that the Empre≈øse Helena honored Deiparae partum, In vita Con≈øtantini. the birth of the Mother of God. Cyrill of Alexandria pre≈øident in the fore≈øaid Councell of Ephe≈øus in his Anathemati≈ømes ≈øent to Ne≈øtorius ≈øaith that Marie genuit, In Conc. Eph. carnally begat him that was made fle≈øh, euen the Word of God: and anathematizeth them that deny her to bee Genitricem Dei, Epi≈øt. 1. ad. Chelid. the Mother of God. Gregory Nazianzen, If any belieue not the Virgin Mary to be Genitricem Dei, the Mother of God, Ep. 97. ad Leon. Aug. let him bee ≈øeparated from God. Leo, Accur≈øed bee Ne≈øtorius, who belieued not the Ble≈ø≈øed Virgin to bee Dei Genitricem, the Mother of God. Iohn Ca≈øsian,
It is not lawfull to ≈øay Chri≈øt and not God is borne of Mary. L. 2. de. Incar. Pro≈øper of Aquitani, The Virgin Mary bare Chri≈øt who is God of Heauen. He≈øychius, L. 1. com. in. Lev. 2. Therefore to note the Natiuity of Chri≈øt; the Sacrifice is ≈øaid to bee baked in an ouen, to wit in the Wombe Genitricis Dei, of the Mother of God. Augu≈øtin, Mary therefore begat, Cont. Faelic. c. 12. and begat not the Sonne of God. She begat him when Chri≈øt was borne of her according to the fle≈øh: Shee begat him not when the Sonne without beginning i≈ø≈øued from the Father. Vincentius Lirinen≈øis, Anathema to Nestorius denying God to bee borne of the Virgin. Many more Fathers I could ea≈øily alledge,Ca 21. but I pre≈øume one Decade of ≈øuch witne≈ø≈øes is euidence ≈øufficient.

Thirdly, by latter writers of the reformed Churches,In≈øt. l. 2. c. 14. ¬ß. 4. who maintaine the ≈øame Faith of the Fathers. Caluin, We are to abhorre the Here≈øie of Ne≈øtorius, that was, that Mary is not the Mother of God. Againe, Hee that is the Sonne of God, the ≈øame is the Sonne of Mary. Beza, Referr. Scr. The Church hath rightly defined again≈øt Ne≈øtorius, In Luc. 1.35. that Mary ≈øhould be called
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , the Mother of God. Peter Martyr, Wee confe≈øse that the Sonne of God is borne of the Ble≈øsed Virgin, neither doubt wee to call Mary
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ,Dial. de Corp. Chri≈øt. loc. the Mother of God. Sadeel, Iu≈øtly was Ne≈øtorius condemned, denying the holy Virgin to bee Deiparam, the Mother of God, ≈øeeing our ance≈øtors haue constantly defended that Mary is
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
the Mother of God, De ver. hum. nat. Chri≈øt. though not the Mother of the Diuinity. Danaeus, In Aug. de haer. c. 91. Part. l. 1. It is manife≈øt that Mary may and ought to bee called
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
the Mother of God. Polanus, It is rightly ≈øaid of Chri≈øt that hee is God borne of the Virgin. Loco de Chri≈øt. Bucanus placeth among doctrines repugnant to diuine truth this of Ne≈øtorius, that Mary is not „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
the Mother of God. Tilenus, The Ble≈øsed Virgin is truly called
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
the
Mother of God. Synt. de Nat. Chri≈øt. n. 19. Ser. c. 18. On Creed. Perkins, Hence Mary is called „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ the Mother of God though ≈øhee be not the Mother of the Deity. And, Shee mu≈øt bee held to bee the Mother of the whole Chri≈øt God and Man: and therefore the ancient Church hath called her the Mother of God, yet not the Mother of the Godhead. Praemonit. Finally the great Defendor of the ancient Catholicke and Apo≈øtolicke Faith King IAMES, I acknowledge her to bee the Mother of God, ≈øeeing in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt the humane nature cannot bee ≈øeparated from the Deity.

Fourthly, by the Creed of the Apo≈øtles ≈øo vniuer≈øally receiued of all Churches: wherein all true Chri≈øtians profe≈ø≈øe, that they belieue in Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, the onely begotten Sonne of the Father, and that he was conceiued of the Holy Gho≈øt, and borne of the Virgin Mary. If the eternall ≈øonne of God were borne of the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, then mu≈øt ≈øhee needs bee the Mother of God. The Creed therefore of the Councell of Chalcedon thus expoundeth and openeth it, Borne of the Ble≈ø≈øed Virgin and
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Mother of God.

Neither may wee thinke that the holy Church of Chri≈øt hath vnadui≈øedly or ra≈øhly bel√©eued this doctrine: but vpon firme and vnmoueable grounds both of Scripture and the analogie of Faith. For fir≈øt Scripture euidently teacheth it. That holy thing which ≈øhall bee borne of thee, ≈øhall bee called the Sonne of God, ≈øaith the Angell Gabriel: and Elizabeth, whence commeth thus that the Mother of my Lord ≈øhould come to me? By which place ≈øaith Beza, it is expre≈øly manife≈øt again≈øt Ne≈øtorius that Mary is
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
the Mother of God. Againe, if Mary bee the Mother of Ie≈øus Christ, and Christ be God, it followeth of nece≈ø≈øity that ≈øhe mu≈øt be the Mother of God. Nay
doth not the Prophet directly ≈øay that the child borne vnto us is the mighty God? In a word,E≈øa. 9.6. it will not I tru≈øt be denied, but that Mary is the Mother of him that was Crucified, that died, that ≈øhed his bloud, that was ≈øeene with the eye, and felt with the hand.1. Cor. 2.8. Phil. 2.8. Act. 20. 1. Ioh. 1.2. But it was the Lord of glory that was Crucified, that was obedient to the death, that ≈øhed his bloud: it was the Lord of life that was both ≈øeene and felt. And therefore is Mary al≈øo the Mother of the Lord of glory, the Mother of the Lord of life, the Mother of him that is equall with God, and con≈øequently God, ≈øeeing none is equall vnto God but God.

As Scripture, ≈øo the Analogie of Faith al≈øo confirmeth it. For no rea≈øon can be rendred why Mary ≈øhould not be the Mother of God, but eyther becau≈øe Chri≈øt is not God, or becau≈øe the humanity was the ≈øubject of Conception and Birth before it was a≈ø≈øumpted by the Word, or la≈øtly becau≈øe the Humanity was neuer a≈ø≈øumpted into the Vnity of the ≈øame Per≈øon, but remayned a di≈øtinct per≈øon by it ≈øelfe: all which were the damnable bla≈øphemies and here≈øies of Arius, Photinus, and Ne≈øtorius, the fir≈øt of Arius, the ≈øecond of Photinus, the third of Nestorius. Therefore contrarywi≈øe I argue thus, If Chri≈øt bee God, and the Humanity were at the fir≈øt creation thereof preuented from ≈øub≈øi≈øting in it ≈øelfe, and neuer had ≈øub≈øi≈øtence but in the Word, ≈øo as both Natures con≈øtitute one onely Hypo≈øta≈øis or Per≈øon: certenly there cannot bee two Sonnes, one of God, and another of Mary, but the Sonne of God mu≈øt needs be the Sonne of Mary, and ≈øo Mary be the Mother of the Sonne of God. And as by rea≈øon of this Hypo≈øtaticall vnion Chri≈øt him≈øelfe doubted not to ≈øay, The Sonne of Man came
downe from heauen: ≈øo the ≈øame analogie and proportion of Faith requires vs to ≈øay, The Sonne of God is borne of the Virgin Mary, which as Vincentius Lirinen≈øis ≈øaith, is mo≈øt catholickly beleeued, and mo≈øt impiou≈øly denied.

Much more might be added hereunto: but to them that iudge of per≈øons by the Faith this is too much, and enough euen to them that iudge of Faith by Per≈øons. Only from hence I inferre fir≈øt that Titius confounding Papi≈øts in open pulpit for calling the ble≈ø≈øed Virgin Deiparam, the Mother of God, either knew not what he ≈øaid, and ≈øo proued him≈øelfe but a nouice in Diuinity: or if he ≈øpake adui≈øedly and out of iudgement, it was no le≈ø≈øe then profe≈ø≈øed here≈øy. Secondly that I di≈øapprouing Titius therein, cannot iu≈øtly bee taxed of tricks or niceties or ≈øpirit of contradiction, vnle≈ø≈øe together with mee, Councels, Fathers, Prote≈øtants, the Apostolicall and Chalcedonian Creed, Scripture and the Analogie of Faith, vndergoe the ≈øame cen≈øure. La≈øtly, that as Seneca (otherwi≈øe an excellent Morali≈øt) ≈øpake very irregularly when hee ≈øaid Drunkennes would ≈øooner be commended in Cato, then Cato condemned for his Drunkennes: ≈øo you (though els I per≈øwade my ≈øelfe a ≈øound and Orthodoxe Christian) much ≈øwarued from the rule of Piety and Faith, when you cho≈øe rather to excu≈øe Nestoriani≈øme in Titius, then with me to condemne him for it. And all lea≈øt ≈øome who haue ouer prodigally be≈øtowed tran≈øcendent and immoderate pray≈øes vpon him, ≈øhould ≈øeeme eyther too weake in iudgement, or too ≈øtrong in pa≈ø≈øion.

lg.l: MY Sonne while you are young
The≈øe precepts learne of mee:
Beare them in mind not on your tongue,
And let them practiz'd bee.
Fir≈øt ≈øee you ≈øerue and feare
The God of heauen aboue:
Then Parents deere, and ≈øuch as beare
The roome of Parents loue.
To lie count it great ≈øhame:
What thereby can you gaine?
If you haue err'd confe≈ø≈øe the ≈øame,
So grace you may obtaine.
Seeke learning greedily:
Then learning what more ≈øweet?
By it you may mo≈øt readily
With wealth and honor meet.
If any ≈øhall you chide
When you haue faulty been,
Thanke him therefore and then take heed
He chide you not agen.
The man that ≈øpeakes you faire
Count him not ≈øtraight your friend:
He hates the child that doth him ≈øpare
When as he doth offend.
Who once hath you deceiu'd
With flattring words and faine:
He when occa≈øion is perceiu'd
Will you deceiue againe.
